The rRNA catalyses the formation of peptide bonds between adjacent amino acids ($\checkmark$). - Any eight of the following: (appropriately labelled and correctly drawn DNA segment can be used in the answer) $\ce{ -> }$ each strand of DNA is a polymer of nucleotides [1] $\ce{ -> }$ each strand has a sugar-phosphate backbone [1] $\ce{ -> }$ four nitrogenous bases A OR adenine AND T OR thymine AND C OR cytosine AND G OR guanine [1] $\ce{ -> }$ two strands are anti-parallel OR parallel but in opposite directions OR one strand is in the 5’ to 3’ direction and the other strand is in the 3’ to 5’ direction [1] $\ce{ -> }$ strands are twisted OR right-handed and turn into a double helix with around 10 base pairs per turn [1] $\ce{ -> }$ nucleotides consist of one phosphate group, one deoxyribose sugar and one nitrogenous base [1] $\ce{ -> }$ phosphate group is bound to the 5’ carbon of the sugar OR deoxyribose OR pentose [1] $\ce{ -> }$ phosphate group is bound to the 3’ carbon OH group of deoxyribose (of the next nucleotide) [1] $\ce{ -> }$ covalent OR phosphodiester bond between phosphate and the sugar [1] $\ce{ -> }$ nitrogenous base OR base is bound to the 1’ carbon of the sugar OR deoxyribose OR pentose sugar [1] $\ce{ -> }$ covalent bond between nitrogenous base and deoxyribose OR sugar OR pentose sugar [1] $\ce{ -> }$ two strands are held together by hydrogen bonds between nitrogen bases of two nucleotides OR 3 hydrogen bonds between guanine and cytosine OR 2 hydrogen bonds between adenine and thymine [1] $\ce{ -> }$ complementary base pairing between nitrogenous bases [1] $\ce{ -> }$ A pairs up with T AND C pairs up with G [1] [8 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: DNA is a nucleic acid, also known as a polymer of nucleotides ($\checkmark$) . Many nucleotides are joined together to form it. One nucleotide consists of three parts; a phosphate group, deoxyribose sugar and a nitrogenous base ($\checkmark$). One end of the phosphate group is bonded to the 5’ carbon of the deoxyribose sugar ($\checkmark$). On the other side of the nucleotide, the phosphate group is bonded to the 3’ carbon sugar ($\checkmark$) of another nucleotide. Both bonds are covalent phosphodiester bonds ($\checkmark$). Repeated alternating sugar-phosphate bonds form the sugar-phosphate backbone ($\checkmark$). The 1’ carbon of the sugar is covalently bonded to the nitrogenous base ($\checkmark$) also through a condensation reaction to make up one complete nucleotide. DNA is a double helix ($\checkmark$) in which nitrogenous bases form the centre of the structure, and both strands are held together by hydrogen bonds ($\checkmark$) between the complementary bases from each strand. A pairs up with T, and C always pairs up with G ($\checkmark$). A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information. [1]

title: Question 44
content: ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/baf04dcc-f4a0-48d2-9a7d-1963add3cf0c/images/19006f6d-bdf7-40b0-a6de-aa5d19c784ed/BI1850.png) [© Revision Village 2024. Created with BioRender.com] - Describe the role of DNA in storing genetic information. [2] - Outline the importance of the antiparallel arrangement of DNA strands in the structure of DNA. [3] - Outline the importance of the diversity of DNA base sequences in the process of evolution. [3] - Discuss the importance of the conservation of the genetic code in understanding universal common ancestry. [2]
markScheme: - Any two of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ genetic code is stored in the sequence of nucleotide bases OR adenine, thymine, cytosine, guanine within the DNA molecule [1] $\ce{ -> }$ groups of three nucleotides OR bases form codons, which correspond to specific amino acids [1] $\ce{ -> }$ sequence of codons determines the primary structure of proteins, which controls the organism’s traits and functions [1] $\ce{ -> }$ double-helix structure ensures stability of genetic information and allows for accurate replication during cell division [1] $\ce{ -> }$ genetic code is degenerate OR multiple codons can code for same amino acid providing some protection against mutations [1] $\ce{ -> }$ genes can be turned on or off OR are used when needed OR can be expressed and repressed [1] [2 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: DNA stores genetic information in the form of codons, which are sequences of three nucleotide bases ($\checkmark$) that code for specific amino acids ($\checkmark$). These codons determine the structure of proteins, which are essential for the organism’s traits and functions ($\checkmark$). - Any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ two DNA strands run in opposite directions OR one strand runs 5' to 3', while the other runs 3' to 5' [1] $\ce{ -> }$ allows the complementary base pairs OR adenine-thymine AND guanine-cytosine to align properly and form hydrogen bonds [1] $\ce{ -> }$ hydrogen bonding stabilises the double helix [1] $\ce{ -> }$ antiparallel strands allow for the twisting of the DNA molecule [1] $\ce{ -> }$ ensures that the DNA molecule is stable and can store genetic information effectively [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The antiparallel arrangement means that one DNA strand runs 5' to 3', while the other runs 3' to 5' ($\checkmark$). This allows the complementary base pairs to align correctly and form hydrogen bonds between adenine-thymine and guanine-cytosine ($\checkmark$). These hydrogen bonds help stabilise the double helix and allow the DNA to twist into its characteristic structure ($\checkmark$). - Any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ leads to genetic variation between individuals within a population [1] $\ce{ -> }$ provides the basis for natural selection, as certain traits may offer a selective advantage in specific environments [1] $\ce{ -> }$ Individuals with advantageous traits are more likely to survive and reproduce, passing their favourable alleles OR genes to the next generation [1] $\ce{ -> }$ over time, advantageous traits become more common, driving evolution and the development of new species [1] $\ce{ -> }$ allows populations to adapt to changing environments, contributing to species' survival [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The diversity of DNA base sequences leads to genetic variation between individuals in a population ($\checkmark$). This variation provides the basis for natural selection, where certain traits offer a selective advantage in specific environments ($\checkmark$). Over time, individuals with advantageous traits are more likely to survive, reproduce, and pass on their favourable genes ($\checkmark$), driving the process of evolution and the development of new species. - Any two of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ genetic code is nearly universal across all living organisms OR there are only a few minor variations in the genetic code observed in certain species [1] $\ce{ -> }$ in nearly all organisms the same triplet codons specify the same amino acids [1] $\ce{ -> }$ universality of the genetic code implies a shared ancestral origin for all organisms [1] $\ce{ -> }$ used in phylogenetic analysis to reconstruct evolutionary relationships, providing strong evidence for universal common ancestry [1] $\ce{ -> }$ conservation of the genetic code helps maintain the integrity of proteins OR reduces risk of mutations that could disrupt essential cellular functions [1] $\ce{ -> }$ despite evolutionary changes in species, the genetic code remains largely unchanged over time [1] [2 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The conservation of the genetic code across all organisms suggests that all life shares a common ancestor, as the same triplet codons specify the same amino acids in all species ($\checkmark$). This universality indicates that the genetic code has been passed down through generations with little change ($\checkmark$), providing evidence for universal common ancestry.

title: Question 46
content: - Distinguish between RNA and DNA. [3] - Explain the importance of orientation and directionality of DNA and RNA. [4] - Describe how the Hershey and Chase experiment demonstrated that DNA carries the genetic information . [8]
markScheme: - Any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ RNA is single-stranded WHEREAS DNA is double-stranded [1] $\ce{ -> }$ RNA has a variety of shapes WHEREAS DNA is a double helix [1] $\ce{ -> }$ RNA contains ribose sugar WHEREAS DNA contains deoxyribose [1] $\ce{ -> }$ RNA contains the nitrogenous base uracil OR U WHEREAS DNA contains thymine OR T [1] $\ce{ -> }$ RNA only contains permanent genetic code in RNA viruses WHEREAS DNA contains permanent genetic code in all cells (except red blood cells) [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: RNA is a single stranded molecule containing ribose sugar and uracil as one of its four nitrogenous bases. DNA on the other hand is double-stranded ($\checkmark$), contains deoxyribose instead of ribose sugar ($\checkmark$), and has thymine instead of uracil ($\checkmark$) as one of its four nitrogenous bases. DNA forms a regular double helix, whereas RNA can form different shapes ($\checkmark$) depending on its role, such as the clover-shaped tRNA and long-stranded mRNA. - Any four of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ 5’ OR 5 prime end refers to the end with a phosphate group bound to the 5th carbon of the deoxyribose OR pentose sugar, but not bound to another nucleotide, the 3’ OR 3 prime end refers to the end where the 3rd carbon of the deoxyribose OR pentose sugar is not bound to another nucleotide [1] $\ce{ -> }$ DNA has antiparallel strands OR one strand is in the 5’ to 3’ direction, and another strand is in the 3’ to 5’ strand [1] $\ce{ -> }$ single DNA strand is tilted; therefore, two DNA strands can only bind together if they are in antiparallel orientation [1] $\ce{ -> }$ in DNA replication, one lagging strand and one leading strand are produced [1] $\ce{ -> }$ in DNA replication DNA polymerase only adds free nucleotides to the 3’ end of the growing DNA strand OR adds free nucleotides in the 5’ to 3’ direction [1] $\ce{ -> }$ in transcription RNA polymerase can only add nucleotides in the 5’ to 3’ direction to form mRNA [1] $\ce{ -> }$ translation must start nearest to the 5’ end of the mRNA [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Both RNA and DNA have directionality they have a 5’ and 3’ end. The 5’ end refers to the end with a phosphate group attached to carbon 5 of the deoxyribose, but not attached to another nucleotide, the 3’ end refers to the end where carbon 3 of the deoxyribose is not attached to another nucleotide ($\checkmark$). DNA forms a double helix with antiparallel strands ($\checkmark$). During replication DNA polymerase can only add free nucleotides in the 5’ to 3’ direction ($\checkmark$). During transcription RNA polymerase can only add nucleotides in the 5’ to 3’ direction ($\checkmark$) to form a strand of mRNA. Translation of the mRNA must start at the 5’ end ($\checkmark$). - Any eight of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ bacteriophages OR phage virus was used [1] $\ce{ -> }$ bacteriophage contains an inner core that has DNA and a protein coat [1] $\ce{ -> }$ experiments tested the hypothesis that DNA and not protein carries the genetic information [1] $\ce{ -> }$ bacteriophage OR virus can attach to the surface of bacterial cell OR host and inject substance into the cell [1] $\ce{ -> }$ substance contains information for bacteria cell OR host to duplicate OR produce more bacteriophages OR viruses [1] $\ce{ -> }$ bacteriophages OR virus were labeled with radioactive phosphorus (32P) and radioactive sulfur (35S) OR 32P was incorporated into DNA core and 35S was incorporated into protein coat [1] $\ce{ -> }$ phosphorus is found only in DNA and not protein [1] $\ce{ -> }$ sulfur is found only in protein and not DNA [1] $\ce{ -> }$ Escherichia coli OR bacterial cells were infected with bacteriophage OR virus [1] $\ce{ -> }$ used centrifuge to separate bacteriophage OR virus from bacteria [1] $\ce{ -> }$ virus in liquid OR supernatant did not contain radioactive 32P but bacterial sediment OR pellet contained radioactive 32P [1] $\ce{ -> }$ 32P DNA entered the bacteria OR host cell for replication [1] $\ce{ -> }$ virus in liquid OR supernatant contained radioactive 35S but bacterial sediment OR pellet did not contain radioactive 35S [1] $\ce{ -> }$ 35S protein structure did not enter the bacteria OR host cell for replication [1] $\ce{ -> }$ genetic material needs to enter the bacterial cell in order to produce new viruses [1] [8 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Hershey and Chase's experiment was conducted to investigate whether DNA or protein carries the genetic material. In their experiment, they used bacteriophages ($\checkmark$) to infect bacteria cells. Bacteriophage contains an outer coat made of protein and an inner core containing DNA ($\checkmark$) which makes it suitable for comparing DNA and protein. The bacteriophage can then attach itself to the surface of the bacteria cell and inject the substance ($\checkmark$) which carries important genetic information into the bacteria cell. The bacteriophages were then cultured under two different conditions — one was incorporated with a radioactive phosphorus isotope, 32P and another with a radioactive sulfur isotope, 35S ($\checkmark$). Radioactive elements 32P and 35S were used because phosphorus is found in the DNA structure but absent in protein ($\checkmark$), whereas sulfur, is found in the protein structure but absent in the DNA ($\checkmark$) structure. The bacteria cells were then cultured together with the bacteriophages and were infected with the bacteriophages ($\checkmark$). After centrifugation, it was found that the pellets containing bacteria cultured with the radioactive 32P bacteriophages contained radioactivity, whereas the bacteriophage protein coats in the supernatant didn’t ($\checkmark$). The pellets containing the bacteria cultured with the radioactive 35S bacteriophages did not contain any radioactivity, whereas the bacteriophage protein coats in the supernatant did ($\checkmark$). These provided evidence that DNA labelled with the 32P entered the bacteria cells, whereas the protein which was labelled with the 35S did not ($\checkmark$) enter the bacteria cells. A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information. [1]

title: Question 47
content:
The table shows the number of bases in a single DNA strand that codes for a strand of mRNA. The strand contains no introns.
The letters X, Y and Z represent the percentage of each type of base in the mRNA.
BasesNumber of kilobases (kb) in the DNA strandPercentage of same bases in the mRNAAdenine3123.3Cytosine22XGuanine26YThymine24Z
Which option shows the correct percentages of bases in the mRNA synthesised?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ X = 25.2%, Y= 21.4%, Z = 30.1%
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ X = 21.4%, Y = 25.2%, Z = 23.3%
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ X = 25.2%, Y = 21.4%, Z = 0%
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ X = 21.4%, Y = 25.2%, Z = 0%
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The correct answer is Choice C because there are 103 kb in total in the DNA strand. This means that in the DNA strand, 30.1% of bases are adenine ($\dfrac{31}{103} \times 100$%), 21.4% of bases are cytosine (22/103 x 100), 25.2% of bases are guanine ($\dfrac{26}{103} \times 100$%) and 23.3% of bases are thymine ($\dfrac{24}{103} \times 100$%). In the mRNA, these bases will be matched with their complementary base pair, so that the percentage value in the cytosine row will be the same as the percentage of guanine, so X = 25.2%. Likewise, Y will be the cytosine percentage (21.4%). Z is 0%, as there are no thymine bases found in mRNA, only uracil.
Choice A is not correct because even though X and Y are showing the right percentages, Z is incorrect as it is showing the percentage of uracil, not thymine. Choice B is not correct because the percentages shown are for the DNA not for the complementary base pair of that base (which would be found in the mRNA), Z is also incorrect as it is showing the percentage of uracil, not thymine. Choice D is not correct because the percentages shown are for the DNA not for the complementary base pair of that base (which would be found in the mRNA).

title: Question 48
content:
Which of the following shows the correct components of one nucleosome?

Number of histone moleculesNumber of loops the DNA formed$\hspace{1.5em}$ A. $\hspace{1.5em}$eightsingle$\hspace{1.5em}$ B. $\hspace{1.5em}$eightdouble$\hspace{1.5em}$ C. $\hspace{1.5em}$foursingle$\hspace{1.5em}$ D. $\hspace{1.5em}$fourdouble
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
In one nucleosome, there are eight histone molecules which are basic in pH. The DNA would supercoil around the nucleosome to form a double loop.

title: Question 50
content:
The graph below shows the results of an experiment conducted by a team of researchers investigating the relationship between the composition and melting point of different DNA samples. At the melting point, the DNA double helix separates into two individual strands.
Two DNA samples were compared, one consisting of only PQ pairs and another one consisting of only RS pairs.  Letters P, Q, R and S represent different nitrogenous bases found in the DNA.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d59dd324-98c9-4e4e-91b6-758d5679701c/images/0881eea3-e69e-45cc-ad3b-7c9e377763b5/BI0321.png)


[ © Revision Village 2022]

Based on the results presented in the graph, and your knowledge of nucleotide base pairing (between purines and pyrimidines), deduce which nitrogenous bases correspond to the letters P, Q, R and S.
 P  Q  R  S  A. $\hspace{1.5em}$CytosineGuanineThymineAdenine$\hspace{1.5em}$ B. $\hspace{1.5em}$AdenineCytosineGuanineThymine$\hspace{1.5em}$ C. $\hspace{1.5em}$GuanineAdenineThymineCytosine$\hspace{1.5em}$ D. $\hspace{1.5em}$ThymineAdenineCytosineGuanine
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Adenine pairs up with thymine and cytosine pairs up with guanine. Hence, PQ or RS would either be adenine with thymine or cytosine with guanine (Choices A and D), but definitely not Choices B or C.
Cytosine and guanine pairing has three hydrogen bonds, whereas the adenine and thymine pairing has only two hydrogen bonds. At $95^oC$, there is a smaller percentage of RS-rich DNA melted content compared to PQ-rich DNA.
This shows that RS would be cytosine and guanine pairing (Choice D) and PQ is adenine and thymine. Because the extra hydrogen bond between C and G makes it more temperature resistant compared to A and T.

title: Question 2
content:
Which of the following statements are reasons that RNA is believed to be the first genetic material?


- I.RNA can form spontaneously when nucleotides are presentII.RNA contains ribose as its sugarIII.RNA can function as enzymes




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ I and III
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
RNA is believed to be a potential candidate for the first genetic material due to its ability to form spontaneously from nucleotides (Statement I). RNA molecules, known as ribozymes, can catalyze chemical reactions (Statement III), including their own replication. This is a key reason why RNA is considered the first genetic material—unlike DNA, RNA can both store information and perform enzymatic functions, making it a strong candidate for early life processes.  Choice B is correct.
Choice A only included Statement I and not III, so it is incorrect.
While it is true that RNA contains ribose as its sugar component (Statement II), the presence of ribose is not a primary reason for RNA being considered the first genetic material. Both RNA and DNA contain sugars in their structures, but the key point in favour of RNA as the first genetic material is its ability to form spontaneously. Choices C and D included Statement II and so are incorrect.

title: Question 3
content:
Which statement(s) is/are a necessary requirement for the evolution of the first cells?


- I.DNA having the ability to catalyse reactionsII.Polymerisation of carbon compoundsIII.Spontaneous formation of vesicles




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
There is evidence that simple carbon-containing molecules were present on Earth, millions of years ago, however, for early cells to evolve, they would have needed these simple molecules to form more complex structures such as polysaccharides and polynucleotides (Statement II). Phospholipids can spontaneously form vesicles (Statement III) or microspheres (microscopic hollow spheres made from a phospholipid bilayer), which resemble the plasma membrane of a small cell, this would allow for early cells to develop a different internal chemical environment from their surroundings. Choice B  is correct.
DNA cannot catalyse reactions, Statement I  is incorrect. Choices A, C and D  are incorrect as they include Statement I.

title: Question 5
content:
Why is it difficult for scientists to test hypotheses about the origin of the first cells?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ The conditions on pre-biotic Earth cannot be accurately replicated
- B. $\hspace{1em}$	The first cells are still alive, but are hard to study
- C. $\hspace{1em}$	Fossil evidence of protocells is abundant but hard to interpret
- D. $\hspace{1em}$	Protocells did not contain nucleic acids
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Scientists face significant challenges replicating the exact environmental conditions of early Earth because our understanding of its atmosphere, temperature, pressure, and chemical composition billions of years ago is limited; Choice A is correct.
The first cells appeared billions of years ago and are now extinct. Modern cells are descendants but not the original first cells; Choice B is incorrect.
There is very limited or no direct fossil evidence of the first protocells because they were microscopic, soft-bodied, and lacked durable structures that fossilise well. The lack, rather than the abundance, of fossil evidence is a key challenge to testing the hypothesis about the origin of the first cells; Choice C is incorrect.
Current scientific understanding strongly supports that protocells contained early forms of genetic material, such as RNA molecules. RNA is believed to have played a dual role as both a genetic material and a catalyst (ribozymes), making it central to hypotheses like the RNA world hypothesis.
Nucleic acids are crucial because they enable self-replication and heredity, essential for the evolution of life. Choice D contradicts the accepted hypotheses and is therefore incorrect.

title: Question 6
content:
Which role of RNA supports the hypothesis that it acted as the first genetic material?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ It functions as a primer during transcription
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ It functions as an enzyme used by ribosomes
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ It serves as a template for polypeptide synthesis
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ It transports amino acids during translation
markScheme:
B
$\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: 
RNA has the ability to self-replicate and can also act as an enzyme. These two properties contribute to the hypothesis that RNA was the first genetic material, rather than DNA. Choice B is correct.
Choice A  is incorrect, as transcription does not involve primers. Choice C  is incorrect, as RNA’s role as a template for polypeptide synthesis does not contribute to the hypothesis that it was the first genetic material. Choice D  is wrong, as RNA’s role in transporting amino acids during translation does not contribute to the hypothesis that it was the first genetic material.

title: Question 9
content:
All organisms evolve through natural selection. Which of the following is a direct effect of natural selection on living organisms?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ It promotes the accumulation of beneficial traits in organisms
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ It allowed the last universal common ancestor to outcompete other organisms within one generation
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ It allows organisms that are best adapted to their environment to survive
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ It explains how life began on Earth
markScheme:
C
$\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: 
Natural selection allows organisms that are best adapted to their environment to survive and pass on their genes; Choice C is correct.
Promoting the accumulation of beneficial traits in organisms is a consequence of natural selection, not the direct effect. As organisms with beneficial traits survive and reproduce more, those traits become more common in the population over time. Natural selection is driven by random mutations that may or may not benefit an organism; Choice A  is incorrect. Although natural selection via evolution did allow the last universal common ancestor to outcompete other organisms, it is likely to have been a gradual process that did not occur within one generation; Choice B is incorrect. Natural selection does not address the origin of life itself; it explains how life changes and evolves after it has already begun. ; Choice D  is incorrect.

title: Question 10
content:
Which statement(s) provide evidence for the common ancestry of all existing forms of cellular life?


- I.The universality of the genetic codeII.The machinery for protein synthesisIII.Use of ATP as a common energy currency




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Statements I, II and III are true, making Choice D the correct answer to the question.
The universality of the genetic code (Statement I) suggests that all modern organisms inherited this code from a single common ancestor. The nearly identical genetic code across all known forms of life. implies that the code was established very early in the history of life and has been conserved through billions of years of evolution. If different forms of life had arisen independently, it is highly unlikely that they would all use the same genetic code.
The machinery for protein synthesis,  (Statement II) which includes ribosomes, transfer RNA (tRNA), and messenger RNA (mRNA), is remarkably conserved across all forms of cellular life. This high degree of similarity suggests that these complex molecular mechanisms were inherited from a common ancestor, known as the Last Universal Common Ancestor (LUCA).
ATP as a common energy currency  (Statement III) used by organisms as diverse as bacteria, archaea, and eukaryotes suggests that this energy system was established early in the evolutionary history of life and inherited from a single ancestral organism. If different forms of life had evolved independently, it is unlikely that they would all rely on the same molecule for energy, reinforcing the idea of a shared origin.

title: Question 13
content:
When early lifeforms first emerged on Earth, the levels of UV radiation were much higher than they are today. How did higher levels of UV radiation affect the conditions of the early Earth?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Provided energy for photosynthesis, so plants produced higher levels of oxygen
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ Broke down gases into smaller molecules
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ Mutated DNA nucleotide sequences so that a variety of polypeptides were formed
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ Caused volcanoes to release gases into the atmosphere
markScheme:
B
$\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: 
The high levels of UV radiation broke down gases in the early atmosphere, which provided smaller, highly reactive molecules that eventually formed the building blocks of life, such as amino acids, peptides and ribose. Choice B  is correct.
Billions of years ago, there were no plants, and high levels of UV can affect plants adversely by damaging DNA; Choice A  is incorrect. Although UV radiation affects DNA, DNA was not thought to be present when the first life forms appeared; Choice C  is incorrect. UV radiation did not cause volcanoes to release gases into the atmosphere, this was caused by Earth cooling down after the Hadean aeon; Choice D  is incorrect.

title: Question 14
content: - Describe how the primordial soup hypothesis (an aqueous mix of simple organic molecules) explains the origin of carbon compounds on Earth. [3] - Mitochondria are organelles that are thought to have evolved from early prokaryotes. Discuss whether mitochondria can be considered living or nonliving. [4] - Discuss the evidence and limitations for the existence of a last universal common ancestor. [8]
markScheme: - Any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ early atmosphere OR oceans contained a mixture of gases OR carbon dioxide AND methane OR water vapour OR ammonia OR hydrogen gas [1] $\ce{ -> }$ high levels of UV OR ultraviolet light OR electrical discharges OR lightning catalysed reactions in these gases [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the gases broke down into smaller, highly reactive components [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the smaller components reacted to form larger carbon compounds OR more complex organic molecules [1] $\ce{ -> }$ abiogenesis OR chemical evolution [1] $\ce{ -> }$ in water OR pools OR oceans [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The primordial soup hypothesis states that billions of years ago, there were much higher levels of UV light on Earth which catalysed reactions in the gases of the early atmosphere ($\checkmark$). The UV radiation broke down inorganic molecules into smaller, highly reactive components ($\checkmark$). The smaller, highly reactive components reacted to form larger carbon compounds ($\checkmark$). - Any four of the following: Answers must include at least one argument for living and one argument for non-living to gain full marks Living because… $\ce{ -> }$ they can replicate independently of the host cell OR carry our binary fission [1] $\ce{ -> }$ they contain their own ribosomes to make their own proteins [1] $\ce{ -> }$ they contain their own DNA OR genetic material [1] $\ce{ -> }$ they can make their own ATP OR release energy from organic molecules OR carry out a series of metabolic reactions independent of the host cell [1] $\ce{ -> }$ they have their own membranes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ they can grow larger [1] $\ce{ -> }$ they can excrete waste OR carbon dioxide [1] Non-living because… $\ce{ -> }$ they cannot survive independently outside of a host cell [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the majority of proteins needed for mitochondrial function are synthesised in the host cell [1] $\ce{ -> }$ they do not regulate homeostasis independently of the host cell [1] $\ce{ -> }$ they cannot respond to stimuli OR adapt to changing environments [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Mitochondria can be thought of as non-living because they cannot survive independently outside the host cell ($\checkmark$) and the majority of proteins needed for mitochondrial function are made in the host cell ($\checkmark$). However, it could be argued that they are living as they carry out several life processes, such as reproduction, independently of the host cell ($\checkmark$), and contain their own ribosomes which they use to make their own proteins ($\checkmark$). - Any eight of the following: Answers must include at least one argument in support of a last universal common ancestor (LUCA) and at least one gap in the evidence to gain full marks Evidence that exists for the existence of a last universal common ancestor $\ce{ -> }$ universal genetic code OR all organisms have the same nucleotide bases OR genetic code [1] $\ce{ -> }$ conserved molecular structures OR all organisms have the same degenerate amino acid code OR the same codons code for the same amino acids in all organisms OR there are highly conserved DNA sequences that are common across many domains of life [1] $\ce{ -> }$ genomic analysis of fossils shows that there are many similarities in the DNA sequences between modern and extinct organisms [1] $\ce{ -> }$ specific proteins produced by different organisms can be used interchangeably between species without any major side effects [1] $\ce{ -> }$ all organisms have a similar process for gene transcription and protein synthesis OR transcription and translation [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mutations in DNA OR amino acid sequences can be tracked over time and used as a ‘molecular clock’ to estimate the age of the last universal common ancestor [1] Gaps in the evidence for the existence of a last universal common ancestor $\ce{ -> }$ incomplete fossil record makes it difficult to link all species together anatomically [1] $\ce{ -> }$ very early organisms were unicellular OR made of soft tissues that do not readily fossilise [1] $\ce{ -> }$ lack of direct fossil evidence for the last universal common ancestor [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the last universal common ancestor does not exist today [1] [8 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The last universal common ancestor (LUCA) is proposed to be the evolutionary link between the abiotic phase of Earth’s history and the biotic phase. It is the last ancestor that links all biological life on Earth. Evidence for the LUCA’s existence comes from the fact that organisms are all biochemically similar; they share the same DNA bases ($\checkmark$). Furthermore, the same codons code for the same amino acids in all organisms ($\checkmark$), and all organisms have a similar process for gene transcription and protein synthesis($\checkmark$). Also, there are some highly conserved sequences across the majority of organisms such as ribosomal RNA which is common across all domains of life ($\checkmark$). Genomic analysis of fossils also shows that there are many similar DNA sequences between extinct and modern organisms ($\checkmark$). However, there isn’t a complete fossil record which makes it difficult to link all species anatomically ($\checkmark$), there is no direct fossil evidence for the existence of the LUCA ($\checkmark$) and the LUCA does not exist on Earth today ($\checkmark$).

title: Question 16
content:
Enzymes are needed to replicate and transcribe DNA. Ribosomes are needed to translate the DNA into enzymes. According to the “RNA world” hypothesis, what problem does this present for the first lifeforms to evolve on Earth?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Early life forms could not catalyse reactions.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Early life forms could not self-replicate.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Early life forms were unable to produce proteins.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Early lifeforms did not have cell membranes.
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice C is correct because early life forms likely had neither ribosomes nor enzymes and therefore could not produce proteins. The “RNA world” hypothesis suggests that early life forms were believed to have used ribozymes (RNA molecules with catalytic activity) to catalyse essential reactions.
Choice A is incorrect because the ability to catalyse metabolic reactions is thought to be a requirement for early life forms. Choice B is incorrect because self-replication is also a basic requirement for all living things. Choice D is incorrect because early life forms would have been unicellular, and all cells need a membrane of some kind to maintain structure and chemical gradients.

title: Question 19
content:
Louis Pasteur disproved the theory of spontaneous generation by showing that life did not spontaneously arise from non-living matter but came from existing microorganisms. In his experiment, he set up the following flasks:
Open straight-neck flask containing boiled broth.
Swan-neck flask containing boiled broth (neck allowed air to flow but trapped dust and microbes).
Control flask containing boiled broth and sealed from the air.
The experiment was replicated as shown below:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4f264e0a-eabd-4da0-bfbf-912611178311/images/9f2606f0-633f-460c-b9ba-a9599ddfb669/Pasteur%20flask%20RV.png)


[ © Revision Village. Created using BioRender.com ]

Which two flasks would show the presence of microorganisms in the results?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ R and S
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ S and Q
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ Q and R
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ P and Q
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Flasks R and S (Choice A) would show the presence of microorganisms as Flask R is exposed to the air, so bacteria can enter and Flask S wasn't boiled, so microorganisms originally in the flask were not killed before the flask was sealed.
Flask P (Choice D)  is incorrect as it was boiled first, killing any microorganisms and sealed so no more microorganisms can enter.
Flask Q (Choices B, C, D) is incorrect because it was boiled, killing any microorganisms present. Swan-necked flasks prevent dust particles from carrying bacteria into the flask.

title: Question 20
content: - Nutritional versatility is a key part of archaea's ability to colonise extreme environments. Describe the different sources of energy that archaea use for ATP production. [4] - Discuss the effectiveness of Rubisco’s active site in facilitating carbon fixation. [4] - Explain how fatty acids can spontaneously form vesicles, and why this was important for the development of primitive cells (protocells). [7]
markScheme: - any four of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ photoautotrophs use light to generate energy in the form of ATP [1] $\ce{ -> }$ archaea don’t use chlorophyll OR archaea use a pigment called bacteriorhodopsin [1] $\ce{ -> }$ light is captured and drives a proton OR ion pump to generate ATP [1] $\ce{ -> }$ chemoautotrophs use oxidation of inorganic chemicals for ATP production [1] $\ce{ -> }$ some archaea use hydrogen as an energy source [1] $\ce{ -> }$ some archaea use hydrogen sulfide ($\ce{H_2S}$) OR elemental sulfur, as an energy source [1] $\ce{ -> }$ archaea may use metal ions OR iron OR manganese OR other suitable example as part of their energy metabolism in extreme environments [1] $\ce{ -> }$ some archaea can use fermentation pathways for ATP production in anaerobic conditions [1] $\ce{ -> }$ some archaea oxidise methane OR ammonia OR are methanogens OR are methane-producing archaea [1] $\ce{ -> }$ carbon dioxide acts as a terminal electron acceptor, reducing it to methane [1] $\ce{ -> }$ heterotrophs use oxidation of carbon compounds as an energy source [1] $\ce{ -> }$ archaea can metabolise complex organic molecules like sugars OR alcohols OR proteins [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Photoautotrophs use light to produce ATP ($\checkmark$). A pigment in them captures light and drives a proton pump ($\checkmark$). Chemoautotrophs use oxidation of inorganic chemicals to produce ATP ($\checkmark$). Some archaea are heterotrophic and use the oxidation of carbon compounds as an energy source ($\checkmark$). - any four of the following (at least one advantage and one disadvantage is needed to gain full marks): Advantages $\ce{ -> }$ rubisco’s active site binds specifically to RuBP OR ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate, enabling the efficient initiation of the carbon fixation process [1] $\ce{ -> }$ binds to carbon dioxide, incorporating it into an organic molecule and playing a central role in the Calvin cycle [1] $\ce{ -> }$ active site positions RuBP and carbon dioxide optimally for the reaction to occur OR lowering activation energy [1] $\ce{ -> }$ active site facilitates the formation of the unstable 6-carbon intermediate which then produces glycerate 3-phosphate [1] $\ce{ -> }$ activity is regulated by environmental factors OR pH OR magnesium ion concentration OR other suitable named factor in the stroma, optimising activity under light-dependent conditions [1] Disadvantages $\ce{ -> }$ rubisco can also bind to oxygen instead of carbon dioxide OR can also carry out photorespiration, which wastes energy OR reduces the efficiency of photosynthesis [1] $\ce{ -> }$ carbon dioxide needs to be at relatively high concentration to out compete oxygen for rubisco’s active site, which is not always achievable in certain environmental conditions OR is hot dry climates OR deserts [1] $\ce{ -> }$ relatively slow catalytic rate, requiring large amounts of Rubisco in plant cells to meet metabolic demands [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Rubisco’s active site is highly effective in facilitating the fixing of carbon dioxide because is binds specifically to ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate (RuBP) ($\checkmark$) and also to carbon dioxide, enabling its incorporation into an organic molecule, and playing a key role in the Calvin cycle ($\checkmark$). By correctly positioning RuBP and carbon dioxide, the active site lowers the activation energy required for the reaction ($\checkmark$). This facilitates the formation of an unstable 6-carbon intermediate, which rapidly splits into two molecules of glycerate-3-phosphate ($\checkmark$). However, rubisco can bind to oxygen instead of carbon dioxide, resulting in photorespiration, which wastes energy and reduces photosynthetic efficiency ($\checkmark$). The enzyme’s relatively slow catalytic rate also requires plants to produce large amounts of Rubisco to meet their metabolic needs ($\checkmark$). - any seven of the following (must contain at least two statements for how vesicles form and two for the role of vesicles in protocell development): Fatty acids can spontaneously form vesicles $\ce{ -> }$ fatty acids are amphipathic molecules OR have a hydrophilic OR polar head AND a hydrophobic OR nonpolar tail [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the hydrophobic OR nonpolar tails orient themselves away from water [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the hydrophilic OR polar heads orient themselves towards the water [1] $\ce{ -> }$ in aqueous environments, fatty acids spontaneously form micelles or bilayers [1] $\ce{ -> }$ bilayers can close into spherical vesicles, creating an enclosed compartment that reduces the energy cost of hydrophobic interactions. [1] Role of vesicle formation in protocell development $\ce{ -> }$ vesicles provide compartmentalisation of biochemical reactions, enabling the development of early metabolic pathways [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the selective permeability of vesicle membranes allows controlled exchange of molecules, crucial for nutrient uptake OR waste removal. [1] $\ce{ -> }$ vesicles can grow and divide, a process resembling primitive cell division WHICH is a critical process for the emergence of cellular life [1] $\ce{ -> }$ fatty acid-based vesicles are considered precursors to modern cellular membranes, providing a foundation for lipid bilayer evolution [1] $\ce{ -> }$ primitive vesicles were less stable than modern membranes and required specific environmental conditions for stability and maintenance [1] $\ce{ -> }$ vesicle formation alone does not explain the origin of complex metabolic networks OR self-replicating systems [1] $\ce{ -> }$ experimental evidence supports the RNA world hypothesis, where vesicles could encapsulate RNA and protect it from degradation, supporting early life processes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ vesicles enable localised concentrations of reactants, increasing reaction efficiency compared to dispersed molecules in open water [1] $\ce{ -> }$ vesicles that encapsulated RNA OR other molecules had an evolutionary advantage by protecting their contents from degradation [1] $\ce{ -> }$ primitive vesicle stability depended on environmental factors like temperature OR pH OR ionic concentration, which influenced protocell evolution [1] [7 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Fatty acids spontaneously self-assemble into vesicles in aqueous environments due to their amphipathic nature, meaning they have a hydrophilic (polar) head and a hydrophobic (nonpolar) tail ($\checkmark$). The hydrophobic tails orient away from water, while the hydrophilic heads interact with water, leading to the formation of stable structures ($\checkmark$). In aqueous conditions, fatty acids can spontaneously form bilayers ($\checkmark$), which can then close into spherical vesicles, creating a compartment that minimises hydrophobic interactions ($\checkmark$). These vesicles played a crucial role in protocell development by providing compartmentalisation, allowing for the concentration of reactants and the formation of early metabolic pathways ($\checkmark$). The selective permeability of vesicle membranes enabled the controlled exchange of nutrients and waste, an essential step for cellular evolution ($\checkmark$). Additionally, vesicles had the ability to grow and divide, a process resembling primitive cell division, which was crucial for the emergence of life ($\checkmark$). The encapsulation of RNA within vesicles would have given protocells an evolutionary advantage by protecting genetic material from degradation, supporting the RNA world hypothesis ($\checkmark$). A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information. [1]

title: Question 1
content:
What is a disadvantage to an organism of being multicellular rather than unicellular?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Larger body size
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Ability to adapt to their surroundings
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ The need for a complex exchange system
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Cell differentiation
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Multicellular organisms are comprised of numerous specialised cells, enabling them to achieve larger sizes compared to unicellular organisms. This results in them needing exchange systems, such as the circulatory and respiratory systems, to manage waste removal and to acquire essential substances such as oxygen and nutrients. In contrast, unicellular organisms can rely on simple diffusion. Choice C  is correct.
Choice A  is incorrect because although multicellular organisms often have a larger body size than unicellular organisms, this can be advantageous to them. Choice B  is incorrect, as multicellular organisms adapting to their environment more easily is an advantage. Choice D  is incorrect, as cell differentiation, where cells become specialised for specific functions, is an advantage as it allows for the division of labour amongst cells.

title: Question 2
content:
Which statement about eukaryotic cells is correct?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Eukaryotic chromosomes are circular and the DNA is associated with histone proteins
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ Eukaryotic cells have looped DNA molecules which are not associated with proteins in the nucleus
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ Eukaryotic cells have linear DNA molecules associated with proteins
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ Eukaryotic cells have linear DNA molecules that are not associated with histone proteins
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The chromosomes of eukaryotes are linear, and the DNA is coiled around histone proteins (Choice C). Choice A is incorrect because eukaryotic DNA molecules are not circular. Choice B  is incorrect because eukaryotic cells do not have looped DNA in the nucleus. Choice D  is incorrect because the linear DNA molecules in eukaryotic cells are coiled around histone proteins.

title: Question 5
content:
Which structure in a eukaryotic cell would also be present in a prokaryotic cell?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Nucleus
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Plasma membrane
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 80S ribosomes
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Histones
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Both eukaryotic and prokaryotic cells contain a plasma membrane; Choice B  is correct.
Choices A, C and D  are incorrect as they are present in eukaryotic cells but not prokaryotic cells.

title: Question 6
content:
Which row in the table correctly identifies structures which are present (✓) or absent (✕)  in prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells?

StructureProkaryotic cellsEukaryotic cellsA.$\hspace{1em}$70S Ribosomes in Cytosol✓✕B.$\hspace{1em}$Cell Wall✕✓C.$\hspace{1em}$Mitochondria✓✕D.$\hspace{1em}$Naked DNA✕✓
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Prokaryotic cells contain 70S ribosomes in their cytoplasm, while eukaryotic cells have 80s cytoplasmic ribosomes, so Choice A is correct.
Choice B is incorrect as prokaryotes have a cell wall, but not all eukaryotes do. Choice C is incorrect as prokaryotes do not contain membrane-bound organelles such as mitochondria, but eukaryotes do. *Choice D is incorrect, as prokaryotic cells have naked DNA, whereas eukaryotic cells contain DNA within a nuclear membrane.

title: Question 7
content:
These photographs show the same section of a human retina. What is the reason for the difference between the two diagrams?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/34eb27e0-6237-4360-ac56-27073683e781/images/58faa56f-a89c-49e0-824a-bfbe19119bb9/BI0391_1.2.png)


[Source: Nestl, A. (2012, January 17). File AMD Super resolution Cremer.png - Wikimedia Commons. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved June 16, 2022, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Opthalmology_AMD_Super_Resolution_Cremer.png Copyright under CC BY 3.0]



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ The photograph on the right was taken using an electron microscope.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ The photograph on the right is at a higher resolution.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ The photograph on the right is at a higher magnification.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ The photograph on the right shows the ultrastructure of the cells.
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The resolution is the ability to distinguish between two objects. Choice B is correct.
Choices A and D are incorrect because a photograph taken using an electron microscope would allow the ultrastructure of the cells (fine detail of cells, such as organelles) to be observed. Choice C is incorrect because these photographs are magnified at the same power.

title: Question 9
content:
Paramecium produces enzymes that catalyse different chemical reactions taking place in the cytoplasm. What function of life is demonstrated in this situation?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Excretion
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Homeostasis
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Reproduction
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Metabolism
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice A - Excretion is the removal of metabolic wastes from the organism. Paramecia expel waste products such as carbon dioxide through the process of diffusion.
Choice B - Homeostasis pertains to the ability of living things to maintain a stable internal environment. Paramecia maintain a stable internal condition by expelling excess water using the contractile vacuole.
Choice C -   Reproduction is the biological process by which organisms produce offspring that are biologically similar to themselves. Paramecia can reproduce sexually through meiosis and asexually through mitosis.
Choice D - Metabolism refers to all the chemical reactions in organisms such as anabolic and catabolic reactions. Paramecia produce enzymes that catalyse different catabolic and anabolic reactions in the cell.

title: Question 10
content:
Which organelle has a double membrane?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Rough endoplasmic reticulum
- B. $\hspace{1em}$	Golgi apparatus
- C. $\hspace{1em}$	Nucleus
- D. $\hspace{1em}$	Vacuole
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The nucleus is the only organelle among the options listed that has a double membrane. The nuclear envelope consists of two lipid bilayers: the inner membrane and the outer membrane. Choice C is correct.
Choices A, B and D are incorrect as they all have a single membrane.

title: Question 12
content:
Which structure found in a eukaryote has a double membrane?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Golgi apparatus
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Mitochondrion
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Lysosome
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Endoplasmic reticulum
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Organelles of a eukaryotic cell are enclosed by a single or double membrane. Double membrane-bound organelles include the nucleus, mitochondria, and chloroplasts. So, a mitochondrion has a double membrane.
The Golgi apparatus (Choice A), lysosome (Choice C), and endoplasmic reticulum (Choice D) all have a single membrane.

title: Question 14
content:
Which of the following statements is true of fungal cell walls?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ They are composed of cellulose.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Fungal cells do not have cell walls.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ They are composed of chitin.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ They are composed of peptidoglycan.
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice C is correct because fungal cell walls are primarily composed of chitin. Choice A is incorrect because cellulose is the main carbohydrate that makes up plant cell walls. Peptidoglycan is found in bacterial cell walls, so Choice D is incorrect. Fungal cells do have cell walls, so Choice B is incorrect.

title: Question 16
content:
Below is a micrograph of a bacterium, Marinomonas arctica, which is found in Arctic sea ice.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e4c4e564-261e-4307-9a32-e06985877dc5/images/c403239f-99bf-4c69-919f-90bc200a737a/BI1258.png)


[Source: Gulf of Alaska Seamounts expedition, 2019. Marinomonas arctica.jpg. Wikimedia. Retrieved, September 25th 2023, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Marinomonas_arctica.jpg. Copyright under Public Domain]
Which row contains features of prokaryotic cells such as Marinomonas arctica?

RibosomesCell wallDNA associated with proteinsA.$\hspace{1em}$80SYesNoB.$\hspace{1em}$80SYesYesC.$\hspace{1em}$70SNoNoD.$\hspace{1em}$70SYesNo
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice D is correct because bacteria are prokaryotes, and prokaryotes have 70S ribosomes and a cell wall; they do not have proteins associated with the DNA. Choice A is incorrect because prokaryotes do not have 80S ribosomes. Choice B is incorrect because prokaryotes do not have 80S ribosomes or proteins associated with DNA. Choice C is incorrect because prokaryotes do have cell walls.

title: Question 21
content:
The electron micrograph shows tobacco leaf mesophyll cells.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/277f4f8c-19fc-469f-b9a4-3305fde9bb35/images/b7225a3a-fdc9-4f9f-a955-1e86a3c869ff/BI1557.png)


[Adapted from: Marys, E. (n.d.). A Ultrathin Section of Vegetal Leaf Mesophyll Cells Showing Chloroplast Structure Stock Image - Image of discovery, botany: 211880559. Dreamstime.com. Retrieved April 23, 2024, from https://www.dreamstime.com/ultra-thin-section-transmission-electron-microscopy-tobacco-leaf-mesophyll-cells-showing-chloroplast-structure-ultrathin-image211880559. Royalty free image.]

Identify structures X, Y, and Z in the micrograph.
Structure XStructure YStructure ZA.$\hspace{1em}$mitochondrionnucleusplasma membraneB.$\hspace{1em}$chloroplastvacuolecell wallC.$\hspace{1em}$mitochondrionvacuoleplasma membraneD.$\hspace{1em}$chloroplastnucleuscell wall
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice D is correct because structure X is a chloroplast, structure Y is the nucleus and structure Z is the cell wall.
Choice A is incorrect because X is a chloroplast, not a mitochondrion. Choice B is incorrect because Y is the nucleus, not a vacuole. Choice C is incorrect because both structures X and Y are mislabelled.

title: Question 23
content:
What is the actual width of the cell in this image? The scale bar represents 5μm.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6b591b07-f59c-48c2-9596-d40067442d9b/images/bc4aab5d-8d13-40de-a819-a662fa2d63b0/BI1135.png)


[Source: Adapted from Itayba, Hebrew Wikipedia (2006, March 1). File: Electron Microscope Siemens, 1960.jpg - wikimedia commons. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved March 4, 2023, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Electron_microscope_Siemens,_1960.jpg Copyright under CC BY 3.0]



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 4μm
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 40μm
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 400μm
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 4000μm
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The scale bar is shown to be 5μm in width, which is represented by 0.5cm on the ruler. The ruler indicates a total cell width of 4cm. Therefore, 8 scale bar widths will fit within the cell. Actual cell width = 8 $\times$ 5μm = 40μm.
Choices A, C, and D are incorrect.

title: Question 24
content:
Mesophyll cells are found in plants. Plant cells have unique characteristics that distinguish them from any other cell type.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/860825df-c83f-42a2-959f-858276f1b357/images/a1726d87-2824-4bf2-b6bb-b3a42c682716/BI0575.png)

[Source: Adapted from Zhang, N., Zhang, L., Zhao, L., Ren, Y., Cui, D., Chen, J., ... & Chen, F. (2017). iTRAQ and virus-induced gene silencing revealed three proteins involved in the cold response in bread wheat. Scientific reports, 7(1), 1-16.Retrieved March 27, 2022. From https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5548720/. Copyright under CC by 4.0]
In the micrograph above, one of the cell parts is labelled X. What is the name of this structure?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Chloroplast
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Central vacuole
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Cell wall
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Starch granule
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice C - The cell wall is the outermost layer of plant cells just outside the plasma membrane.
Chloroplasts (Choice A) are membrane-bound oval-shaped organelles (labelled Ch in the image) that are responsible for photosynthesis.
The central vacuole (Choice B) is located in the centre of the cell, not towards the outside.  It is evident in the micrograph provided by the white, empty space in the middle of the cell.
Starch granules (Choice D) are structures consisting of starch.  Their function is to store starch which is produced during photosynthesis. Starch granules are not visible in the micrgraph above.

title: Question 29
content:
Which part of the cell is labelled with the letter P?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8c50f434-e0ff-47b5-b17a-389a3e9bd2a2/images/aeaa4f06-2d32-4828-8370-65b4b9af9ffc/BI0395%20image.png)


[Source: Adapted from Itayba, Hebrew Wikipedia. (2016, March 1). Category: Electron Microscope Images. Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved May 19, 2022, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Electron_microscopy.jpg. Copyright under CC BY 3.0]



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Vacuole
- B. $\hspace{1em}$	Lysosome
- C. $\hspace{1em}$	Nucleoid
- D. $\hspace{1em}$	Nucleus
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice A is incorrect, as the photo shows an animal cell, which can contain smaller, single membraned vacuoles, but the nucleus is much larger. Choice B is incorrect as lysosomes are smaller and have a single membrane. Choice C is incorrect as nucleoids are only present in prokaryotes and are not membrane bound.

title: Question 30
content:
Which of the following supports the theory that multicellularity has evolved repeatedly?


- I.Sexual reproduction is more common in multicellular organisms, allowing for greater genetic diversity.II.Modern eukaryotes are believed to have evolved from larger prokaryotes which engulfed but didn't digest beneficial smaller prokaryotes.III.Fossil evidence indicates that different taxa developed multicellularity at different times in evolutionary history.




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ III only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Fossils provide evidence that different taxa developed multicellularity at different times in evolutionary history, indicating that multicellularity developed independently in different taxa; Statement III is correct. Choice A is correct.
Although multicellular organisms more commonly reproduce sexually than single-celled organisms, leading to greater genetic diversity, this does not directly support the idea of multicellularity evolving repeatedly. It highlights one of the advantages of sexual reproduction, however, single-celled organisms tend to reproduce rapidly by asexual reproduction, which can lead to more effective dispersal and the withstanding of harsher conditions. Statement I is not true. Statement II  is not true as it summarises the theory of endosymbiosis rather than supports multicellularity evolving repeatedly. Choices B, C and D  are incorrect, as they all contain Statement II and/or Statement III.

title: Question 35
content:
Which of the following options correctly identifies the forms of DNA and the types of ribosomes found in prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells?

Prokaryotic DNAEukaryotic DNAProkaryotic RibosomesEukaryotic RibosomesA.$\hspace{1em}$LinearCircular80S70SB.$\hspace{1em}$CircularLinear80S80SC.$\hspace{1em}$CircularLinear70S80SD.$\hspace{1em}$LinearLinear70S70S
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Prokaryotic cells have circular DNA and 70S ribosomes, while eukaryotic cells have linear DNA and 80S ribosomes. Therefore, Choice C is correct. Choices A, B and D are incorrect because they do not have the correct combinations.

title: Question 36
content:
Which process is most likely responsible for the origin of mitochondria as a eukaryotic cell organelle?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Osmosis
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Exocytosis
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Apoptosis
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Endocytosis
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice A – Osmosis is an example of passive transport, which involves the movement of water across a semi-permeable membrane.
Choice B - Exocytosis is an example of active transport that moves large molecules out of the cell to the cell’s exterior.
Choice C – Apoptosis is the process of programmed cell death.
Choice D - Endocytosis is an example of active transport that moves large molecules, parts of a cell, or a cell from the cell’s exterior, into a cell’s interior. This is in accordance with the endosymbiotic theory, which is the most likely process by which mitochondria came to be eukaryotic organelles.

title: Question 38
content:
What feature distinguishes fungal hyphae and striated muscle from the two cell types shown in the images?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/aa05a687-8639-4d5b-b98e-676e515e3db9/images/cb9d1305-aecb-4b44-9d15-1ffb1d245817/bi0756.png)


[Source: Adapted from CNX OpenStax. (2016, May 27). File 04 00 00.jpg. Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved March 5, 2023, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Figure_04_00_00.jpg Copyright under CC by 3.0]



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ They are multinucleate.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ They only have one nucleus.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ They have unusually large cells that contain only one nucleus.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ They contain mitochondria.
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Fungal hyphae and striated muscle are both exceptions to the cell theory as they are much larger than typical cells and are multinucleate. Choice B  is incorrect as the diagrams depict onion epidermis cells and mast cells, which each contain one nucleus. Choice C  is incorrect as both fungal hyphae and striated muscles contain multiple nuclei. Choice D is incorrect as fungal hyphae, striated muscle AND the cells in the diagram all contain mitochondria.

title: Question 39
content:
Which of the following correctly pairs the structure with the type of cell in which it is found?

StructureType of cellA.$\hspace{1em}$Nucleoid regionAnimalB.$\hspace{1em}$Cell wallProkaryoticC.$\hspace{1em}$ChloroplastFungal cellD.$\hspace{1em}$Sap vacuoleProkaryotic
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice B is correct because nearly all prokaryotic cells possess a cell wall that provides structure, support, and protection. Choice A is incorrect because a nucleoid region is characteristic of a prokaryotic cell, not an animal cell. Choice C is incorrect because chloroplasts are found in plants and some algae cells, but not fungi. Choice D is incorrect because sap vacuoles are characteristic of plant cells, not prokaryotic cells.

title: Question 41
content: The micrograph shows a part of a plant cell from the leaf of Anemone sp. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/55c44e62-f294-437f-866e-7723a75ab94f/images/2e2a83c5-f65e-4f81-801c-a67ed0ddb9cf/EM%20of%20chloroplast%20no%20labels.png) [Source: and3k, & caper437. (2009, June 25). File: chloroplast in leaf of Anemone sp Tem 85000x.png - Wikimedia Commons. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved June 13, 2022, from https ://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Chloroplast_in_leaf_of_Anemone_sp_TEM_12000x.png Copyright free] - Label structures in the plant cell above: - using the letter R where starch can be found; [1] - using the letter S where lipids can be found; [1] - using the letter T where cellulose can be found. [1] - Compare and contrast between the structure and functions of glycogen and starch. [4]
markScheme: - - $\ce{ -> }$ arrow labelled R pointing to a lighter oval [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/55c44e62-f294-437f-866e-7723a75ab94f/images/51c8aaf3-7ba5-402f-b12e-e626a9ec4fe8/450ai%201.png) - $\ce{ -> }$ arrow labelled S pointing to the cell membrane OR membrane around chloroplast OR thylakoid membrane OR lipid droplet OR vacuolar membrane [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/55c44e62-f294-437f-866e-7723a75ab94f/images/fc427c88-70d0-4caa-9509-ff244ca0fd32/450aii.png) - $\ce{ -> }$ arrow labelled T pointing to the cell wall [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/55c44e62-f294-437f-866e-7723a75ab94f/images/cc9f3445-e9f2-45b5-acd6-e04606b44b17/450aiii.png) - Any four of the following (should include AT LEAST ONE for compare and AT LEAST ONE for contrast): Compare: $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH are polysaccharides [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH are made up of $\alpha$- glucose molecules [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH have 1,4 and 1,6 linkages [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH are energy storage molecules [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH amylopectin in starch and glycogen are branched molecules [1] Contrast: $\ce{ -> }$ glycogen is more branched IN CONTRAST TO starch, OR amylose of starch is unbranched, amylopectin has few branched chains WHEREAS glycogen is more branched [1] $\ce{ -> }$ Starch is composed of two different polymers, amylose and amylopectin WHEREAS glycogen is composed of only one polymer [1] $\ce{ -> }$ starch is found in plant cells WHEREAS glycogen is found in animal cells [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: Both starch and glycogen are polysaccharides ($\checkmark$) made of $\alpha$- glucose molecules ($\checkmark$), which have 1,4 and 1,6 linkages ($\checkmark$). Starch is composed of two different polymers; amylose (unbranched and forms a helix) and amylopectin (branched), whereas glycogen is composed of only one type of polymer ($\checkmark$). Both amylopectin, in starch, and glycogen are branched molecules ($\checkmark$), but glycogen is more branched than starch ($\checkmark$). Both are energy storage ($\checkmark$)molecules but starch is found in plant cells whereas glycogen is found in animal cells ($\checkmark$). $\underline{\textrm{For additional detail}}$: , see 4:30 in Carbohydrates Key Concept Video: https://www.revisionvillage.com/ib-biology/sl/key-concepts/?keyConceptId=4fa07df3-4cd4-4a65-897b-96212f2186ee

title: Question 46
content:
Which statements about unicellular and multicellular organisms are correct?

Unicellular organismsMulticellular organismsA.$\hspace{1em}$They only reproduce asexuallyContains differentiated cellsB.$\hspace{1em}$Consist of only one cellAll cellular processes are carried out by one organelleC.$\hspace{1em}$Can reproduce sexuallyThey have emergent propertiesD.$\hspace{1em}$Contains differentiated cellsCan reproduce sexually
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice A  is incorrect, as not all unicellular organisms reproduce asexually. Choice B is incorrect, as both unicellular and multicellular organisms contain multiple organelles that carry out different functions. Choice D  is incorrect, because unicellular organisms do not contain more than one cell, and so do not contain multiple differentiated cells.

title: Question 49
content: - Distinguish between a colony of algal cells forming a multicellular sphere, and a multicellular plant such as a water lily. [3] - Draw a labelled diagram which shows the structure of an animal cell. [5] - Describe the evidence for the endosymbiotic theory. [7]
markScheme: - Any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ colony of algal cells are generally undifferentiated WHEREAS multicellular plants like water lilies are composed of different types OR differentiated of cells [1] $\ce{ -> }$ no OR minimal organisation OR minimal division of labour of cells in algal colony, WHEREAS in multicellular plant cells arranged into tissues, organs and organ systems, OR well-defined structures carry out specific roles in plants [1] $\ce{ -> }$ each individual algal cell is capable of performing all necessary functions for life OR survival independently WHEREAS most individual cells of multicellular plants cannot survive independently OR away from the main body of the plant [1] $\ce{ -> }$ each algal cell in a colony is genetically distinct, WHEREAS nearly all cells in a multicellular organism are genetically identical [1] $\ce{ -> }$ development of colonies is often simple OR cells simply join existing colony WHEREAS plants undergo complex developmental processes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ reproduction in an algal colony typically involves asexual methods WHEREAS in multicellular plants such as the water lily typically involves sexual reproduction OR multicellular plants use both sexual and asexual reproduction [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Unlike true multicellular organisms like water lilies, algal colonies lack cellular differentiation and specialised tissues. Individual cells within the colony are genetically distinct and largely independent, being able to perform all vital functions. In contrast, most cells in the multicellular plant are genetically identical ($\checkmark$) and usually do not survive when separated from the plant ($\checkmark$). These cells become specialised ($\checkmark$) and form tissues, organs, and organ systems within the plant. This intricate division of labour ($\checkmark$) allows plants to achieve greater size and complexity. - Any four of the following labelled correctly in an appropriate drawing of an animal cell: $\ce{ -> }$ nucleus (shown with double membrane) [1] $\ce{ -> }$ cytoplasm [1] $\ce{ -> }$ cell OR plasma membrane [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mitochondrion [1] $\ce{ -> }$ ribosome [1] $\ce{ -> }$ golgi apparatus [1] $\ce{ -> }$ rough endoplasmic reticulum [1] $\ce{ -> }$ smooth endoplasmic reticulum [1] $\ce{ -> }$ lysosome [1] and the following: $\ce{ -> }$ diagram drawn without sketchy lines and acceptable size [1] [5 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1ff31851-24a7-4efc-b3a3-080da5df9c59/images/efb7b494-b22f-41fc-8c24-c635f2f9bcac/BI1050.png) [© Revision Village 2022] - Any seven of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ larger prokaryotes OR cells engulfed smaller prokaryotes OR cells [1] $\ce{ -> }$ ingested cell was kept alive [1] $\ce{ -> }$ symbiotic relationship between both cells [1] $\ce{ -> }$ ingested cell acquired a second membrane [1] $\ce{ -> }$ ingested cell is ancestor of chloroplasts OR mitochondria [1] $\ce{ -> }$ chloroplast OR mitochondrial structures provide evidence for the endosymbiotic theory [1] $\ce{ -> }$ chloroplasts OR mitochondria contain 70S ribosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ chloroplasts OR mitochondria contain their own DNA OR looped DNA [1] $\ce{ -> }$ chloroplasts OR mitochondria can conduct transcription OR translation [1] $\ce{ -> }$ chloroplasts OR mitochondria divide in a similar manner to prokaryotic cells OR by binary fission [1] $\ce{ -> }$ chloroplasts OR mitochondria are similar in size to prokaryotes [1] [7 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The endosymbiotic theory explains the origin of some structures in eukaryotic cells, including chloroplasts and mitochondria. The ancestors of chloroplasts and mitochondria were prokaryotes that were engulfed by larger prokaryotes ($\checkmark$). The ingested cells were kept alive ($\checkmark$) and both cells eventually developed a symbiotic relationship ($\checkmark$) with the cell that engulfed them. When the larger cells engulfed the smaller cells, the smaller cells gained a second membrane ($\checkmark$) as they were engulfed via endocytosis. Further evidence for the theory is that chloroplasts and mitochondria contain their own 70s ribosomes ($\checkmark$) so can make their own proteins, and also contain their own DNA ($\checkmark$) so can carry out transcription ($\checkmark$). Chloroplasts and mitochondria are also able to divide in a similar manner to prokaryotic cells ($\checkmark$). A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information. [1]

title: Question 50
content:
The following electron micrograph shows part of an exocrine pancreas cell. Which of the labelled structures is responsible for the production of vesicles for exocytosis?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2f272307-8afa-40f2-baa3-3849afb23e89/images/ec933293-9b93-43e7-a9a2-a31402bd84cb/BI0532.png)


[Source: Adapted from Howard, L.  (n.d.). File: Pancreatic cells - TEM.jpg. Wikipedia.  Retrieved January, 3, 2023, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Pancreatic_cells_-_TEM.jpg. Copyright under Public Domain]
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The Golgi apparatus produces vesicles that contain substances destined for exocytosis from the cell. The Golgi apparatus is composed of stacks of flattened pouches called cisternae. These appear in a micrograph as the stacked, flattened discs indicated by Choice C.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2f272307-8afa-40f2-baa3-3849afb23e89/images/72bfb0b1-4b14-4045-980a-bd0565c72938/BI0532A.png)


[Source: Adapted from Howard, L.  (n.d.). File: Pancreatic cells - TEM.jpg. Wikipedia.  Retrieved January, 3, 2023, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Pancreatic_cells_-_TEM.jpg. Copyright under Public Domain]
Choice A is the plasma membrane, Choice B is a lysosome and Choice D is the nucleus.

title: Question 52
content:
Which statements about chloroplasts and mitochondria support the endosymbiotic theory?

ChloroplastsMitochondria$\hspace{1em}$A.$\hspace{1em}$Contain 70S ribosomesContain cristae$\hspace{1em}$B.$\hspace{1em}$Found in prokaryotesContain 80S ribosomes$\hspace{1em}$C.$\hspace{1em}$Have a single membraneContain circular DNA$\hspace{1em}$D.$\hspace{1em}$Contain 70S ribosomesHave a double membrane
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The endosymbiotic theory states that larger prokaryotes engulfed smaller prokaryotes, which were the ancestors of modern chloroplasts and mitochondria. The smaller prokaryotes were engulfed via endocytosis, so they have their original membrane as well as the membrane of the larger prokaryote.   Both chloroplasts and mitochondria have 70S ribosomes and a double membrane. Choice D is correct.
Choice A is incorrect because the fact that mitochondria contain cristae is not due to the endosymbiotic theory. Choice B  is incorrect because chloroplasts are not found in prokaryotes. Choice C  is incorrect because chloroplasts have a double membrane.

title: Question 53
content: - Outline the steps in calculating the magnification of a micrograph. [4] - Describe the steps taken to focus on a specimen using the 40x objective lens of a light microscope. [4]
markScheme: - Any four of the following: $\ce{->}$ measure (using a ruler) the scale bar on the drawing OR micrograph [1] $\ce{->}$ note the stated length which the scale bar represents [1] $\ce{->}$ convert the represented and real length or scale bar into the same units [1] $\ce{->}$ M= I/A OR any correct example of the calculation [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: To calculate the magnification of a microphotograph, the first step is to measure the scale bar using a ruler ($\checkmark$). The second step is to note the length the scale bar represents ($\checkmark$). This gives you the actual size of the image. These two measurements should be converted to the same units ($\checkmark$). The last step is to divide the length measured by the ruler by the length represented by the scale bar ($\checkmark$). During this calculation, units cancel out. Therefore, the magnification does not have units. - Any four of the following: $\ce{->}$ use the lowest power OR 4X objective lens first [1] $\ce{->}$ place the specimen OR slide directly below the objective lens OR on the centre of the microscope stage [1] $\ce{->}$ turn the coarse focus knob to focus on the specimen at 4X [1] $\ce{->}$ adjust the turret OR change the objective lens so the medium power OR 10X objective lens is used [1] $\ce{->}$ refocus on the specimen using a fine focus knob at 10X and 40X [1] $\ce{->}$ adjust the turret OR change the objective lens, so the high power OR 40X objective lens is used [1] $\ce{->}$ while fine focusing always move the lens away from the slide [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Place the specimen in the centre of the microscope stage ($\checkmark$). Use the 4x objective lens first ($\checkmark$) and use the coarse focus knob ($\checkmark$) to focus on the specimen. Adjust the position of the specimen so it is in the middle of the field of view and then switch to the 10x ($\checkmark$) objective lens and refocus using the fine focus knob, ($\checkmark$) by moving lens away from the specimen ($\checkmark$) to prevent lens breakage. Finally, switch to the 40x objective lens ($\checkmark$) and use the fine focus knob to refocus on the specimen.

title: Question 54
content: The micrograph below shows Cyanobacteria, which contain chlorophyll. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c3dfa29a-d486-40b4-9fc1-d44b66ce3fc7/images/937853fc-bf32-495b-aba7-33e0cf82a199/BI1197-SL.png) [Source: Adapted from Thompson L. and Whatson N. (2007, January 1). Cyanobacteria. Wikipedia. Retrieved on September 6, 2023, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyanobacteria#. Copyright under CCO] - Using your knowledge and the micrograph, state two features that would indicate that this is a bacterium. [2] - Outline the structural differences between animal and plant cells. [3] - Explain how light energy is used in photosynthesis to carry out anabolic reactions. [3]
