markScheme: - Any two of the following $\ce{ -> }$ cell wall of peptidoglycan [1] $\ce{ -> }$ naked DNA OR DNA not associated with histones OR proteins [1] $\ce{ -> }$ nucleoid OR DNA free in cytoplasm [1] $\ce{ -> }$ no membrane bound organelles [1] $\ce{ -> }$ 70s ribosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ cell smaller than 10μm [1] [2 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Two features that would indicate that this is a bacterium are it has no membrane-bound organelles ($\checkmark$) and 70s ribosomes ($\checkmark$). - Any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ plant cells have a cell wall, WHEREAS animal cells do not [1] $\ce{ -> }$ plant cells generally have a central vacuole WHEREAS animal cells do not [1] $\ce{ -> }$ plant cells have chloroplasts WHEREAS animal cells do not [1] $\ce{ -> }$ animal cells may have lysosomes WHEREAS plant cells do not [1] $\ce{ -> }$ animal cells may have cilia OR flagella WHEREAS plant cells do not [1] $\ce{ -> }$ animal cells have centrioles WHEREAS plant cells do not [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Plant cells have a cell wall, central vacuole and chloroplasts, whereas animal cells do not ($\checkmark$) ($\checkmark$) ($\checkmark$). - Any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ light energy is absorbed by chlorophyll [1] $\ce{ -> }$ light energy is transferred to electrons OR is used to excite electrons [1] $\ce{ -> }$ light energy splitting water molecules OR photolysis releases electrons for the electron transport chain OR hydrogen ions for use in ATP production [1] $\ce{ -> }$ light energy is used to synthesise ATP from ADP and inorganic phosphate OR NADPH from electrons and one proton [1] $\ce{ -> }$ NADPH OR ATP is used to make larger organic compounds OR glucose OR starch OR other named organic compound from carbon dioxide [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Light energy is absorbed by chlorophyll ($\checkmark$) and is used to excite electrons ($\checkmark$). These electrons reduce NADP+ to form NADPH, which is an anabolic reaction ($\checkmark$). Energy present in NADPH is then used to produce glucose from carbon dioxide ($\checkmark$). This is also an anabolic reaction.

title: Question 56
content:
The figure below shows the results of a study on the evolution of multicellularity. Obligate multicellularity means the organism is always multicellular, facultative multicellularity means the organism is usually unicellular but can sometimes form multicellular structures.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e940829b-1b89-44cf-8a66-34d55df8cf92/images/6b245b5b-8c5e-4ec0-ad11-47b0515ebe5a/Ed2727.png)


[Source: Adapted from Fisher, R. (2013). Group Formation, Relatedness, and the Evolution of Multicellularity. Current Biology, 23. Retrieved April 2025  from https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0960982213005678. CC BY 3.0.]

What can be deduced from this phylogenetic tree?


- I.All mammals are obligately multicellularII.Multicellularity evolved once in eukaryotesIII.All prokaryotes are unicellular




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ I and III
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Statement I is true because mammals are animals, and from the phylogenetic tree, the word animals is boxed(obligately multicellular). 
Statement II is false because multicellularity appears on multiple separate branches that do not share a recent common ancestor, suggesting independent evolution. 
Statement III is false because cyanobacteria are prokaryotes, and the tree shows them boxed, indicating they are multicellular. 
Therefore, Choice A is correct as it only contains the one true Statement I.
Choices B, C, and D are all incorrect as they include one or more of the false Statements II and III.

title: Question 58
content:
The table below compares two specialised cells found in the human body:
Cell TypePrimary FunctionProteins ExpressedSkeletal MuscleMovementActin & MyosinNeuronCommunicationNeurotransmitters & Ion Channel Proteins
Which of the following explains the differences between the specialised cells?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Muscle cells and neurons have different DNA, so they produce different proteins
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Each cell type expresses only the genes needed for its function
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Differentiation permanently deletes unused genes from a cell’s DNA
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Neurons and muscle cells switch functions over time, depending on environmental conditions
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice B is correct. Each cell type expresses only the genes needed for its function, while other genes remain inactive. This selective gene expression leads to structural and functional differences between cells.
Choice A is incorrect. All cells in an organism (except gametes and red blood cells) contain the same DNA. Differences in protein production result from differences in gene expression, not in DNA sequence. Choice C is incorrect. Differentiation silences genes but does not remove them. Choice D is incorrect. Once differentiated, cells do not differentiate again — a neuron will not become a muscle cell later in life.

title: Question 63
content: - Outline the different uses of karyograms. [3] - Distinguish between cells with haploid and diploid nuclei. [4] - Compare and contrast different types of chromosomes. [8]
markScheme: - Any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ karyograms are images of the chromosomes in an organism [1] $\ce{ -> }$ homologous chromosomes are arranged in pairs of decreasing length OR Sex chromosomes are the 23rd pair in human karyograms [1] $\ce{ -> }$ karyograms can be used to identify the sex of an individual [1] $\ce{ -> }$ karyograms can be used to identify conditions caused by trisomy, e.g. Down syndrome OR Patau syndrome OR Klinefelter syndrome [1] $\ce{ -> }$ karyograms can be used to determine if a chromosome is missing OR if part of a chromosome is missing [1] [3 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: Karyograms ($\checkmark$) are images of the chromosomes in an organism. In a karyogram, the pairs of homologous chromosomes are arranged in pairs of decreasing length ($\checkmark$). The sex chromosomes are shown as the 23rd pair in human karyograms. Karyograms can be used to determine if an individual is a biological male or female ($\checkmark$). Two X chromosomes are present in a human female cell, and one X chromosome and one Y chromosome are present in a human male cell. Karyograms can be used to identify conditions caused by trisomy (three copies of a chromosome) e.g. Down syndrome, Patau syndrome, Edward’s syndrome and Klinefelter syndrome). - Any four of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ haploid nuclei have one set of chromosomes, OR one chromosome per type WHEREAS diploid nuclei have two sets OR two chromosomes of each type [1] $\ce{ -> }$ haploid nuclei have one allele for each gene WHEREAS diploid nuclei have two alleles for each gene [1] $\ce{ -> }$ haploid nuclei in humans have 23 chromosomes, and diploid nuclei in humans have 46 chromosomes OR any other valid species example [1] $\ce{ -> }$ haploid cells are usually gametes WHEREAS diploid cells are usually somatic cells [1] $\ce{ -> }$ haploid cells are usually the result of meiosis, WHILE diploid cells are usually the result of mitosis. [1] [4 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: Haploid nuclei have one set of chromosomes($\checkmark$), whereas diploid nuclei have two sets of chromosomes. For example, in humans($\checkmark$), gametes have 23 chromosomes, while somatic cells have 46 chromosomes. Haploid nuclei have one allele for each gene, ($\checkmark$) whereas diploid nuclei have two alleles for each gene. In humans, only gametes($\checkmark$) have haploid nuclei, whereas the rest of the somatic cells have diploid nuclei. - Any eight of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ (within one species) different chromosomes are composed of DNA molecules with different lengths [1] $\ce{ -> }$ (within one species) different chromosomes have different numbers of genes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ (within one species) different chromosomes have different types OR different numbers of genes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ both prokaryotic AND eukaryotic chromosomes contain DNA [1] $\ce{ -> }$ bacterial chromosomes are not associated with proteins, WHILE eukaryotic and archaeal chromosomes are associated with proteins [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic chromosomes are looped molecules of DNA, WHILE eukaryotic chromosomes are linear molecules of DNA [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH autosomes and sex chromosomes contain genes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the human Y chromosome carries information mainly coding for male sex determination and development, WHILE the X chromosome carries information for other body characteristics [1] $\ce{ -> }$ there is only one pair of sex chromosomes, WHILE there can be more than one pair of autosomes (in different species) [1] $\ce{ -> }$ autosomes are pairs of homologous chromosomes of equal length, WHILE two sex chromosomes can be different lengths [1] $\ce{ -> }$ chromosomes can be homologous and non-homologous [1] $\ce{ -> }$ homologous chromosomes are pairs of chromosomes of equal length carrying the same genes, but different alleles, WHILE non-homologous chromosomes, carry different genes [1] [8 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: All chromosomes are made of DNA and contain genes, but they differ in length ($\checkmark$) and in the number of genes ($\checkmark$) and type of genes ($\checkmark$). Similarities and differences between prokaryotic and eukaryotic chromosomes: Both prokaryotic and eukaryotic chromosomes contain DNA ($\checkmark$). Bacterial chromosomes are not associated with proteins, but eukaryotic chromosomes are associated with proteins ($\checkmark$). Prokaryotic chromosomes are looped, while eukaryotic chromosomes are linear ($\checkmark$). Similarities and differences between autosomes and sex chromosomes: Both autosomes and sex chromosomes are made of DNA and contain genes. Autosomes are chromosomes that do not determine sex and do not have genes for sex-linked characteristics; sex chromosomes determine sex and have genes for sex-linked traits. There is one pair of sex chromosomes in a somatic nucleus, but there can be more than one pair of autosomes ($\checkmark$) in a somatic nucleus. X and Y chromosomes are of different lengths, while autosomal homologous chromosome pairs are equal in length ($\checkmark$) Comparing non-homologous chromosomes and homologous chromosomes: Homologous chromosomes are pairs of chromosomes that have genes for the same characteristics and can have the same or different alleles. Non-homologous chromosomes have genes for different characteristics ($\checkmark$). A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information. [1]

title: Question 65
content: - Outline the features of cells that do not conform to the cell theory. [3] - Use named species to explain how unicellular organisms carry out processes of life. [4] - Compare and contrast the structure of prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells. [8]
markScheme: - Any three from the following: $\ce{ -> }$ mature red blood cells do not have a nucleus [1] $\ce{ -> }$ striated muscle cells have many nuclei [1] $\ce{ -> }$ giant algal cells can be seen without a microscope OR giant algal cells are very large [1] $\ce{ -> }$ aseptate fungal hyphae OR fungal hyphae OR Mucor are multinucleate [1] $\ce{ -> }$ phloem sieve tube elements lack nuclei OR do not have many organelles OR have continuous cytoplasm flowing through adjacent cells OR have sieve tube elements to provide metabolic support OR are interconnected cells. [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Mature red blood cells do not have a nucleus ($\checkmark$), mature sieve tube elements do not have a nucleus ($\checkmark$) and striated muscle cells and fungal hyphae have many nuclei ($\checkmark$). - Any four of the following characteristics and a correct way the chosen unicellular organism carries out that process: $\ce{ -> }$ cilia allow movement in Paramecium OR flagella allow movement in Chlamydomonas OR any other suitable mode of movement relevant to a named unicellular organism [1] $\ce{ -> }$ contractile vacuole helps to regulate water potential of the cell OR contractile vacuole has a role in homeostasis in Paramecium OR contractile vacuole helps to regulate water potential of the cell OR contractile vacuole has a role in homeostasis in Chlamydomonas OR any other mechanism of homeostasis that is relevant to a named unicellular organism [1] $\ce{ -> }$ oral groove allows nutrition in Paramecium OR nutrition is by photosynthesis in Chlamydomonas OR correct mode of nutrition for a named unicellular organism [1] $\ce{ -> }$ Paramecium can reproduce asexually by binary fission OR Paramecium can reproduce by conjugation OR Chlorella produce asexually by mitosis [1] $\ce{ -> }$ anal groove allows excretion in Paramecium OR excretion is by contractile vacuoles in Chlamydomonas OR correct mode of excretion for a named unicellular organism [1] $\ce{ -> }$ growth of Paramecium occurs after cell division OR Chlamydomonas grows before and after cell division OR correct mode of growth for a named unicellular organism [1] $\ce{ -> }$ Paramecium sense their environment and respond by movement due to the movement of cilia OR Chlamydomonas have an eyespot to detect light OR correct example of sensitivity for a named unicellular organism [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Paramecia are unicellular organisms that can carry out all functions of life. Paramecia have cilia that allow movement ($\checkmark$). Metabolic reactions ($\checkmark$) happen in mitochondria and the cytoplasm. The contractile vacuole helps to regulate the water concentration ($\checkmark$) of Paramecium by releasing excess water. The oral groove takes in food, so it is responsible for nutrition ($\checkmark$). - Any eight of the following: Answer must include at least one similarity and one difference Similarities: $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic AND eukaryotic cells have plasma membranes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic AND eukaryotic cells have cytoplasm [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic AND eukaryotic cells have ribosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic AND eukaryotic cells have genetic material OR DNA OR RNA [1] Differences: $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells are not compartmentalised BUT eukaryotic cells are compartmentalised [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells do not have membrane-bound organelles BUT eukaryotic cells do have membrane-bound organelles [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells have DNA in a loop OR plasmid BUT eukaryotes have linear DNA OR chromosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells have 70S ribosomes BUT eukaryotic cells have 80S ribosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells do not have a true nucleus OR have a nucleoid region BUT eukaryotic cells do have a true nucleus [1] $\ce{ -> }$ all prokaryotic cells have a cell wall BUT not all eukaryotic cells have a cell wall [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic DNA is naked OR not associated with proteins BUT eukaryotic DNA is associated with histone proteins [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells are smaller THAN eukaryotic cells [1] [8 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells have genetic material ($\checkmark$). Prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells have plasma membranes ($\checkmark$). Prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells have cytoplasm ($\checkmark$). Prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells have ribosomes ($\checkmark$), but prokaryotes have 70S ribosomes, whereas eukaryotic cells have 80S ribosomes ($\checkmark$). Prokaryotic cells do not have a true nucleus, but eukaryotic cells do have a true nucleus ($\checkmark$). Prokaryotic cells do not have membrane-bound organelles but eukaryotic cells do have membrane-bound organelles such as mitochondria ($\checkmark$). Prokaryotic cells have DNA in a loop but eukaryotic cells have linear DNA ($\checkmark$). Not all eukaryotic cells have a cell wall but all prokaryotic cells do have a cell wall ($\checkmark$). A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information. [1]

title: Question 66
content:
Palisade mesophyll cells produce and release large amounts of carbohydrates. Which characteristics would you expect to observe in such cells?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ A high density of mitochondria and a large central vacuole.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ A high density of chloroplasts and an extensive Golgi apparatus.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ A high density of chloroplasts and a large central vacuole.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ A high density of mitochondria and an extensive Golgi apparatus.
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Palisade mesophyll cells are cells in the leaves of plants that produce carbohydrates through photosynthesis. Since photosynthesis takes place within chloroplasts, these cells contain a high density of chloroplasts They also contain a large central vacuole, which occupies the space at the center of the cell and helps maintain the turgor pressure in the cell. The position of the central vacuole ensures the chloroplasts will be pushed near the edges of the cell, where they can receive light. Additionally, the vacuole acts as a storage reservoir for water and other nutrients needed for photosynthesis.
Choice A and Choice D are incorrect because mitochondria are the site of aerobic respiration, during which carbohydrates are broken down to produce ATP. Choice D is also incorrect as the Golgi apparatus packages proteins, not carbohydrates, for export, so Choice B  is also incorrect.

title: Question 69
content: - Outline one way unicellular organisms can carry out each of nutrition, movement and excretion. [3] - Draw a single mitochondrion, and annotate it to outline the role of four labelled structures. [5] - Compare and contrast the structure of E. coli and a palisade mesophyll cell. [7]
markScheme: - Any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ nutrition by diffusion through cell membrane OR engulfment OR phagocytosis OR endocytosis OR photosynthesis OR digestion by enzymes in vacuoles [1] $\ce{ -> }$ movement by cilia OR flagella OR pseudopodia [1] $\ce{ -> }$ excretion by simple diffusion OR active transport OR exocytosis OR contractile vacuoles OR vacuoles storing OR isolating waste before removal [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Unicellular organisms carry out the processes of life in varying ways. They can carry out nutrition by engulfing the nutrients ($\checkmark$) from their surroundings, they can move using flagella ($\checkmark$), and they can remove wastes from the cell by simple diffusion ($\checkmark$). - Diagram must include four of the following labels and annotations: $\ce{ -> }$ outer membrane protective barrier OR contains transport proteins that allow specific molecules to enter the mitochondrion [1] $\ce{ -> }$ inner membrane OR cristae increase surface area for reactions OR contains proteins essential for reactions OR ATP production [1] $\ce{ -> }$ DNA encodes genes essential for mitochondrial functioning [1] $\ce{ -> }$ 70S ribosomes for synthesis of proteins required by mitochondrion [1] $\ce{ -> }$ matrix contains enzymes for chemical reactions [1] $\ce{ -> }$ intermembrane space - allows build-up of protons OR ion gradient for ATP synthesis OR chemiosmosis OR contains enzymes for chemical reactions [1] $\ce{ -> }$ clear drawing with no sketchy lines and of suitable size [1] [5 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ba177021-8efc-4ac3-8984-af65f603bc24/images/51530aa5-3ec2-45cc-8701-1d4b4fd4ec74/BI1049.png) [© Revision village 2022] - Any seven of the following (must contain at least one similarity and/or one difference): $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH E.coli and palisade mesophyll cells have cell OR plasma membranes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH E.coli and palisade mesophyll cells have cytoplasm [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH E.coli and palisade mesophyll cells have a cell wall [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH E.coli and palisade mesophyll cells contain ribosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ E.coli cell wall is made up of peptidoglycan WHEREAS palisade mesophyll cell walls are made of cellulose [1] $\ce{ -> }$ palisade mesophyll cells have a compartmentalised structure WHEREAS E.coli do not [1] $\ce{ -> }$ palisade mesophyll cells have 80S ribosomes WHEREAS E.coli have 70S [1] $\ce{ -> }$ palisade mesophyll cells have nuclei WHEREAS E.coli have a nucleoid [1] $\ce{ -> }$ E.coli can have plasmids OR circular DNA WHEREAS palisade mesophyll cells have linear DNA [1] $\ce{ -> }$ E.coli have external structures such as flagella OR pili BUT palisade mesophyll cells do not [1] $\ce{ -> }$ palisade mesophyll cells have membrane bound organelles such as golgi apparatus, rough endoplasmic reticulum, chloroplasts, mitochondria WHEREAS E.coli do not [1] [7 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Palisade mesophyll cells and E.coli both have cell membranes ($\checkmark$) and cytoplasm ($\checkmark$). They also both can have cell walls ($\checkmark$), however the cell wall in E.coli is composed of peptidoglycan, whereas the cell wall in palisade mesophyll cells is composed of cellulose ($\checkmark$). Palisade mesophyll cells are full of membrane bound organelles such as the golgi apparatus, which gives them a compartmentalised structure, whereas E.coli do not have a compartmentalised structure or membrane bound organelles ($\checkmark$). Both palisade mesophyll cells and E.coli have ribosomes ($\checkmark$), but E.coli have 70S ribosomes and palisade mesophyll cells have 80S ribosomes ($\checkmark$). DNA is also stored differently in palisade mesophyll cells and E.coli. Palisade mesophyll cells store their DNA inside the nucleus and it has a linear structure, whereas E.coli have DNA floating freely in the cytoplasm as a nucleoid ($\checkmark$) and can sometimes contain extra DNA in the form of a plasmid ($\checkmark$). E.coli can also have external structures such as pili or flagella ($\checkmark$). A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information. [1]

title: Question 72
content: - Outline the role of auxin in positive phototropism. [3] - Explain the evidence that supports the theory that eukaryotic cells evolved from prokaryotic cells. [5] - Explain how the products of the light-dependent stage of photosynthesis are used in the light-independent stage to convert carbon dioxide into organic substances. [7]
markScheme: - Any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ light is detected by group of proteins OR phototropins which trigger the movement of auxins by active transport [1] $\ce{ -> }$ auxin efflux pumps move auxin so the concentration of auxins is more on the shadier side and lesser on the side with more light [1] $\ce{ -> }$ plant cells have auxin receptors [1] $\ce{ -> }$ when auxin binds to these receptors ,transcription of genes for enzyme OR expansin [1] $\ce{ -> }$ auxin causes movement of hydrogen ions from cytoplasm into the cell walls [1] $\ce{ -> }$ hydrogen ions and expansion OR enzyme loosens cellulose fibres OR fibres of cell wall [1] $\ce{ -> }$ causes cells on the shaded side of shoot tip to elongate [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Light is detected by phototropins and this triggers the movement of auxins by active transport ($\checkmark$). Auxin efflux pumps move auxins from cytoplasm into cell walls, so that the concentration of auxin is more on the shadier side ($\checkmark$) and less on the side with more light. When auxin binds to receptors on the cells, genes for the enzyme expansin are expressed ($\checkmark$). Expansin, and the pumping of protons from the cytoplasm into the cell wall cause the loosening of cellulose fibres ($\checkmark$) in the cell walls, leading to elongation of the cells ($\checkmark$). - Any five of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ theory of endosymbiosis proposes that mitochondria OR chloroplasts have evolved from free-living prokaryotes that were engulfed OR taken in by endocytosis, by larger cells [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mitochondria OR chloroplasts have naked DNA [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mitochondria OR chloroplasts divide by binary fission [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mitochondria OR chloroplasts divide independently of cell cycle OR cell [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mitochondria OR chloroplasts about same size as prokaryotes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mitochondria OR chloroplasts have 70S ribosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mitochondria OR chloroplasts can synthesise their own proteins [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mitochondria OR chloroplasts have double membranes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mitochondria OR chloroplasts have inner membrane like OR similar in structure to prokaryotes AND outer membrane like OR similar in structure to eukaryotes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ DNA of mitochondria OR chloroplasts is more closely related OR more similar to prokaryotic DNA than to nuclear DNA of eukaryotic cells, OR rRNA OR ribosomal RNA more closely related OR more similar to prokaryotes than eukaryotes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ observations of modern examples of endosymbiosis OR given examples of present day endosymbiosis, provide support for the theory [1] [5 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The endosymbiotic theory supports the evidence that mitochondria and chloroplasts in eukaryotic cells evolved from prokaryotic cells, which were taken in by larger cells through endocytosis ($\checkmark$). The evidence supporting this theory includes the fact that these organelles have naked DNA ($\checkmark$), divide by binary fission ($\checkmark$), can synthesise their own proteins ($\checkmark$) and have double membranes around the outside ($\checkmark$). - Any seven of the following: (drawing showing the Calvin cycle with the steps described below): $\ce{ -> }$ products of the light-dependent reaction are essential for the light-independent reactions [1] $\ce{ -> }$ light-dependent reactions produce ATP, NADPH and oxygen [1] $\ce{ -> }$ ATP and NADPH are used in the light-independent reactions OR Calvin cycle [1] $\ce{ -> }$ light-independent reactions convert carbon dioxide into glucose and other organic molecules [1] $\ce{ -> }$ enzyme RuBisCO fixes carbon dioxide [1] $\ce{ -> }$ causes 1 x RuBP to bind to 1 x carbon dioxide [1] $\ce{ -> }$ 6 C compound is unstable and forms two 3C compounds of glycerate-3-phosphate OR GP [1] $\ce{ -> }$ ATP and NADPH are used to convert glycerate-3-phosphate OR GP to triose phosphate OR TP [1] $\ce{ -> }$ some of the triose phosphate OR TP leaves the cycle to form carbohydrates, most is used to reform RuBP [1] $\ce{ -> }$ regeneration of RuBP requires energy in the form of ATP [1] [7 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Light-dependent reactions of photosynthesis produce ATP, NADPH ($\checkmark$) and oxygen. Oxygen is a by-product, ATP and NADPH are used in the light-independent reactions. In the stroma of the chloroplast, carbon dioxide combines with RuBP ($\checkmark$), a 5C compound catalysed by the enzyme Rubisco ($\checkmark$). The 6C compound formed is unstable and splits into two molecules of glycerate-3-phosphate ($\checkmark$). ATP and NADPH ($\checkmark$) are used to convert glycerate-3-phosphate into triose phosphate ($\checkmark$). Some of the molecules of triose phosphate leave the cycle to form glucose ($\checkmark$) or other carbohydrates, most of it is used to regenerate the 5C RuBP ($\checkmark$). Regeneration of RuBP again requires ATP ($\checkmark$) obtained from the light-dependent reactions. $\underline{\textrm{For additional detail}}$: see 5:26 in Photosynthesis Key Concept Video: https://www.revisionvillage.com/ib-biology/hl/key-concepts/?keyConceptId=cd710a11-a37d-4f93-aed3-30e4e1d75e55 A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information. [1]

title: Question 77
content: - Electron microscopy provides images of cells with significantly higher resolution when compared to light microscopy. Evaluate the implications and limitations of relying primarily on electron micrographs to understand cell function. [3] - Explain how advances in microscopy have contributed to our understanding of cell structure and function. [4] - Discuss the evidence for and against the idea that prokaryotic cells are “simple” compared to eukaryotic cells. [8]
markScheme: - any three of the following, must include at least one implication and one limitation Implications $\ce{ -> }$ fine detail resolution has led to a more detailed understanding of structure-function relationships [1] $\ce{ -> }$ discovery of new organelles and structures [1] Limitations $\ce{ -> }$ requires complex sample preparation [1] $\ce{ -> }$ sample preparation can leave artefacts [1] $\ce{ -> }$ samples must be fixed, dead, meaning no dynamic cellular processes can be observed [1] $\ce{ -> }$ pigmentation or colour is not detected [1] $\ce{ -> }$ maximum understanding comes from combining information from both light and electron microscopy [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Electron microscopy gives us very detailed images, which let us see how the tiny parts of a cell are structured to fulfil their functions ($\checkmark$). It has also led to the discovery of new things inside cells ($\checkmark$). Unfortunately, to prepare specimens for electron microscopy, they must be treated in such a way that they are killed, and so we cannot observe processes happening in real time ($\checkmark$). - any four of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ light microscopy allowed for the initial visualisation of cells and basic structures [1] $\ce{ -> }$ staining techniques have enhanced the visibility of cell components [1] $\ce{ -> }$ fluorescence microscopy enables visualisation and localisation of specific molecules [1] $\ce{ -> }$ live-imaging techniques allow dynamic processes to be observed [1] $\ce{ -> }$ electron microscopy provides significantly higher resolution than light microscopy [1] $\ce{ -> }$ transmission electron microscopy reveals details of the internal structure of organelles [1] $\ce{ -> }$ scanning electron microscopy provides 3-D images of cell surfaces OR cell shape [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Light microscopy first allowed us to see cells and their basic parts ($\checkmark$). Later, staining made it easier to see these parts more clearly ($\checkmark$). Fluorescence microscopy has allowed scientists to visualise and pinpoint the locations of specific molecules within cells ($\checkmark$). Electron microscopy provides far greater resolution than light microscopy ($\checkmark$), making it possible to see internal structures like mitochondria and membranes in fine detail ($\checkmark$). - any eight of the following: In favour $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells lack membrane-bound organelles OR have less compartmentalisation [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells have a single, circular chromosome; eukaryotic cells have multiple linear chromosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells are generally smaller [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells reproduce by binary fission, which is less complex than mitosis/meiosis [1] Against $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells efficiently carry out all life processes within a single cell, demonstrating functional sophistication [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells exhibit diverse and complex metabolic pathways [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells exhibit unique metabolic pathways, ie chemosynthesis [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells can engage in cell signaling [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells have highly specialised adaptations (ie flagellae) [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells have a high surface area to volume ratio, increasing the exchange rate with the surroundings [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells are structurally simpler but functionally complex [1] $\ce{ -> }$ evaluation of the application of the word “simple” [1] [8 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Prokaryotes are generally smaller ($\checkmark$) than most eukaryotic cells, and they reproduce by binary fission ($\checkmark$) instead of mitosis or meiosis. Prokaryotic cells are often called more simple than eukaryotic cells, but it is important to distinguish between structure and function ($\checkmark$). Prokaryotic cells may appear simple, but they still carry out all of the functions of life ($\checkmark$) and have some that are unique to prokaryotes. Although prokaryotes do not have membrane-bound organelles ($\checkmark$), they still have complex metabolic pathways like cellular respiration and even pathways eukaryotes do not have, like chemosynthesis ($\checkmark$). Prokaryotes can communicate with each other via cell signalling pathways like quorum sensing ($\checkmark$) and also have highly specialised structures such as flagellae for motility ($\checkmark$). The term “simple” is an oversimplification of a superficial observation. A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information. [1]

title: Question 78
content:
Which characteristic is not true for both mitochondria and chloroplasts?



- A.	$\hspace{1em}$ They are present in both eukaryotes and prokaryotes.
- B.	$\hspace{1em}$ They are both able to self replicate.
- C.	$\hspace{1em}$ They are both able to synthesise proteins.
- D.	$\hspace{1em}$ They both contain circular DNA.
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Chloroplasts and mitochondria are present only in eukaryotes. Therefore Choice A  is the correct answer.
Mitochondria and chloroplasts are both able to self replicate (Choice B), synthesise proteins (Choice C) and contain circular DNA (Choice D).

title: Question 80
content:
The electron micrograph shows a prokaryotic cell, Cyclotella litoralis. What is the actual diameter of the cell in this image?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ba4f9e8b-a955-4426-94f3-bb5346da7d37/images/2c24792a-990f-42ed-8bfd-64f98a3ec8d6/bi0753.png)


[Source: Adapted from FWC Fish and Wildlife Research Institute. (2011, June 7). Cyclotella litoralis (scanning electron micrograph). Flickr. Retrieved March 5, 2023, from https://www.flickr.com/photos/myfwc/5808259556 Copyright under CC BY 3.0]



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 3.5 cm
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 350 µm
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 3500 mm
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 35 µm
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The diameter of the cell is the total length, along the widest part of the cell; 3.5 cm. When the scale bar, which represents 10 µm, is measured, it is shown to be 1 cm long in the image. 3.5 multiplied by 10 is 35 µm.  Choice D is correct.
Choices A, B and C are incorrect.

title: Question 2
content:
Viruses, compared to living organisms, are very small. Which other characteristic listed below distinguishes viruses from unicellular living organisms?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Contain genetic material
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Contain cytoplasm
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Lack enzymes
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Genetic material is surrounded by a capsid
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice D is correct because The structure of all viruses includes the presence of a capsid, which surrounds the genetic material (Choice D). Both viruses and living organisms contain genetic material (Choice A). Unicellular living organisms contain cytoplasm (Choice B).  Some viruses lack enzymes, but not all viruses lack enzymes (Choice C).

title: Question 3
content:
Bacteriophages and coronaviruses are both viruses that affect living organisms. Which structures are present in both bacteriophages and coronaviruses?


- I.cytoplasmII.capsidIII.genetic material




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice C is correct because bacteriophages and coronavirus have a capsid and genetic material, and do not have cytoplasm (Choice A, Choice B, and Choice D).

title: Question 9
content:
Which gives the best summary of the action of reverse transcriptase?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ viral DNA $\rarr$ viral RNA
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ viral RNA $\rarr$ viral DNA
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ viral RNA $\rarr$ host cell RNA
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ viral RNA $\rarr$ host cell DNA
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice B is correct because reverse transcriptase is an enzyme used by retroviruses (e.g. HIV) to convert their RNA genome into a DNA copy. This DNA copy is then integrated into the host cell’s genome, allowing the virus to hijack the host's transcription and translation machinery to produce viral proteins and replicate itself.
Choice A is incorrect because a DNA-containing virus would simply use the host cell’s replication mechanisms to replicate its DNA; there would be no need for reverse transcription.
Choice C is incorrect because reverse transcription involves the conversion of RNA into DNA.
Choice D is incorrect because, whilst the viral DNA copy does get incorporated into the host cell’s genome, this cannot be regarded as host cell DNA as it remains distinct from the host's original DNA. It is not accurate to refer to this DNA as "host cell DNA" since it originates from the virus.

title: Question 10
content:
The origin of viruses is an area of active research and exploration. Which statement is not evidence that viruses have origins in other organisms?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Similarities between genome sequence in viral and cellular genes.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Coevolution of viruses and host.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Retroviral enzymes such as reverse transcriptase convert RNA to DNA.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Rate of mutation is rapid in viruses.
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice D is correct because the rapid mutation rate is not evidence of viral origins, but rather a characteristic of some viruses.   Similarities between genome sequences in viral and cellular genes (Choice A), the coevolution of viruses and hosts (Choice B), and retroviral enzymes converting RNA to DNA (Choice C),  are all evidence of viral origins from other organisms.

title: Question 2
content:
The scientific name for the little spotted kiwi is Apteryx owenii. Which of the species below is most closely related to the little spotted kiwi?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9878cab2-bbf6-4ef3-affc-520f8a700b10/images/6faa3925-6492-47de-90a7-925e1e8a2859/BI1227.png)


[Source: Adapted from Lapsley Miller, J. (2023, August 28). Little Spotted Kiwi. Wikipedia. Retrieved September 13, 2023, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Little_spotted_kiwi.  Copyright under CC BY-SA 4.0]



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Apteryx australis
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Little spotted pardalote
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Owenii apteryx
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Neognathae owenii
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Species names are given using the binomial system, where the genus comes first, and the species follows. Species with the same genus have similar traits and are closely related;  Choice A  is correct.
Choice B  is incorrect as it is not a scientific name, so conveys no information about the relatedness of species. Choice C is incorrect as it is just a reversal of the scientific name of the little spotted kiwi, and is in a different genus. Choice D  is incorrect as it is not in the same genus as the little spotted kiwi.

title: Question 6
content:
Biologists use the binomial naming system to name every organism on the planet. The binomial name for the platypus is Ornithorhynchus anatinus. Which statement(s) below are true for the binomial naming system and the platypus?


- I. $\hspace{1em}$	The genus for the platypus is   Ornithorhynchus.
- II. $\hspace{.7em}$	The binomial naming system is based on an international agreement
between scientists.
- III. $\hspace{.4em}$ 	The name,   Ornithorhynchus anatinus is unique to platypus species.




- A. $\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B. $\hspace{1em}$	I and II only
- C. $\hspace{1em}$	II and III only
- D. $\hspace{1em}$	I, II and III
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
All three statements are correct. The first part of the binomial name is the genus, the second part is the species which is unique to platypus species. The binomial system and binomial names are agreed between biologists at international congresses.

title: Question 7
content:
Which of the following is the correct format for species names according to the binomial naming system?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Genus + Species
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Genus + species
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Genus + species
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Genus + Species
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice C is correct because only the genus name should be capitalised, it should come before the species name, and both should be in italics. Choices A and D are incorrect because only the genus name should be capitalised. Choice B is incorrect, as the genus and species name should be in italics.

title: Question 8
content:
Whole genome sequencing has been used to sequence the genomes of many species. Which of the following are potential future uses of whole genome sequencing?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Identifying disease-causing alleles.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Sequencing the genomes of bacteria and fungi.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Advancing personalised medicine.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Identifying evolutionary relationships between species.
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice C is correct because personalised medicine is a potential future application of whole genome sequencing. While it is not yet widely available, the continued study of individual genomes could lead to treatments tailored to an individual’s genetic profile, improving the effectiveness of medical interventions.
Choice A is incorrect because whole genome sequencing has already been used to identify disease-causing alleles which is improving understanding of genetic diseases.
Choice B is incorrect because whole genome sequencing is currently being used to sequence the genomes of disease-causing bacteria and viruses.
Choice D is incorrect because whole genome sequencing of a range of species is currently being used to identify evolutionary relationships and common ancestors; it is not a novel use.

title: Question 12
content:
The okapi looks like a small-sized giraffe and has stripes that resemble the zebra. It lives in the Ituri Forest in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Okapis eat the leaves and buds of trees they can reach. They also graze on grass and ferns and eat fruit. Okapis tend to be solitary animals and the mother gives birth to one offspring which continues to be dependent on the mother’s milk for six months. When they are four to five years old, they are mature and can breed, but only with other okapis.
Which of the following statements is applicable to the okapi?


- I.Okapi is a hybrid of a giraffe and a zebraII.Okapi is an herbivoreIII.Okapi is its own species




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Okapi is a herbivore (II) because it only eats plants. Okapi is a species (III) since it can interbreed and produce fertile offspring.
They are not a hybrid of a giraffe and a zebra (I), even though they look like one.

title: Question 13
content:
When constructing a dichotomous key for classifying bird species, which characteristic would be most appropriate for the first division in the key?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Colour of feathers
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Habitat (forest, grassland, urban)
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Presence or absence of webbed feet
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Diet (carnivorous, herbivorous, omnivorous)
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice C is correct because binary traits (presence/absence) work best for early divisions in a dichotomous key.
Choice A  is incorrect because colour is too variable within a species.
Choice B  is incorrect because habitat is a variable characteristic, so not suitable for classification.
Choice D is incorrect because diet varies within species and requires direct observation.

title: Question 15
content:
Which statement(s) below are challenges associated with the biological species concept (BSC)?


- I.The BSC assumes reproductive isolation, but some species are reproductively isolated only in certain environments.II.Fossil species cannot be assessed using the BSC due to the lack of observable mating behaviour.III.The BSC relies on morphological features, which can vary widely within a species.




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II, and III
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Statement I is true because reproductive isolation may be context-dependent (e.g. due to geography or behaviour), making it unclear whether two populations are separate species under BSC.
Statement II is true because the BSC depends on observing whether organisms can interbreed. This is impossible with fossils, which are studied based on morphology and location, not reproductive behaviour.
Statement III is false because the BSC specifically does not define species based on morphology; that is the morphological species concept. BSC focuses instead on reproductive capability, so this is not a valid criticism of BSC.
Choice B is correct because it includes only the two true Statements I and II.
Choice A is incorrect as it is missing the true Statement II.
Choices C and D are incorrect as they include the false Statement III.

title: Question 17
content:
How are the chromosomes in a karyogram ordered?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ By analogous pairs
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ By number of genes
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ By size
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ By position of the centromeres
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice C is correct because the chromosomes in a karyogram are ordered in homologous pairs from largest to smallest.
Choice A is incorrect because chromosomes are grouped in homologous pairs (one from each parent), not analogous pairs. Choice B is incorrect because the number of genes on each chromosome is highly variable, and genes do not have a consistent length. Although the chromosomes are aligned with their centromeres in a karyogram, the question only asks about the order of the chromosomes, which is not dependent on centromere position; thus, Choice D is also incorrect.

title: Question 19
content: - Outline the different uses of karyograms. [3] - Distinguish between cells with haploid and diploid nuclei. [4] - Compare and contrast different types of chromosomes. [8]
markScheme: - Any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ karyograms are images of the chromosomes in an organism [1] $\ce{ -> }$ homologous chromosomes are arranged in pairs of decreasing length OR Sex chromosomes are the 23rd pair in human karyograms [1] $\ce{ -> }$ karyograms can be used to identify the sex of an individual [1] $\ce{ -> }$ karyograms can be used to identify conditions caused by trisomy, e.g. Down syndrome OR Patau syndrome OR Klinefelter syndrome [1] $\ce{ -> }$ karyograms can be used to determine if a chromosome is missing OR if part of a chromosome is missing [1] [3 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: Karyograms ($\checkmark$) are images of the chromosomes in an organism. In a karyogram, the pairs of homologous chromosomes are arranged in pairs of decreasing length ($\checkmark$). The sex chromosomes are shown as the 23rd pair in human karyograms. Karyograms can be used to determine if an individual is a biological male or female ($\checkmark$). Two X chromosomes are present in a human female cell, and one X chromosome and one Y chromosome are present in a human male cell. Karyograms can be used to identify conditions caused by trisomy (three copies of a chromosome) e.g. Down syndrome, Patau syndrome, Edward’s syndrome and Klinefelter syndrome). - Any four of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ haploid nuclei have one set of chromosomes, OR one chromosome per type WHEREAS diploid nuclei have two sets OR two chromosomes of each type [1] $\ce{ -> }$ haploid nuclei have one allele for each gene WHEREAS diploid nuclei have two alleles for each gene [1] $\ce{ -> }$ haploid nuclei in humans have 23 chromosomes, and diploid nuclei in humans have 46 chromosomes OR any other valid species example [1] $\ce{ -> }$ haploid cells are usually gametes WHEREAS diploid cells are usually somatic cells [1] $\ce{ -> }$ haploid cells are usually the result of meiosis, WHILE diploid cells are usually the result of mitosis. [1] [4 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: Haploid nuclei have one set of chromosomes($\checkmark$), whereas diploid nuclei have two sets of chromosomes. For example, in humans($\checkmark$), gametes have 23 chromosomes, while somatic cells have 46 chromosomes. Haploid nuclei have one allele for each gene, ($\checkmark$) whereas diploid nuclei have two alleles for each gene. In humans, only gametes($\checkmark$) have haploid nuclei, whereas the rest of the somatic cells have diploid nuclei. - Any eight of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ (within one species) different chromosomes are composed of DNA molecules with different lengths [1] $\ce{ -> }$ (within one species) different chromosomes have different numbers of genes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ (within one species) different chromosomes have different types OR different numbers of genes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ both prokaryotic AND eukaryotic chromosomes contain DNA [1] $\ce{ -> }$ bacterial chromosomes are not associated with proteins, WHILE eukaryotic and archaeal chromosomes are associated with proteins [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic chromosomes are looped molecules of DNA, WHILE eukaryotic chromosomes are linear molecules of DNA [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH autosomes and sex chromosomes contain genes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the human Y chromosome carries information mainly coding for male sex determination and development, WHILE the X chromosome carries information for other body characteristics [1] $\ce{ -> }$ there is only one pair of sex chromosomes, WHILE there can be more than one pair of autosomes (in different species) [1] $\ce{ -> }$ autosomes are pairs of homologous chromosomes of equal length, WHILE two sex chromosomes can be different lengths [1] $\ce{ -> }$ chromosomes can be homologous and non-homologous [1] $\ce{ -> }$ homologous chromosomes are pairs of chromosomes of equal length carrying the same genes, but different alleles, WHILE non-homologous chromosomes, carry different genes [1] [8 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: All chromosomes are made of DNA and contain genes, but they differ in length ($\checkmark$) and in the number of genes ($\checkmark$) and type of genes ($\checkmark$). Similarities and differences between prokaryotic and eukaryotic chromosomes: Both prokaryotic and eukaryotic chromosomes contain DNA ($\checkmark$). Bacterial chromosomes are not associated with proteins, but eukaryotic chromosomes are associated with proteins ($\checkmark$). Prokaryotic chromosomes are looped, while eukaryotic chromosomes are linear ($\checkmark$). Similarities and differences between autosomes and sex chromosomes: Both autosomes and sex chromosomes are made of DNA and contain genes. Autosomes are chromosomes that do not determine sex and do not have genes for sex-linked characteristics; sex chromosomes determine sex and have genes for sex-linked traits. There is one pair of sex chromosomes in a somatic nucleus, but there can be more than one pair of autosomes ($\checkmark$) in a somatic nucleus. X and Y chromosomes are of different lengths, while autosomal homologous chromosome pairs are equal in length ($\checkmark$) Comparing non-homologous chromosomes and homologous chromosomes: Homologous chromosomes are pairs of chromosomes that have genes for the same characteristics and can have the same or different alleles. Non-homologous chromosomes have genes for different characteristics ($\checkmark$). A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information. [1]

title: Question 21
content:
The image on the left shows a cross-section of a symmetrical flower. The image on the right shows the same flower but looking upwards from below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/09109e4f-739a-4be6-9f76-8c9ae9a8da25/images/4efabe18-9f85-4bba-878c-f0ed970e5145/BI2660.png)


[© Revision Village 2025. Created with BioRender.com]

Use the following key to identify the plant which this flower is from:
1.Animal pollinated ….Go to 2Wind pollinated ….Plant P2.Flower with 10 stamens ….Plant QFlower with more than 10 stamens ….Go to 33.Ovary as tall as wide….Plant ROvary taller than wide….Go to 44.Flower has more sepals than petals ….Plant SFlower has fewer sepals than petals….Plant T

Which plant does the flower belong to?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Plant P
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Plant Q
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Plant T
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Plant R
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice C is correct. The plant is animal-pollinated (the flower has large petals and internal reproductive structures (stigma and anthers), indicating animal pollination). It also has more than 10 stamens and an ovary that is taller than it is wide. This takes us to step 4. From the diagram on the right, we can see that the flower has fewer sepals than petals which means it must be plant T.
Choice A is incorrect because the flower in the diagram is animal-pollinated as it has anthers and a stigma held inside the large, colourful petals.
Step 2: The image only shows half the flower, which has 11 stamens visible. This means the full flower has more than eleven stamens; Choice B is, therefore, incorrect.
Choice D is incorrect because, in step 3, the ovary is taller than it is wide, so it can't be flower R.

title: Question 22
content:
Which of the following statements explain why classifying diverging populations as species can be arbitrary?


- I.Traits may diverge at different rates in different populationsII.Some populations may remain reproductively compatible despite divergenceIII.Morphological changes always occur before genetic differences appear




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II, and III
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Statement I is true because, during speciation, some traits (e.g., behaviour, physiology, morphology) can evolve faster than others. This means two populations might look different but still interbreed, or might appear similar but already be reproductively isolated. Because divergence doesn’t follow a fixed pattern, deciding when to define them as separate species becomes subjective.
Statement II is true because Populations might develop noticeable differences in traits (such as colouration or mating calls), but still produce fertile offspring when they interbreed. According to the biological species concept, they’re technically the same species, but these differences can confuse classification.
Statement III is false because often, the opposite is true. Genetic differences (mutations, allele frequency changes) may accumulate before any visible morphological change occurs. For example, two populations may look identical but carry distinct genetic markers and be reproductively isolated.
Saying morphological change “always” comes first is incorrect and overly simplistic.
Choice A is correct because it includes only the two true Statements I and II.
Choices B, C and D are incorrect as they include the false Statement III.

title: Question 23
content:
The images below represent haploid or diploid cells from different individuals. Based on their cells, which pairs could produce fertile offspring if they interbreed?


- I.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0e07ee1d-2174-4c9f-b030-faa106d5f85b/images/9a2f92c1-ef3b-4ebf-ae97-0592003e8699/BI1029A.png)

II.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0e07ee1d-2174-4c9f-b030-faa106d5f85b/images/e6accf1d-0d53-45da-813b-cf941471c871/BI1029B.png)

III.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0e07ee1d-2174-4c9f-b030-faa106d5f85b/images/6e522064-62f3-4ff3-822f-a33138000796/BI1029C.png)






- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice C is correct because only pairs II and III could produce fertile offspring. This is because pair II shares the same haploid number, and pair III share the same diploid number. Choices A, B and D are incorrect because they include pair I. Pair I is not likely to produce fertile offspring as the haploid number of one individual is NOT half the diploid number of the other individual, which means they have different numbers of chromosomes.

title: Question 31
content:
Why is the cytochrome oxidase I gene the region most commonly used for DNA barcoding in animal species?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Because this gene is highly conserved, resulting in nearly identical sequences across all animal species.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Because this gene is sufficiently different between species while remaining relatively constant within a species.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Because this gene is found exclusively in animals and not in any other organisms.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Because this gene is part of the nuclear DNA and evolves rapidly, ensuring distinct differences even among closely related species.
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice B is correct.  The cytochrome oxidase I gene has the ideal balance of variability. Its sequence differs enough between species to allow clear differentiation, yet it remains consistent within individuals of the same species. This makes it highly effective for DNA barcoding.
Choice A is incorrect: If the cytochrome oxidase I gene were too highly conserved (i.e., nearly identical across species), it wouldn’t provide enough variation to distinguish one species from another.
Choice C is incorrect. The cytochrome oxidase I gene is not exclusive to animals; it is found in the mitochondria of many eukaryotes. Its utility for animal barcoding comes from its pattern of variability, not its exclusivity.
Choice D is incorrect. The cytochrome oxidase I gene is mitochondrial, not nuclear, and its evolutionary rate is moderate rather than extremely rapid. A gene that evolves too quickly might accumulate too many mutations, complicating species-level identification.

title: Question 32
content: - Outline the role of the active site in an enzyme. [3] - Outline how members of the same species can become separate populations via speciation. [4] - Describe the regulation and use of hormones during in vitro fertilisation (IVF). [8]
markScheme: - any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ it is the binding site for a substrate OR specific region where the substrate binds [1] $\ce{ -> }$ it allows for induced fit binding of the substrate [1] $\ce{ -> }$ it facilitates enzyme-substrate specificity OR has a specific shape that allows the substrate to bind effectively [1] $\ce{ -> }$ it causes a conformational change in the enzyme-substrate complex, which leads to the formation of products [1] $\ce{ -> }$ it is the site where a substrate is converted into a product OR where a substrate is held while a chemical reaction takes place [1] $\ce{ -> }$ it lowers the energy of the transition state OR activation energy so that a chemical reaction can take place more efficiently [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The active site of an enzyme is a specific region where a substrate binds ($\checkmark$). Within the active site, the enzyme lowers the energy of the transition state ($\checkmark$), facilitating the chemical reaction so that the substrate can be successfully converted into a product ($\checkmark$). - any four of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ a population consists of all organisms of one species living in the same place at the same time, capable of breeding together [1] $\ce{ -> }$ members of the species can become geographically isolated OR separated by a physical barrier such as a river OR mountain [1] $\ce{ -> }$ members of the species can become temporally isolated OR become separated by producing gametes at different times OR seasons [1] $\ce{ -> }$ members of the species can become behaviourally isolated OR become separated by displaying distinctive courtship behaviours [1] $\ce{ -> }$ when populations of the same species become separated, genetic drift will cause the allele frequencies to change [1] $\ce{ -> }$ reproductive isolation mechanisms, such as incompatibility of reproductive organs, can prevent interbreeding between separated populations [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mutations can introduce new genetic variations in each isolated population, contributing to genetic divergence over time [1] $\ce{ -> }$ selective pressures will act on the separated species, leading to an accumulation of genetic differences in each population OR natural selection will act on each population so that traits that are beneficial to each group will accumulate [1] $\ce{ -> }$ over many generations, speciation will occur OR the separate populations will not be able to breed to produce fertile offspring [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Members of the same species can become separate populations if they become geographically isolated($\checkmark$) or behaviourally isolated ($\checkmark$). Once populations of the same species are separated, genetic drift will cause the allele frequencies to change ($\checkmark$). Selective pressures will act on the separated populations, leading to an accumulation of genetic differences ($\checkmark$). Eventually, speciation($\checkmark$) will occur, resulting in populations that can no longer interbreed to produce fertile offspring. - any eight of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ drugs are used to downregulate several hormones OR FSH OR follicle stimulating hormone AND LH OR luteinising hormone, to better control the release OR maturation of follicles later on [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the function of FSH OR follicle-stimulating hormone is to promote follicle growth OR mature eggs [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the function of LH OR luteinising hormone is to trigger ovulation OR trigger the release of mature eggs from the ovaries [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the downregulation of LH and FSH also results in the downregulation of oestrogen and progesterone [1] $\ce{ -> }$ oestrogen normally stimulates the uterine OR endometrial lining to build up [1] $\ce{ -> }$ progesterone normally stimulates the maintenance of the uterine OR endometrial lining for implantation [1] $\ce{ -> }$ high doses of FSH are injected to stimulate superovulation OR the development of many follicles [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the development of many follicles increases the chances of successful fertilisation during the IVF process [1] $\ce{ -> }$ gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists are injected to prevent premature ovulation OR control the timing of ovulation [1] $\ce{ -> }$ human chorionic gonadotropin OR hCG is injected to stimulate the follicles to mature [1] $\ce{ -> }$ progesterone is injected before the fertilised egg is implanted to improve the chances of successful implantation [1] [8 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: In vitro fertilisation (IVF) is a process used by couples with fertility issues, where mature eggs are fertilised outside the body. To start the process, drugs are used to downregulate several reproductive hormones to better control the release and maturation of follicles later on ($\checkmark$). The downregulation of FSH stops follicles from growing ($\checkmark$). Drugs are also used to downregulate LH, which results in the prevention of ovulation ($\checkmark$). The downregulation of LH and FSH also results in the downregulation of oestrogen and progesterone ($\checkmark$), which normally function to stimulate the build-up of the uterine lining($\checkmark$) and maintain the uterine lining ($\checkmark$), respectively. Once these hormones are successfully downregulated, high doses of FSH are injected to trigger the development of multiple follicles in the ovary($\checkmark$). The development of many follicles increases the chance of successful fertilisation during the IVF process ($\checkmark$). GnRH agonists are injected to prevent premature ovulation ($\checkmark$), and hCG is injected to stimulate the follicles to mature ($\checkmark$). A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.

title: Question 34
content:
Marbled crayfish, Procambarus virginalis (shown below) only reproduce through parthenogenesis, a type of asexual reproduction.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ba0e6004-4d7f-48a7-bf9e-a8069777b737/images/c8f8303c-ea98-4db3-beb6-4205e32b355a/BI2655.png)


[Adapted from Lyko, F. (2017). The marbled crayfish (Decapoda: Cambaridae) represents an independent new species. Zootaxa 4363(4): 544–552. Retrieved 10/03/2025, DOI: 10.11646/zootaxa.4363.4.6. CC PY]

Which of the following statements about classifying these crayfish is/are correct?


- I.They produce genetically identical offspring, making species classification impossibleII.They cannot be classified using the biological species conceptIII.They can produce many offspring so cannot be classified using the biological species concept




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ II only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II, and III
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Statement I is false. Although marbled crayfish produce genetically identical offspring, this does not make classification impossible; it just means the biological species concept (which relies on interbreeding) isn’t applicable. Other species concepts can be used.
Statement II is true. The biological species concept defines species based on their ability to interbreed and produce fertile offspring, with reproductive isolation preventing gene flow between different species. However, it does not apply to organisms that reproduce exclusively asexually.
Statement III is false. The number of offspring does not affect the applicability of the biological species concept. The issue is the absence of sexual reproduction, not the offspring count.
Choice A is correct because it contains only the true statement and none of the false ones.
Choice B is incorrect because it contains the false Statement III.
Choice C is incorrect because it contains the false Statement I.
Choice D is incorrect because it contains the false Statements I and III.

title: Question 35
content:
Why does chromosome number affect hybrid fertility?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Species with different chromosome numbers can always produce fertile offspring because meiosis is not affected by chromosome pairing.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Hybrids with mismatched chromosome numbers have increased genetic diversity, making them more fertile.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Chromosome number only affects physical traits, not reproductive ability.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Hybrids with different chromosome numbers cannot produce functional gametes because homologous chromosomes fail to pair during meiosis.
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice D is correct because meiosis requires homologous chromosomes to pair correctly. If the chromosome numbers do not match, pairing cannot occur properly, leading to errors in gamete formation and often resulting in sterility.
Choice A is incorrect because mismatched chromosomes disrupt meiosis, preventing successful gamete production and leading to sterility in many hybrids.
Choice B is incorrect because increased genetic diversity does not necessarily lead to higher fertility—chromosome mismatches usually cause sterility rather than increased reproductive success.
Choice C is incorrect because chromosome number directly affects meiosis and fertility.

title: Question 36
content:
Which of the following could be used to identify different species?


- I.Dichotomous keyII.KaryogramsIII.Binomial naming system




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ III only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice B is correct because only Statements I and II are correct. Dichotomous keys could be used to identify two different species based on their characteristics, and karyograms could be used to identify two different species based on their chromosome number and size. Choices A, C, and D are incorrect because they contain Statement III, which is incorrect. The Binomial naming system can be used to give species a name but does not identify species.

title: Question 38
content: The karyogram is from a rat (Rattus rattus) cell without any chromosomal abnormalities. Biological sex is determined in the same way in rats and humans. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b5a7f5e3-5dd7-4aea-8b10-a1b8e986feb8/images/4ec8e247-e777-434d-bc1c-587a943d54bc/BI1652.png) [Source: Adapted from Hamanaka, S., Yamaguchi, T., Kobayashi, T., Kato-Itoh, M., Yamazaki, S., Sato, H., Umino, A., Wakiyama, Y., Arai, M., Sanbo, M., Hirabayashi, M., & Nakauchi, H. (2011, July 15). File: Karyogram of normal rat.png. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved June 11, 2024 from URL https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Karyogram_of_normal_rat.png. Copyright under CC BY 4.0] - State at which stage of mitosis the chromosomes are photographed to make a karyogram. [1] - Deduce, with a reason, the biological sex of the rat. [1] - State how the chromosomes have been arranged to create the karyogram. [2] - Using the karyogram, compare and contrast between the chromosomes of rats and humans. [2]
markScheme: - $\ce{ -> }$ metaphase BECAUSE the chromosomes are visible OR condensed OR aligned on the equator of the cell so that it is easier to sort them [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The chromosomes are in metaphase because the chromosomes are visible and aligned on the equator of the cell, which makes it easier to sort them ($\checkmark$). - $\ce{ -> }$ male BECAUSE it has a Y chromosome OR has both X and Y chromosomes [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The rat is male because it has a Y chromosome ($\checkmark$). - any two of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ by decreasing length [1] $\ce{ -> }$ using banding patterns OR centromere positions [1] $\ce{ -> }$ in pairs OR homologous pairs OR one chromosome from each parent forms a pair [1] [2 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The chromosomes have been arranged by decreasing length ($\checkmark$) and using their banding patterns ($\checkmark$). - any two of the following: Answer must include at least one similarity and at least one difference to gain full marks Similarities $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH have pairs of chromosomes OR homologous chromosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH have specific banding patterns OR genes on the chromosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH have a pair of sex chromosomes OR X and Y chromosomes [1] Differences $\ce{ -> }$ rats have fewer chromosomes OR autosomes than humans OR humans have more chromosomes OR autosomes than rats OR rats have 21 pairs of chromosomes AND humans have 23 pairs of chromosomes OR rats have 42 chromosomes AND humans have 46 chromosomes OR rats have 40 autosomes and 2 sex chromosomes AND humans have 44 autosomes and 2 sex chromosomes OR rats have 20 pairs of autosomes and 1 pair of sex chromosomes AND humans have 22 pairs of autosomes and 1 pair of sex chromosomes [1] [2 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Both rats and humans have homologous chromosomes ($\checkmark$), however, rats have fewer chromosomes (42) than humans (46) ($\checkmark$).

title: Question 40
content:
Which of the following highlight(s) difficulties in applying the biological species concept?


- I.Budding in yeastII.Runners in spider plantsIII.Bacterial conjugation




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ III only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice D is correct because all statements are examples of either asexual reproduction (Statements I and II) or horizontal gene transfer (Statement III), which makes applying the biological species concept difficult. The biological species concept defines a species as a group of organisms that can interbreed and produce fertile offspring under natural conditions. This concept is formulated for sexual reproduction, not asexual or horizontal genetic transfer.

title: Question 42
content:
The following table shows the approximate number of protein-encoding genes found in various species. What can be concluded from these findings?
SpeciesApproximate number of protein-encoding genesDrosophila melanogaster (fruit fly)14,000Oryza sativa (rice)51,000Gallus gallus (chicken)20,000-23,000Homo sapiens (human)20,000-25,000


- I.The number of genes is not a good indicator of organism complexity.II.Chickens may have more genes than humans.III.The number of base pairs in the rice genome is greater than in the other species.




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The number of genes found in a species does not serve as a good indicator of complexity (Statement I). If it did, the data here would suggest that chickens and humans are equally complex, and that rice is far more complex than either of them. Due to the overlapping ranges in the number of genes, it is entirely possible for chickens to have a greater number of genes than humans (Statement II). It is impossible to determine the size of the genome (measured in base pairs) of a species based on the number of genes it has. In reality, rice has far fewer base pairs than chickens or humans despite having approximately twice as many genes (Statement III). Choice A is, therefore, correct.
Choices B, C, and D are incorrect as they all contain Statement III.

title: Question 43
content: - Outline the binomial naming system and its importance. [4] - Explain how a sample of cells taken from a foetus can be used to determine whether the foetus will be biologically male or biologically female at birth. [4] - Outline the outcomes of the human genome project and their impacts on different fields of science. [7]
markScheme: - Any four of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ binomial naming system as the system used to name species [1] $\ce{ -> }$ genus name and species name [1] $\ce{ -> }$ species with the same genus share many characteristics OR are closely related [1] $\ce{ -> }$ internationally agreed [1] $\ce{ -> }$ facilitates understanding and communication between scientists [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The binomial naming system is the system which scientists use to name species ($\checkmark$) and this is internationally agreed ($\checkmark$), which means it’s used all over the world, which aids in the communication between scientists ($\checkmark$) in different countries. The name of each species has two parts, the first highlights the genus to which it belongs and the second part refers to the species ($\checkmark$). - Any four of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ cells grown in a culture medium [1] $\ce{ -> }$ cells stained [1] $\ce{ -> }$ observed under a light microscope [1] $\ce{ -> }$ photomicrograph taken during mitosis OR mitotic metaphase [1] $\ce{ -> }$ chromosomes arranged according to size OR position of centromeres [1] $\ce{ -> }$ look at chromosome pair 23 [1] $\ce{ -> }$ two large chromosomes mean foetus is XX [1] $\ce{ -> }$ one large chromosome and one small chromosome means foetus is XY [1] $\ce{ -> }$ XX is biologically female AND XY is biologically male [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Once the sample of cells has been taken from the foetus they are grown in a culture medium ($\checkmark$). They are then stained ($\checkmark$) and observed under a light microscope ($\checkmark$). A photomicrograph is taken ($\checkmark$), and the image is cut up so that the chromosomes can be arranged by size and position of the centromere ($\checkmark$). A foetus with two large X chromosomes will be biologically female ($\checkmark$), and a foetus with one large X and one small Y chromosome will be biologically male ($\checkmark$). - Any seven of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ the Human Genome Project (HGP) sequenced the entire human genome [1] $\ce{ -> }$ it determined the total number of base pairs in the human genome [1] $\ce{ -> }$ it estimated the number of genes in the human genome [1] $\ce{ -> }$ identified the loci of genes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ identified repeat sequences [1] $\ce{ -> }$ identified locations of single nucleotide polymorphisms [1] $\ce{ -> }$ identified gene sequences associated with certain diseases OR biological processes OR traits [1] $\ce{ -> }$ HGP stimulated further development OR reduced the price of sequencing technology [1] $\ce{ -> }$ technology developed for the HGP is now used to diagnose diseases OR identify micro-organisms OR DNA matching in forensics and medicine OR genetic modification [1] $\ce{ -> }$ contributed to the field by identifying genetic markers that affect how individuals metabolise and respond to medications OR contribute information for personalised medicine [1] $\ce{ -> }$ insights into evolutionary relationships OR genetic similarities OR genetic differences [1] $\ce{ -> }$ identification of regulatory elements OR non-coding RNAs OR components that play essential roles in gene expression OR cellular function [1] $\ce{ -> }$ emphasised importance of consideration of ethical OR legal OR social implications of genomic research [1] [7 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The Human Genome Project (HGP) sequenced the entire human genome ($\checkmark$), identified the loci of genes ($\checkmark$) and identified gene sequences that are connected to some diseases ($\checkmark$) such as breast cancer. Locations of single nucleotide polymorphisms ($\checkmark$) were discovered which are variations in individuals DNA base pairs.
