The results have contributed to the development of personalised medicine ($\checkmark$) as genetic markers have been identified that affect how individuals respond to medications. The technology developed for the HGP has led to further advancements in technology, reducing the cost of genetic sequencing ($\checkmark$). The HGP also emphasised how important it is to consider the ethical implications ($\checkmark$) of genomic research and the importance of informed consent. A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information. [1]

title: Question 46
content: The karyogram shows a karyotype of a healthy human foetus. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/abc08017-69b8-4823-982a-12bb8e00c243/images/e3d89299-8c59-4872-a8af-84cb0cbaf394/BI1630%20fig1.png) [Source: Adapted from National Cancer Institute (2013, January 21). File: Karyotype (normal). jpg. Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved April 28, 2024. https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Karyotype_(normal).jpg. Copyright free] - Deduce, with a reason, the biological sex of the foetus. [1] - The biological father of the foetus has haemophilia, and the biological mother is a carrier of the disease. Using a Punnett square, calculate the probability that the foetus has haemophilia. [3] - Haemophilia occurs in approximately 1 in 6000 biological males and 1 in 100,000 biological females. Suggest a reason for this difference. [1] - Much research has been conducted into the use of stem cells to treat genetic diseases. Outline the advantages and disadvantages of the use of adult stem cells over embryonic ones in stem cell therapy. [3]
markScheme: - any one of the following $\ce{ -> }$ biologically male BECAUSE they have a Y chromosome OR they have 22 pairs of homologous chromosomes AND 1 pair of non-homologous sex chromosomes [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The foetus is biologically male because they have a Y chromosome ($\checkmark$). - any three of the following $\ce{ -> }$ parental genotypes identified in the Punnett square; biological father: $\ce{X^hY}$ AND biological mother: $\ce{X^HX^h}$ [1] $\ce{ -> }$ offspring genotypes identified as $\ce{X^HY, X^hY}$ [1] $\ce{ -> }$ 0.50 OR 50% OR $\frac{1}{2}$ [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/abc08017-69b8-4823-982a-12bb8e00c243/images/23e5eaf5-4187-4a5f-b4d9-7b165e6ae1be/1630.png) The biological sex of the foetus is male, so it must inherit the Y chromosome from its biological father. The probability of a biologically male foetus having haemophilia is 50 % ($\checkmark$). - any one of the following $\ce{ -> }$ it is a sex-linked recessive disease, OR the gene is carried on the X chromosome AND biological males only have one X chromosome, so if they have the recessive allele, they will have the disease, whereas biological females with one copy would be carriers [1] $\ce{ -> }$ for a biological female to have haemophilia, they would need to have two copies of the recessive allele, whereas biological males only need one copy of the recessive allele to have haemophilia [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Haemophilia is more common in biological males because it is a sex-linked disease on the X chromosome. Biological males have only one X chromosome, so inheriting the recessive allele results in the disease, while biological females with two X chromosomes can be carriers without symptoms ($\checkmark$). - any three of the following (at least one advantage and one disadvantage must be given to gain full marks) advantages: $\ce{ -> }$ adult stem cells can be obtained from the individual needing treatment, reducing the risk of immune rejection WHILE embryonic stem cells may be rejected by the patient’s immune system [1] $\ce{ -> }$ harvesting adult stem cells is generally less controversial OR has fewer ethical implications compared to embryonic stem cells [1] $\ce{ -> }$ adult stem cells have a lower risk of producing tumours compared to embryonic stem cells [1] $\ce{ -> }$ adult stem cell therapies generally face fewer regulatory hurdles and greater public acceptance compared to therapies involving embryonic stem cells [1] disadvantages: $\ce{ -> }$ adult stem cells are multipotent OR are often restricted in the number of cell types they can produce WHILE embryonic stem cells are pluripotent OR can differentiate into any bpdy cell type [1] $\ce{ -> }$ adult stem cells are limited in number within adult tissues OR can be challenging to obtain OR culture WHILE embryonic stem cells are more numerous OR easier to harvest [1] $\ce{ -> }$ adult stem cells have less potential for long-term proliferation OR durability in culture COMPARED TO embryonic stem cells [1] $\ce{ -> }$ adult stem cells are derived from fully developed tissues so typically more differentiated, WHEREAS embryonic stem cells are derived from a very early developmental stage so less differentiated [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: One advantage of using adult stem cells in therapy is that they can be obtained from the patient, reducing the risk of immune rejection ($\checkmark$). Additionally, harvesting adult stem cells is less controversial and has fewer ethical implications ($\checkmark$) compared to embryonic stem cells. However, adult stem cells are multipotent and limited in the types of cells($\checkmark$) they can produce, unlike pluripotent embryonic stem cells. Moreover, adult stem cells are less numerous and harder to harvest ($\checkmark$) than embryonic stem cells.
