title: Question 3
content:
What evidence can be, and has been used, to determine the members of the same clade?


- I.	$\hspace{1em}$ Base sequence of genes
- II.	$\hspace{.7em}$ Amino acid sequence of proteins
- III.	$\hspace{.4em}$ Physical appearance of organisms




- A.	$\hspace{1em}$ II only
- B.	$\hspace{1em}$ I and II
- C.	$\hspace{1em}$ II and III
- D.	$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice D is correct.
The DNA sequence (Statement I) and amino acid sequence (Statement II) are the usual, present way of determining members of the same clade, however, physical appearance (Statement III) was previously, but is now rarely, used.

title: Question 7
content:
Which technique estimates the divergence time between species based on genetic differences?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Radioactive dating
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Molecular clock dating
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Comparative anatomy
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Studying fossil layers
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Molecular clock dating uses the genetic differences between species to estimate their times of divergence. This method relies on the assumption that mutations accumulate at a relatively constant rate over time. By comparing the DNA sequences of different organisms, scientists can estimate how long ago their last common ancestor lived. Choice B is, therefore, correct.
Radioactive dating is a method used to date rocks and other materials based on the known decay rates of radioactive isotopes. Choice A is, therefore, not correct.
Comparative anatomy involves comparing the structures of different organisms to understand their evolutionary relationships. While it can provide evidence of common ancestry and evolutionary trends, it does not offer a precise method for estimating the time of divergence between species based on genetic differences. Choice C is, therefore, not correct.
Studying the distribution of fossils within sedimentary rock layers establishes relative ages and the chronological order of geological and evolutionary events. Whilst it is essential for constructing the timeline of life on Earth, it does not use genetic differences to estimate divergence times between species. Choice D is, therefore, not correct.

title: Question 9
content:
Which of the following represents the correct order for the traditional taxonomic hierarchy?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Class $\rightarrow$ Order	$\rightarrow$ Family
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ Phylum $\rightarrow$ Order $\rightarrow$ Class
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ Order $\rightarrow$ Genus	$\rightarrow$ Family
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ Kingdom	$\rightarrow$ Order	$\rightarrow$ Phylum
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice A is correct because the traditional hierarchy of taxa is a domain, kingdom, phylum, class, order, family, genus, so class $\rightarrow$ order $\rightarrow$ family is in the correct order. Choice B is incorrect because the class is above order. Choice C is incorrect because the family is above genus. Choice D is incorrect because the phylum is above order.

title: Question 10
content:
In a cladogram, what is represented by a node?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ A new trait that is shared by two organisms
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ The most recent common ancestor between species
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ A group of organisms with a common ancestor
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ The most genetically distant organisms
markScheme:
B
$\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: 
Nodes on a cladogram are a splitting point that represent the most recent ancestor between species; Choice B is correct.
A node does not represent a new trait shared by two organisms; Choice A is incorrect. A group of organisms with a common ancestor is a clade, not a node; Choice C  is incorrect. The most genetically distant organism on a cladogram is an outgroup, not a node; Choice D  is incorrect.

title: Question 12
content:
According to the cladogram, which two primates are the most closely related?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/008ac188-a233-4bb5-b8bb-1f6a59da105e/images/1afb59aa-b10a-4467-b0d5-c7f223838826/BI0263.png)


[Adapted from: Source Bockman, P. (2011, October 3). File: Primate cladogram.jpg. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved June 14, 2022, from https:// commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Primate_cladogram.jpg CC-BY-SA-3.0]



- A.	$\hspace{1em}$ New world monkeys and old world monkeys
- B.	$\hspace{1em}$ Lorises and lemurs
- C.	$\hspace{1em}$ Lemurs and humans
- D.	$\hspace{1em}$ Apes and humans
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Humans and apes (Choice D) are the most closely related because they shared a common ancestor more recently than the other primates, such as new world and old world monkeys (Choice A), Lorises and Lemurs (Choice B) and Lemurs and Humans (Choice C).

title: Question 17
content:
The image shows the skulls of a gorilla, chimpanzee, and human. What conclusion can be drawn from the anatomies of the skulls?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dae42746-c318-47a8-bb28-40949593158e/images/1dc8d91c-26ff-4b43-954b-8b30cb9b0c03/BI1522%20fig1.png)


[Source: Adapted from Zhang, K. (2015, May 1). Wikimedia Commons. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved February 29, 2024.https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: The_Skulls_of_the_gorilla,chimpanzee_and_humans_-_Kaiwei_Zhang.jpg. Copyright free]



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Gorillas and chimpanzees are more closely related to each other than they are to humans
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ Humans are more intelligent than chimpanzees and gorillas
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ Gorillas, chimpanzees and humans share a recent common ancestor
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ Chimpanzees and gorillas have a diploid chromosome number of 48, whereas humans have a diploid chromosome number of 46
markScheme:
C
$\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: 
The similar anatomies of the gorilla, chimpanzee and human skull suggest they have a common ancestor; Choice C  is correct.
Choice A  is incorrect, as similar anatomy is not enough to say that gorillas and chimpanzees are more closely related to each other than humans due to convergent evolution. Choice B is incorrect, as skull size is not necessarily correlated to intelligence. Choice D  is incorrect as skull size and shape do not provide any information on chromosome number.

title: Question 20
content:
The table shows the number of differences in amino acid sequences for the Insulin-A protein, between pigs and other organisms.
$\hspace{3em}$ Organism $\hspace{3em}$Number of differences in amino acid sequence for Insulin-AHuman2Cow5Giraffe50Goat4Warthog1Chimpanzee10Flamingo25

Which organism would be furthest from pigs in a cladogram?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Warthogs because they have the least number of differences
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ Giraffes because they have the largest number of differences
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ Humans because they are most different physically
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ Flamingoes because they have a different number of limbs
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Organisms with the largest differences in the amino acid sequence are the most evolutionarily diverged, so would be the furthest apart. Choice B is correct. Choice A is incorrect as warthogs and pigs have the least number of differences so would be the closest organisms on a cladogram. Choices C and D are incorrect because cladograms are not based on physical appearance.

title: Question 21
content:
The cyanobacteria Leptolyngbya nigrescens  has recently been reclassified as Phormidesmis nigrescens. What is a  possible reason for this?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Observation of similar sensitivities to light between bacteria in the Phormidesmis genus and the newly classified Phormidesmis nigrescens
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Discovery of structural similarities of cyanobacteria to other bacteria in the Leptolyngbya genus
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Discovery of similarities in ribosomal RNA sequences between Phormidesmis nigrescens and other bacteria in the Phormidesmis genus
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ New evidence that Phormidesmis nigrescens  share a common ancestor with other cyanobacteria in the Leptolyngbya genus
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Similarities between ribosomal RNA sequences between Phormidesmis nigrescens  and other bacteria in the Phormidesmis genus indicates that they are likely to share a common ancestor, belong in the same genus and therefore should be reclassified. Choice C is correct.
Similarities in behaviour do not indicate that Phormidesmis nigrescens  share a common ancestor with other bacteria in the Phormidesmis genus; Choice A  is incorrect. To be reclassified, the Phormidesmis nigrescens should be more similar to bacteria in the Phormidesmis genus than the Leptolyngbya genus, also structural similarities are not grounds for reclassification; Choice B is incorrect. To be reclassified, the Phormidesmis nigrescens should share a common ancestor with cyanobacteria in the Phormidesmis genus rather than the Leptolyngbya genus; Choice D  is incorrect.

title: Question 23
content:
The following image shows a member of the Scrophulariaceae (figwort) family drawn in 1774. Although this family was once among the largest groups of flowering plants, it has since been reclassified and is now less than half of its former size. Which of the following explains why reclassification of taxonomic groups may be required?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7c908cc5-d161-4aae-aebd-4022e07a9452/images/faca6029-51b6-4e7b-9dc9-1f94775fc7d7/BI1390.png)


[Source: Bouchard, M. (1774). Figwort (Scrophularia sp): flowering stem with separate flower. Look and Learn. Retrieved December 30, 2023, from https://www.lookandlearn.com/history-images/YW042762VEL/Figwort-Scrophularia-sp-flowering-stem-with-separate-flower. Copyright BY CC 4.0]



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Genomic sequencing
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Improvements in dichotomous keys
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Genetically modified species
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Discovery of new species
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
When the taxonomic system was developed, species were largely classified according to physical similarities. With the discovery of DNA and gene sequencing techniques, it became possible to compare the genomes of organisms. Genomic data allows the evolutionary relationships between organisms to be determined much more accurately and thus can lead to the reclassification of some taxa. Choice A is correct.
Choice B is incorrect because dichotomous keys are used to identify organisms based on observable characteristics, not for reclassifying taxonomic groups. Choice C is incorrect because genetic modification is when the genetic material of an organism has been altered through human intervention, however, this does not lead to the reclassification of species. Choice D is incorrect since the discovery of a new species should not affect previously classified organisms, especially if genome sequencing is used as the primary means of classification.

title: Question 31
content: The diagrams below show two cladograms for primates. One cladogram was made using data from DNA sequences and the other using amino acid sequences. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d834264a-48ae-474c-af53-c7ed003a94e8/images/d839b234-e401-4a51-ae04-32fd9b023985/BI0272.png) [Source: Adapted from Bockman, P. (2011, October 3). File: Primate cladogram.jpg. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved June 14, 2022, from https: //commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Primate_cladogram.jpg CC-BY-SA-3.0] - Identify the organism(s) most closely related to humans in the cladogram based on… - DNA sequences [1] - amino acid sequences [1] - Describe the advantage of using DNA sequences to construct cladograms compared to amino acid sequences. [2] - Suggest why cladograms made using physical features are not reliable predictors of phylogenetic relationships. [2]
markScheme: - - $\ce{ -> }$ apes [1] [1 mark maximum] - $\ce{ -> }$ old world monkeys AND new world monkeys [1] [1 mark maximum] - Any two of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ the nucleotide sequence of a gene contains more information than the amino acid sequence of the corresponding polypeptides [1] $\ce{ -> }$ silent mutations alter the DNA sequence but do not affect the amino acid sequence [1] $\ce{ -> }$ degeneracy in the genetic code means a mutation does not necessarily change the amino acid sequence [1] $\ce{ -> }$ greater information can be obtained by DNA sequence analysis because variability in both the coding and non-coding regions of the genome can be examined [1] $\ce{ -> }$ DNA samples can be easily sequenced OR DNA is cheaper to sequence OR DNA sequencing yields more data whereas the approach to sequencing of proteins varies with type of protein [1] $\ce{ -> }$ DNA sequence can be used to establish amino acid sequence, but not the other way around [1] [2 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: Using DNA sequences to construct cladograms is advantageous because due to the existence of coding and non-coding regions ($\checkmark$) of DNA, more information ($\checkmark$) is held in the nucleotide sequence than the amino acid sequence . Also mutations may occur in the DNA which do not show up in the amino acid sequence due to the degenerative code ($\checkmark$) leading to silent mutations ($\checkmark$). - Any two of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ adaptive radiation can result in closely related species showing very different structural features [1] $\ce{ -> }$ convergent evolution means that distantly related organisms may show very similar structural features [1] $\ce{ -> }$ analogous structures are derived through separate evolutionary pathways and are not indicators of evolutionary relationships [1] $\ce{ -> }$ DNA and amino acid analysis have shown that some classification of organisms based on shared structural features was incorrect [1] [2 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: Cladograms are no longer based on structural features due to the presence of analogous structures, which are the result of convergent evolution ($\checkmark$) and so are not indicators of evolutionary relationships ($\checkmark$). DNA and amino acid analysis have shown that many cladograms based solely on shared structural features are incorrect ($\checkmark$).

title: Question 4
content:
Which characteristic(s) is/are observed in both natural selection and selective breeding?


- I.Favourable traits are selectedII.Increase in variationIII.Change is driven by the environment




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Statement I is correct because in both selective breeding and natural selection, favourable characteristics are “selected” by either the environment (natural selection) or humans (selective breeding). Statement II is incorrect because natural selection and selective breeding don’t increase variation, it influences the proportion of existing variants. Statement III is incorrect because selective breeding is not driven by the environment, it is driven by humans. Choice A is, therefore, correct.
Choices B, C and D are incorrect as they include Statement II and/or Statement III.

title: Question 5
content:
The diagram shows the haploid number of chromosomes in a gamete. What could be the polyploid number of chromosomes for this organism?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/51e41ed5-56e6-42d0-8db1-e48caf3e68dd/images/9ac6bf4f-ee2e-4489-9079-5a64545af1f9/BI0714.png)


[Adapted from: Source Ehamberg. (2010, May 10). File vs diploid.svg. Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved June 30, 2022, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File.svg Copyright under CC BY 3.0]



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 6
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 24
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 3
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 4
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Polyploidy is when an organism develops a mutation where they have more than two sets of the haploid number of chromosomes. Choice B is correct as it has 8 sets of 3 chromosomes.
Choice A is incorrect, as it is the diploid number, which is double the haploid number. Choice C is incorrect, as it is the haploid number of chromosomes. Choice D is incorrect because it is not a multiple of the haploid number.

title: Question 8
content: The male firefly (P. pyralis) signals to potential female mates by flashing its lights in specific patterns. Females will only respond to light patterns produced by their own species. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4bb67863-e258-4a4f-b20c-e75935003089/images/d2b81121-d7da-4354-9e50-45429c3e396a/BI0715A.png) [Source: Adapted from Gallagher, J. (2014, June 3). File: Firefly - Photinus pyralis, Woodbridge, Virginia.jpg - Wikimedia ... Wikimedia commons. Retrieved July 1, 2022, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Firefly_-_Photinus_pyralis,_Woodbridge,_Virginia.jpg Copyright under CC BY 2.0] - Identify the form of reproductive isolation that fireflies exhibit. Justify your answer. [2] - Suggest one possible advantage of this mating ritual. [1] - All fireflies seen today have diverged from the same ancestral species. Explain how speciation is responsible for the large variety of firefly species. [3]
markScheme: - Any two of the following: $\ce{->}$ behavioural type [1] $\ce{->}$ the different light patterns OR the mating behaviour OR rituals [1] $\ce{->}$ prevents the fireflies from mating with different species OR interspecies breeding [1] [2 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The fireflies are exhibiting behavioural isolation ($\checkmark$), as the specific mating rituals that they perform ($\checkmark$), prevent interspecies breeding ($\checkmark$). - Any one of the following: $\ce{->}$ allows females to find males of the same species OR allows fireflies to identify members of the opposite sex [1] $\ce{->}$ allows females to select the fittest males OR mates [1] $\ce{->}$ brighter OR faster flashes can increase the chance of mating OR be more attractive to females [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: An advantage to the firefly of exhibiting this type of behaviour is that it allows females to find males of the same species. ($\checkmark$). - Any three of the following: $\ce{->}$ speciation is the formation of a new species OR the process by which populations diverge OR evolve over time to become distinct species [1] $\ce{->}$ members of a population are isolated from one another OR barriers prevent interbreeding [1] $\ce{->}$ allopatric speciation involves a physical barrier separating groups OR sympatric speciation involves a non-physical barrier separating groups [1] $\ce{->}$ over time selective pressures affect each group differently OR different mutations occur within each group OR over time each group can develop different behaviours OR different characteristics develop due to natural selection [1] $\ce{->}$ allele frequencies change in each population OR genetic drift [1] $\ce{->}$ groups are unable to interbreed OR are reproductively isolated when the barrier is removed OR cannot reproduce to produce fertile offspring [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Speciation is when a group of organisms change so much that they can no longer mate together to produce fertile offspring ($\checkmark$). This can come about by a group of fireflies being separated or isolated ($\checkmark$) from the original population, say by being blown to an island. Over time, the separated group will change. For example the climate may be colder so those individuals with a larger abdomen have more chance of surviving ($\checkmark$) as they lose less heat, and so they pass on their favourable alleles and the allele frequency in the population changes ($\checkmark$). When the separated group encounter fireflies from the original population, they can no longer reproduce together ($\checkmark$) as their abdomens are so different.

title: Question 9
content:
What can result in speciation among organisms living in the same location?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Behavioural isolation
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Geographic isolation
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Stabilising selection
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Directional selection
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Speciation comes about through reproductive isolation which can result from behavioural isolation, in which a population of a species can no longer interbreed with other populations of the species. For example, some segments of a population may respond to a particular mating call or mating behaviour not expressed by another segment of the population.
Geographic isolation (Choice B) occurs when populations are prevented from interbreeding because they are in different physical locations. In this question they are in the same location, therefore this is incorrect. Stabilising selection (Choice C) is a type of natural selection that promotes an intermediate phenotype, so extremes are reduced, and it does not result in speciation. Directional selection (Choice D) is a type of natural selection that promotes an extreme phenotype, but the selection is in one direction so it does not divide the population and so does not lead to speciation. Only if selection occurs in both directions (divergent selection) does it tend to lead to speciation.

title: Question 10
content:
Which of the following are often barriers to hybridisation between species?


- I.A given animal hybrid species has an even, as opposed to an odd number of chromosomes.II.Two species of flowering plants produce gametes at different times of the year.III.Behavioural barriers exist due to variations in bird song between species.




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice D is correct.  Cross-pollination is unlikely if two species of flowering plants produce gametes at different times of year (Statement II).  Mating, and thus hybridisation, is unlikely or impossible if members of one bird species fail to recognise the mating calls of another bird species (Statement III).  Statement I is not a barrier to hybridisation because, typically, animals with even numbers of chromosomes in their somatic cells can reproduce sexually, but those with odd numbers are usually sterile due to an inability of their cells to undergo meiosis.

title: Question 11
content:
Which is a key difference between homologous and analogous structures?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Homologous structures are similar due to ancestry, but analogous structures are similar due to convergent evolution.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ Homologous structures are similar due to ancestry, but analogous structures are similar due to divergent evolution.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ Analogous structures are similar due to ancestry, but homologous structures are similar due to convergent evolution.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ Analogous structures always look similar but homologous structures do not.
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice A is correct because homologous structures are due to common ancestry, but analogous structures are not due to common ancestry and instead are the result of convergent evolution. Choice B is incorrect because analogous structures are similar due to convergent evolution, where structures evolve independently but have similar functions due to the needs of the organisms. Choice C is incorrect because analogous structures are not due to common ancestry. Choice D is incorrect because homologous structures and analogous structures can sometimes look different.

title: Question 12
content:
Triticum monococcum  is an einkorn wheat and was the first domesticated crop. It has a diploid number of 14 chromosomes. Triticum turgidum is a durum wheat with a total of 28 chromosomes. It is a result of the hybridization of Triticum monococcum and another grass Aegilops speltoides which also has a diploid number of 14. What is the correct term for Triticum turgidum in comparison to Triticum monococcum?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Haploid
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Triploid
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Hexaploid
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Tetraploid
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The normal diploid number (2n) means an organism has two sets of chromosomes, one from each parent. Triticum turgidum arose from a hybridisation event between Triticum monococcum (2n = 14) and Aegilops speltoides (2n = 14). Following chromosome doubling, the resulting organism inherited two full sets of chromosomes from each parent, making it tetraploid (4n = 28). Choice D is correct.
Choice A (Haploid) is incorrect because haploid (n) refers to having one set of chromosomes, which would be 7 in this case.
Choice B (Triploid) is incorrect because triploid (3n) means three sets, totalling 21 chromosomes.
Choice C (Hexaploid) is incorrect because hexaploid (6n) refers to six sets, or 42 chromosomes.

title: Question 13
content:
Shown in diagrams A and B are two pairs of similar structures.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f8372de6-7083-44a4-b525-006eed25005b/images/3cd298f7-34ad-4f4c-bc2b-6b7a3b43bf2f/BI0857.png)


[© Revision Village 2022]
Which of the following statements correctly explain the structural similarities shown in diagrams A and B?


- I.Structural similarities in diagram A are primarily due to random mutations, not common ancestry.II.Structural similarities in diagram B are due to the fact they both perform similar functions.III.Diagram A depicts analogous structures, and diagram B depicts homologous structures.




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ II only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice C is correct because only statement II correctly explains the structural similarities.
The bird and insect wings are similar due to convergent evolution.  Statement III is incorrect because diagram A depicts homologous structures, and diagram B depicts analogous structures.  Statement I is incorrect because humans and bats evolved from a common ancestor, and random mutations slowly gave rise to differences in the pentadactyl limb between different species. Choices A, B and D are all incorrect because they include either statements I or III, or both.

title: Question 14
content:
The table below shows the percentage of the amino acid sequences of cytochrome c shared between a human and four other species.
Species PairCytochrome c sequence shared (%)Human–chimpanzee99Human–mouse87Human–chicken75Human–zebrafish50

Which conclusion is best supported by these data?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ A human and a chimpanzee shared a common ancestor more recently than a human and a mouse.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Cytochrome c has evolved faster in the chicken lineage than in the mouse lineage.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ The human–zebrafish divergence occurred most recently.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ The molecular clock runs at different rates in mammals and fish.
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice A is correct because there is a higher percentage similarity for the cytochrome c amino acid sequence between the human and chimpanzee (99%) compared to the human and mouse (87%). This indicates less time for mutations to accumulate, meaning humans and chimpanzees shared a common ancestor more recently than humans and mice.
Choice B is incorrect because although the cytochrome c percentage similarity is lower in chickens (75%) than in mice (87%), this alone does not confirm that cytochrome c evolved faster in the chicken lineage. To determine evolutionary rates, both sequence similarity and known divergence times are needed.
Choice C is incorrect because the lowest sequence similarity (50%) between human and zebrafish suggests the longest time since divergence, not the most recent.
Choice D is incorrect because differences in sequence similarity alone cannot demonstrate variation in molecular clock rates. The molecular clock is a concept based on the idea that mutations accumulate at a relatively constant rate over time in most species. To conclude rate differences, both the time since divergence and the number of accrued changes must both be known.

title: Question 20
content:
Which breeding practice most directly illustrates artificial selection of a polygenic trait?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Allowing the organisms with traits that fit the environment best to pass them on to the next generation.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Breeding plants which are susceptible to a specific bacteria with those that contain the resistance gene.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Crossing only the tallest wheat plants each generation for an increase in yield.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Introducing wild genes to increase genetic diversity in a breed.
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice C is correct because artificial selection on a polygenic trait involves humans selecting individuals with desirable values for a trait that shows continuous variation, such as plant height, which is typically controlled by multiple genes. By repeatedly crossing the tallest wheat plants, breeders shift the population’s average height upwards over successive generations.
Choice A is incorrect because it describes natural selection, where environmental pressures—not human choice—determine which traits are passed on. In this scenario, humans are letting the environment dictate which individuals breed more successfully, so it is not an example of artificial selection.
Choice B is incorrect because crossing a disease-resistant plant with those that are susceptible to the disease is an example of artificial selection, but not on a polygenic trait, as it only involves one gene.
Choice D is incorrect because introducing wild genes to increase genetic diversity adds variation to the gene pool, but does not involve selecting for a specific trait.

title: Question 22
content:
Which pair of structures would be considered analogous?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7166516d-959c-43cd-ac6f-8b646c6bcc04/images/b41d5e40-835b-4b46-8022-7f52ad7a8980/BI1154.png)


[© Revision Village 2023. Created with BioRender.com]
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Analogous structures refer to structures found in different species which serve a similar function, but are not the result of common ancestry. Sharks are cartilaginous fish, and their fins are modified pectoral fins made of cartilage. Whales are mammals, and their fins are modified forelimbs, which are homologous to the forelimbs of land-dwelling mammals. Whale and shark fins serve the same purpose, are similar in structure, and are the product of convergent evolution.
The structures in Choices A and B share similar functions, but they also share a common ancestry, making them homologous, not analogous. Choice C cannot be correct as they share a common ancestry but are quite different in terms of structure and function, also making them homologous.

title: Question 27
content:
The table shows factors that can result in speciation. Which word is matched to the correct definition?

WordDefinitionA.$\hspace{1em}$PolyploidyHaving two complete sets of chromosomesB.$\hspace{1em}$Sexual reproductionThe combining of genetic information from two individualsC.$\hspace{1em}$Reproductive isolationSpecies breeding to produce infertile offspringD.$\hspace{1em}$MutationsRandom changes to the amino acid sequence
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Sexual reproduction involves the fusion of gametes from two individuals, resulting in offspring with a combination of genetic material. This process increases genetic variation, which is essential for evolution and natural selection. Choice B is the correct answer.
Polyploidy occurs when an organism has more than two complete sets of chromosomes (e.g., triploid 3n, tetraploid 4n). The definition given in the table describes diploidy (2n), which is the standard chromosome number in most sexually reproducing organisms; Choice A incorrect.
Interbreeding between different species can sometimes produce infertile offspring, such as a horse × donkey = mule. This is an example of reproductive isolation because the hybrid offspring is sterile, preventing gene flow between the two species. However, because horses and donkeys are already separate species, this does not result in speciation—it simply reinforces their reproductive barrier. For reproductive isolation to lead to speciation, it must occur within a single species, preventing interbreeding between different populations.  Choice C is incorrect.
Mutations are random changes in DNA sequences, not in the amino acid sequence; Choice D is incorrect.

title: Question 28
content: - Outline the role of the active site in an enzyme. [3] - Outline how members of the same species can become separate populations via speciation. [4] - Describe the regulation and use of hormones during in vitro fertilisation (IVF). [8]
markScheme: - any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ it is the binding site for a substrate OR specific region where the substrate binds [1] $\ce{ -> }$ it allows for induced fit binding of the substrate [1] $\ce{ -> }$ it facilitates enzyme-substrate specificity OR has a specific shape that allows the substrate to bind effectively [1] $\ce{ -> }$ it causes a conformational change in the enzyme-substrate complex, which leads to the formation of products [1] $\ce{ -> }$ it is the site where a substrate is converted into a product OR where a substrate is held while a chemical reaction takes place [1] $\ce{ -> }$ it lowers the energy of the transition state OR activation energy so that a chemical reaction can take place more efficiently [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The active site of an enzyme is a specific region where a substrate binds ($\checkmark$). Within the active site, the enzyme lowers the energy of the transition state ($\checkmark$), facilitating the chemical reaction so that the substrate can be successfully converted into a product ($\checkmark$). - any four of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ a population consists of all organisms of one species living in the same place at the same time, capable of breeding together [1] $\ce{ -> }$ members of the species can become geographically isolated OR separated by a physical barrier such as a river OR mountain [1] $\ce{ -> }$ members of the species can become temporally isolated OR become separated by producing gametes at different times OR seasons [1] $\ce{ -> }$ members of the species can become behaviourally isolated OR become separated by displaying distinctive courtship behaviours [1] $\ce{ -> }$ when populations of the same species become separated, genetic drift will cause the allele frequencies to change [1] $\ce{ -> }$ reproductive isolation mechanisms, such as incompatibility of reproductive organs, can prevent interbreeding between separated populations [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mutations can introduce new genetic variations in each isolated population, contributing to genetic divergence over time [1] $\ce{ -> }$ selective pressures will act on the separated species, leading to an accumulation of genetic differences in each population OR natural selection will act on each population so that traits that are beneficial to each group will accumulate [1] $\ce{ -> }$ over many generations, speciation will occur OR the separate populations will not be able to breed to produce fertile offspring [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Members of the same species can become separate populations if they become geographically isolated($\checkmark$) or behaviourally isolated ($\checkmark$). Once populations of the same species are separated, genetic drift will cause the allele frequencies to change ($\checkmark$). Selective pressures will act on the separated populations, leading to an accumulation of genetic differences ($\checkmark$). Eventually, speciation($\checkmark$) will occur, resulting in populations that can no longer interbreed to produce fertile offspring. - any eight of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ drugs are used to downregulate several hormones OR FSH OR follicle stimulating hormone AND LH OR luteinising hormone, to better control the release OR maturation of follicles later on [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the function of FSH OR follicle-stimulating hormone is to promote follicle growth OR mature eggs [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the function of LH OR luteinising hormone is to trigger ovulation OR trigger the release of mature eggs from the ovaries [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the downregulation of LH and FSH also results in the downregulation of oestrogen and progesterone [1] $\ce{ -> }$ oestrogen normally stimulates the uterine OR endometrial lining to build up [1] $\ce{ -> }$ progesterone normally stimulates the maintenance of the uterine OR endometrial lining for implantation [1] $\ce{ -> }$ high doses of FSH are injected to stimulate superovulation OR the development of many follicles [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the development of many follicles increases the chances of successful fertilisation during the IVF process [1] $\ce{ -> }$ gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists are injected to prevent premature ovulation OR control the timing of ovulation [1] $\ce{ -> }$ human chorionic gonadotropin OR hCG is injected to stimulate the follicles to mature [1] $\ce{ -> }$ progesterone is injected before the fertilised egg is implanted to improve the chances of successful implantation [1] [8 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: In vitro fertilisation (IVF) is a process used by couples with fertility issues, where mature eggs are fertilised outside the body. To start the process, drugs are used to downregulate several reproductive hormones to better control the release and maturation of follicles later on ($\checkmark$). The downregulation of FSH stops follicles from growing ($\checkmark$). Drugs are also used to downregulate LH, which results in the prevention of ovulation ($\checkmark$). The downregulation of LH and FSH also results in the downregulation of oestrogen and progesterone ($\checkmark$), which normally function to stimulate the build-up of the uterine lining($\checkmark$) and maintain the uterine lining ($\checkmark$), respectively. Once these hormones are successfully downregulated, high doses of FSH are injected to trigger the development of multiple follicles in the ovary($\checkmark$). The development of many follicles increases the chance of successful fertilisation during the IVF process ($\checkmark$). GnRH agonists are injected to prevent premature ovulation ($\checkmark$), and hCG is injected to stimulate the follicles to mature ($\checkmark$). A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.

title: Question 30
content:
Which of the following statements accurately describes characteristics of homologous structures?


- I.Homologous structures are defined as functionally similar anatomical features that arise through divergent evolution.II.Although bats and dolphins exhibit distinct external morphology, their forelimbs evolved from a common ancestor.III.Bird wings and insect wings originate from the same embryonic tissues and are therefore homologous.




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
While homologous structures do arise via divergent evolution, they are not defined by functional similarity. In fact, their function may differ considerably, for example, the forelimbs of bats for flight versus the flippers of dolphins for swimming. Homology is established based on shared structural origin, not shared function; Statement I is false.
Homologous structures are anatomical features found in different species that share a common evolutionary origin, even if they have diverged in form or function. Both bats and dolphins have a pentadactyl limb structure in their forelimbs, despite a differing external appearance and function. This reflects divergent evolution from a shared ancestor; Statement II is true.
Bat wings and insect wings are analogous structures. Although they perform a similar function (flight), they evolved independently in different evolutionary lineages and do not share embryological origin. Bat wings derive from the vertebrate limb, while insect wings arise from outgrowths of the arthropod exoskeleton. Statement III is false.
Choice B is the correct answer because it only includes the one true Statement II.
Choices A, C and D are incorrect as they include one or more of the false Statements I and III.

title: Question 33
content:
Two species of smartweed (genus Persicaria) hybridise and form a new species.  Which of the examples of parent chromosome number would result in a barrier to reproduction?


- I.2nII.3nIII.4n




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II, and IIII
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice B is correct because 3n cells cannot undergo meiosis and, therefore, they would be a barrier to reproduction.
If both parents have the regular diploid chromosome number (2n) then the resulting offspring would also be 2n, due to normal meiotic cell division and formation of viable gametes. A parent with a diploid number of chromosomes would, therefore, not be a barrier to reproduction.
Even though tetraploidy (4n) can lead to more complex pairing of chromosomes during meiosis, the even number of chromosomes allows meiosis to occur and viable gametes can be produced. A tetraploid parent would, therefore, not necessarily be a barrier to reproduction.
Choices A, C and D do not include 3n, and so are not correct answers.

title: Question 36
content: - Outline how reproductive isolation can result in changes in allele frequencies between populations. [3] - Compare and contrast spermatogenesis and oogenesis. [5] - Outline how muscle contraction is brought about according to the sliding filament model. [7]
markScheme: - any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ allopatric speciation is caused by geographical isolation and, therefore reproductive isolation [1] $\ce{ -> }$ sympatric speciation takes place in the same habitat due to different niches OR differences in feeding behaviour OR behavioural differences OR courtship differences [1] $\ce{ -> }$ both processes lead to isolation of populations [1] $\ce{ -> }$ genetic variation occurs due to genetic drift OR mutation [1] $\ce{ -> }$ reproductive isolation prevents or limits gene flow between populations [1] $\ce{ -> }$ leads to changes in allele frequencies within those populations [1] $\ce{ -> }$ over time this leads to formation of a new species due to inability to breed with the original population of the species [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Geographic isolation, such as that caused by tectonic plate movement, can lead to isolation of a population ($\checkmark$). Reproductive isolation prevents or limits gene flow ($\checkmark$) between populations of the same species. This leads to changes in allele frequencies within those populations, and over time could lead to the formation of a new species ($\checkmark$) due to its inability to breed with the original population that it separated from. - any five of the following: (at least one from each): Similarities $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH produce haploid cells OR nuclei [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH involve meiosis [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH occur in reproductive organs [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH involve maturation of immature germ cells [1] Differences $\ce{ -> }$ spermatogenesis occurs in testes WHEREAS oogenesis occurs in the ovaries [1] $\ce{ -> }$ spermatogenesis produces many gametes WHEREAS oogenesis produces one gamete per month or cycle [1] $\ce{ -> }$ spermatogenesis produces OR results in four mature sperms from one precursor cell ( and no polar bodies) WHEREAS oogenesis produces one mature egg from the precursor cell, (the other cells forming polar bodies) OR spermatogenesis involves mitotic and meiotic divisions WHEREAS oogenesis involves meiotic divisions with uneven cytokinesis [1] $\ce{ -> }$ spermatogenesis starts at puberty WHEREAS oogenesis begins during fetal development [1] $\ce{ -> }$ spermatogenesis continues through adult life WHEREAS oogenesis stops at menopause [1] [5 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Both spermatogenesis and oogenesis take place in reproductive organs ($\checkmark$), however spermatogenesis occurs in the testes of biologically male animals whereas oogenesis occurs in the ovaries of biologically female animals ($\checkmark$). Both processes produce haploid cells ($\checkmark$) via the process of meiosis ($\checkmark$). While spermatogenesis produces four mature sperms from one precursor cell, oogenesis produces one mature egg ($\checkmark$) from the precursor cell, the other cells becoming polar bodies. Spermatogenesis continues throughout adult life in the biological male, whereas oogenesis stops at menopause ($\checkmark$) in biological females. Spermatogenesis produces many gametes, whereas oogenesis produces one gamete per month ($\checkmark$). - any seven of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ muscle fibres consist of myofibrils made up of myosin AND actin AND troponin AND tropomyosin protein [1] $\ce{ -> }$ tropomyosin winds around actin filaments covering binding sites for myosin heads [1] $\ce{ -> }$ action potential passes along cell membrane of muscle fibre OR sarcolemma OR down T-tubules [1] $\ce{ -> }$ causes release of calcium ions OR Ca2+ from sarcoplasmic reticulum [1] $\ce{ -> }$ Ca2+ bind troponin protein on the actin filaments causing a conformational change [1] $\ce{ -> }$ change lifts tropomyosin away for myosin binding sites on actin OR leads to a change in the tropomyosin protein on the actin filament exposing sites to which myosin can bind [1] $\ce{ -> }$ myosin head binds to actin forming cross bridges [1] $\ce{ -> }$ inorganic phosphate OR Pi released from myosin head and myosin head changes angle, pulling actin filament along OR leading to power stroke [1] $\ce{ -> }$ ‘power stroke’ OR movement of myosin head shortens the sarcomere leading to a muscle contraction [1] $\ce{ -> }$ ADP is released from myosin head, allowing ATP to bind [1] $\ce{ -> }$ causes cross-bridge to break OR cause myosin head to release actin [1] $\ce{ -> }$ hydrolysis of ATP releases energy to return myosin head to original position OR to ‘re-cock’ head [1] $\ce{ -> }$ titin stabilises the sarcomere by anchoring myosin to the Z-line OR provides elasticity OR helps the sarcomere return to its resting length after contraction [1] [7 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Muscle fibres consist of myofibrils made up of thick filaments containing myosin, and thin filaments made up of actin, tropomyosin and troponin ($\checkmark$). An action potential travelling along the sarcolemma causes the release of calcium ions from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. The calcium ions bind to troponin, which causes a conformational change ($\checkmark$), lifting the tropomyosin and, exposing sites to which myosin can bind ($\checkmark$). The binding of the myosin head to the actin causes the release of inorganic phosphate, and the change in the angle of the myosin head, pulling the actin filament along ($\checkmark$). ADP is released from the myosin head, which allows ATP to bind to the myosin in its place ($\checkmark$), causing the cross-bridge between the actin and myosin to break ($\checkmark$). The ATP molecule is then hydrolysed to ADP and Pi, releasing the energy needed for the myosin head to return to its original position ($\checkmark$). It is now ready for the whole process to occur again. $\underline{\textrm{For additional detail}}$: , see 6:00 in Muscle and Motility II Key Concept Video: https://www.revisionvillage.com/ib-biology/hl/key-concepts/?keyConceptId=6ed962e4-ed05-44fc-b4e4-c0ff93db627f A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information. [1]

title: Question 37
content:
What is adaptive radiation?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ When a new species is produced through natural selection
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ When new ecological niches are exploited, resulting in speciation
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ When a species moves to a new location and adapts to new conditions
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ When speciation occurs, and analogous traits remain
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice B is correct because adaptive radiation refers to the rapid diversification and speciation of a single ancestral species into multiple descendent species, taking advantage of different niches within a community. Choice A is incorrect as natural selection refers to organisms with advantageous traits having a greater chance of survival and so a greater chance to reproduce and pass on those traits to future generations within that population, leading to the evolution of species over time.  Choice C is incorrect as it refers to the phenomenon where an organism changes in response to new environmental conditions through natural selection and random mutations, while adaptive radiation involves the rapid evolution of more than one species from a single ancestral species. Choice D is incorrect, as analogous traits do not result from common ancestry.

title: Question 38
content:
Which of the following is NOT a true statement of allopolyploidy in plants?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ It results in an increased chance of hybrid vigour.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Plant breeders can select varieties that are best suited to local conditions.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ It results in the duplication of chromosomes within a single species.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ It results in an Increased ability of plants to colonise new habitats.
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Allopolyploidy arises from hybridisation between two different species, followed by chromosome doubling. The key point is that it introduces a new set of chromosomes from a different species rather than simply doubling an existing diploid genome.
In contrast, autopolyploidy occurs within a single species and results in an exact doubling (or higher multiple) of its own chromosome set.  Choice C is, therefore, the correct answer.
Choice A is incorrect because hybrid vigour is often a direct result of allopolyploidy. New alleles are introduced into a species, giving an immediate selective advantage to that plant species.
Choice B is incorrect because allopolyploidy allows new varieties that are well adapted to different local abiotic and biotic conditions. This characteristic can explain the widespread global cultivation of wheat (Triticum aestivum) as a staple crop.
Choice D is incorrect because the new alleles brought in from new species allow a species to compete in a territory or habitat that it had not otherwise been successful in, allowing an invasive species to outcompete the native species in many cases.

title: Question 39
content: The pale and dark forms of the peppered moth (Biston betularia) are a classic example of natural selection. The graph shows the changes in the population of pale (mostly white) and dark (mostly black) peppered moths (Biston betularia) during and post the industrial revolution. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/06c9ef98-77c2-415f-98d2-5ce3c2d35738/images/d3574329-664b-4912-804c-f9a20dfa2636/BI1291.png) [© Revision Village 2023] The image shows the phenotype of pale and dark moths on white tree bark. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/06c9ef98-77c2-415f-98d2-5ce3c2d35738/images/2cab37cd-63f2-45dd-b597-e0d9ac454ded/BI1291b.png) [Source: Adapted from Bedin, T. (2020, May 26). Tilpasning og evolusjon - natural science (PB) - NDLA. ndla.no. Retrieved October 02, 2023, from https://ndla.no/en/subject:1/topic:6/topic:3/resource:09fc6c1a-eaa1-4901-b2ae-ee5e7ce1900c. Copyright free] - Distinguish between the changes in the numbers of pale and dark moths shown in the graph. [2] - - Outline how the trends in the graph can be explained by natural selection. [3] - Suggest a technique a group of students could use to compare the population sizes of peppered moths between a deciduous (broadleaved) and a coniferous (evergreen) wood. [1] - Calculate the percentage increase in dark-coloured moths between 1850 and 1900. [1] - Draw a line on the graph, predicting how the number of pale moths would have changed, if the industrial revolution did not happen. [1] - In addition to collecting data such as that shown in the graph, scientists rely on various forms of evidence to explore the concept of evolution. State two other forms of evidence that supports the theory of evolution. [2]
markScheme: - Any two of the following $\ce{ -> }$ between 1800 and 1850 OR around the middle of the Industrial Revolution, the number of pale moths remained high OR between 95 and 100% WHEREAS the number of dark moths remained low OR between 0 and 5% [1] $\ce{ -> }$ from 1850, the number of pale moths began to rapidly decrease WHEREAS the number of dark moths rapidly increased [1] $\ce{ -> }$ around 1870 OR just before 1875, the number of dark moths surpasses the number of pale moths [1] $\ce{ -> }$ from 1900, the number of pale moths was low OR less than 5% WHEREAS the number of dark moths was high OR around 95% [1] [2 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Between 1800 and 1850, the number of pale moths was between 95 and 100%, whereas the number of dark moths was between 0 and 5% ($\checkmark$). However, from 1850 the number of pale moths decreased rapidly, whereas the number of dark moths increased rapidly ($\checkmark$). - - Any three of the following $\ce{ -> }$ natural selection explains how individuals with advantageous traits are more likely to survive to reproduce [1] $\ce{ -> }$ before the Industrial Revolution, lichens OR mosses OR bark on trees OR brickwork were white, so the pale moths were able to camouflage from predators [1] $\ce{ -> }$ increased rates of pollution OR soot during the Industrial Revolution caused white lichen and mosses on lichen OR moss OR bark on trees OR brickwork to turn black [1] $\ce{ -> }$ pale moths were more visible to predators, so their numbers decreased [1] $\ce{ -> }$ dark moths were able to camouflage from predators, so were better able to survive and breed [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the dark moths gained a selective advantage over the pale moths OR were selected for OR are under directional selection OR pale moths faced intense selection pressure due to predation [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Before the Industrial Revolution, lichen and mosses on trees were white, so the pale moths were able to camouflage from predators ($\checkmark$). However, post-Industrial Revolution, there were increased rates of pollution which caused trees to turn black ($\checkmark$). This meant that the dark moths were able to camouflage from predators, so were better able to survive and breed ($\checkmark$). - - $\ce{ -> }$ capture-mark-release-recapture [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: One technique that students could use is the mark-release-recapture of peppered moths ($\checkmark$) in coniferous and deciduous woods. - Any one of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ 1800 % [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/06c9ef98-77c2-415f-98d2-5ce3c2d35738/images/335ad891-c368-45e8-8155-0eaae77e5ba2/BI1291c.png) [© Revision Village 2023] Percentage increase = ((final value - initial value) ÷ initial value) $\times$ 100% Percentage increase = ((95 - 5) ÷ 5 ) $\times$ 100% Percentage increase = 1800% ($\checkmark$) - Any one of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ line should continue the same trend from before 1850 to 1900 [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/06c9ef98-77c2-415f-98d2-5ce3c2d35738/images/6b0f3bad-5b55-4b8b-a3eb-6976229dd3c3/BI1291d.png) [© Revision Village 2023] - Any two of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ DNA sequence OR RNA sequencing [1] $\ce{ -> }$ amino acid sequence of proteins [1] $\ce{ -> }$ selective breeding OR artificial selection [1] $\ce{ -> }$ homologous structures OR comparative anatomy OR vestigial structures [1] $\ce{ -> }$ embryonic development [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the fossil record [1] $\ce{ -> }$ geographic distribution of species [1] [2 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The fossil record ($\checkmark$) and DNA sequencing ($\checkmark$) provide evidence for the theory of evolution.

title: Question 41
content:
Which letter in the Venn diagram correctly matches a description of a speciation event?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/20820265-d2c3-4e59-814e-19b8b0ef6f14/images/eab43cca-4ca7-478f-ba36-41e908d682e6/BI0868%20A4.1.11%20png.png)


[©Revision Village 2023.]



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Bonobos (Pan paniscus) and chimpanzees (Pan troglodytes) evolved from a common ancestor.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ A hybrid species (3n) was produced by two smartweed species (genus Persicaria) living in the same geographical region.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Sub-species of tortoise (C. nigra becki and C. nigra guntheri) in the Galapagos have evolved due to lava flow forming lava fields and impassable terrain.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ The tetraploid grey treefrog emerged as a new species distinct from its diploid relative leading to reproductive isolation despite occupying the same geographical area.
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice B is correct because speciation through polyploidy is common in smartweed; if the resulting chromosome number is odd (here 3n), then the plants will become reproductively isolated from the 2n population, even though they are in the same geographic location. This is, therefore, an example of polyploidy and sympatric speciation.
Choice A is incorrect because, although bonobos and chimpanzees were geographically isolated from each other (allopatric speciation), there was no increase in the chromosome number during the speciation event.  Choice C is incorrect because the lava fields geographically isolated the tortoises, leading to sub-species forming. This is, therefore, an ongoing allopatric speciation event, not sympatric, and it does not involve polyploidy. The tetraploid frog resulted from a polyploidy speciation event that resulted in reproductive isolation. This did not involve spatial separation, so cannot be regarded as allopatric speciation; therefore, Choice D is also incorrect.

title: Question 42
content:
Which statement is true for both Lamarckism and epigenetic inheritance?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Both involve changes in the DNA sequence that are inherited and lead to evolution.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Both involve inherited changes caused by the environment, but the effect of epigenetics may only last a few generations, so it is not a type of evolution.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Both operate by the use and disuse of traits, leading to evolutionary change.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Only epigenetics leads to changes in the DNA sequence and, therefore, evolution.
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice B is correct because both Lamarckism and epigenetic inheritance propose that environmental factors can cause inherited changes, while Lamarckism suggested these changes were permanent and led to evolution through traits acquired during an organism's lifetime. Epigenetic changes involve reversible chemical modifications to DNA or histone proteins that affect gene expression without altering the DNA sequence. These epigenetic changes can be passed to offspring, but often only persist for a few generations and typically do not lead to long-term evolutionary change.
Choice A is incorrect because neither Lamarckism nor epigenetic inheritance involves changes to the DNA sequence itself. Epigenetics modifies gene expression through chemical tags, while Lamarckism assumed physical or behavioural changes were inherited.
Choice C is incorrect because only Lamarckism proposed that the use or disuse of traits directly causes evolutionary change. Epigenetic inheritance does not involve the use or disuse of structures but rather chemical changes to gene regulation influenced by environmental factors. Furthermore, epigenetics does not lead to evolution.
Choice D is incorrect because epigenetic inheritance does not involve changes to the DNA sequence itself and therefore does not cause long-term evolutionary change.

title: Question 43
content: The Allium genus contains leeks, garlics and chives. The images below show two members of the Allium genus that are native to Lithuania and their associated chromosome numbers. Polyploidy events have occurred to produce Allium oleraeceum. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fb64d4df-df2a-4b61-8edd-4bbd46ffa597/images/8bab7929-0bd6-4141-be1e-51087f10847c/BI1407A.png) ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fb64d4df-df2a-4b61-8edd-4bbd46ffa597/images/b20d81ba-794e-4f15-aed0-f63bb438d293/BI1407B.png) Allium angulosumAllium oleraeceum2n = 164n = 32 [Source: Adapted from Lefnaer, S. (2015, July 26). Category: allium angulosum. Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved January 8, 2023, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Allium_angulosum_sl3.jpg. Copyright under CC BY 4.0][Source: Adapted from Leidus, I. (2013, July 7). File: allium oleraceum - rohulauk.jpg - wikimedia commons. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved January 8, 2023, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Allium_oleraceum_-_rohulauk.jpg. Copyright under CC BY 3.0] - Suggest how polyploidy may occur in plants. [1] - Outline how polyploidy in a species can lead to speciation. [2] - With reference to plant hormones, explain the directional growth observed in the image of Allium oleraceum. [3] - Plants within the Allium genus often have bulbs which grow underground. Outline how bulbs can be considered sinks and sources in the process of translocation. [2]
markScheme: - Any one of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ hybridisation events between closely related plant species OR gametes of two closely related plant species fuse [1] $\ce{ -> }$ extra set of chromosomes formed during DNA replication stage in interphase OR cell cycle [1] $\ce{ -> }$ a diploid gamete fuses with a haploid gamete OR two diploid gametes fuse together [1] $\ce{ -> }$ failed spindle formation OR non-disjunction OR failed separation of chromosomes IN meiosis leading to gametes with extra set of chromosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ chromosomal duplications in cells involved in vegetative OR asexual reproduction [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Polyploidy can occur in plants if there are hybridisation events between closely related plant species ($\checkmark$). - Any two of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ organisms with a different number of chromosomes OR new tetraploid and original diploid cannot breed together to produce fertile offspring [1] $\ce{ -> }$ results in reproductive isolation [1] $\ce{ -> }$ polyploid plants may be larger OR more fertile OR better adapted than original populations allowing them to exploit different ecological niches leading to geographical isolation [1] $\ce{ -> }$ once isolated polyploid population diverges genetically from original populations [1] [2 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The new polyploid organism has a different number of chromosomes than the original plant and so they cannot breed together to produce fertile offspring ($\checkmark$). This can result in reproductive isolation ($\checkmark$), which could lead to the formation of a new species. - Any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ plant stems OR Allium oleraceum stems respond to light by growing towards it OR plant stems are positively phototropic [1] $\ce{ -> }$ auxin is produced by actively dividing cells in the tip of the stem OR in the meristem [1] $\ce{ -> }$ light causes auxin to accumulate on the shaded side of the stem [1] $\ce{ -> }$ auxin efflux pumps bring about increased concentration on shaded side [1] $\ce{ -> }$ this causes cells on the shaded side to elongate [1] $\ce{ -> }$ auxin causes protons to be pumped from cytoplasm of cells into cell wall lowering pH [1] $\ce{ -> }$ lowering of pH loosens linkages between cellulose fibres so when water enters cell wall stretches and cell elongates [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Allium oleraceum has a positive phototropic response to light ($\checkmark$). Auxin is released from the actively dividing cells of the meristem ($\checkmark$). Light stimulates auxin to accumulate on the shaded side of the stem ($\checkmark$), so that cells on the shaded side elongate ($\checkmark$). - Any two of the following: Answer must include statements supporting bulbs being a sink and supporting bulbs being a source to gain full marks Bulbs are a source because… $\ce{ -> }$ when the plant is not actively photosynthesising, it uses sucrose OR starch OR carbohydrate OR nutrients OR amino acids stored in bulb [1] Bulbs are a sink because… $\ce{ -> }$ when the plant is actively photosynthesising it will provide carbohydrates OR glucose OR sucrose OR starch, for storage in OR growth of, bulb [1] [2 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: At the beginning of the growing season, the bulb is a source because the plant is not actively photosynthesising, so it needs to use the sucrose and amino acids stored in the bulbs for growth ($\checkmark$). However, during the middle of the growing season, when the plant is actively photosynthesising, sucrose is transported from the leaves to the bulb to store the excess carbohydrate and so the bulb becomes a sink ($\checkmark$).

title: Question 45
content: - Adaptive radiation results in a single ancestral species evolving into multiple, closely related new species which may live in close proximity to each other. Outline 3 mechanisms by which closely related species living in close proximity may be reproductively isolated. [3] - Outline the process by which two species may be formed from an ancestral population through the process of allopatric speciation. [5] - Describe how sexual and asexual reproduction can lead to the formation of new species with different numbers of copies of each chromosome. [7]
markScheme: - Any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ behavioural isolation OR failure to recognise members of different species as possible mates [1] $\ce{ -> }$ temporal isolation OR reproduction occurs at different times [1] $\ce{ -> }$ postzygotic barriers [1] $\ce{ -> }$ habitat isolation, whereby a subsection of one population occupies a different ecological niche [1] $\ce{ -> }$ hybrid offspring are sterile [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mechanical isolation, whereby different morphological structures evolve, resulting in physical incompatibility [1] $\ce{ -> }$ two closely related species may have different numbers of chromosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ incompatibility of gametes OR inability of sperm to fertilise egg [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Species living close to one another may be reproductively isolated due to behavioural isolation ($\checkmark$), which is a failure to recognise potential mates. Two species may also be isolated due to postzygotic barriers ($\checkmark$). For example, their offspring could be sterile ($\checkmark$). - Any five of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ geographic isolation OR ancestral population is separated into two areas OR any named example, e.g. mountain range, isthmus etc. [1] $\ce{ -> }$ different random mutations accrue in the two different populations [1] $\ce{ -> }$ different alleles are produced in the two different populations [1] $\ce{ -> }$ different phenotypes are produced in the two different populations [1] $\ce{ -> }$ different selection pressures in two different areas [1] $\ce{ -> }$ different traits selected for in two different areas [1] $\ce{ -> }$ genetic drift [1] $\ce{ -> }$ reproductive isolation OR behavioural isolation OR temporal isolation OR post-zygotic barriers [1] $\ce{ -> }$ gene flow cannot occur [1] [5 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The ancestral population could have been divided into two populations by the formation of a mountain range ($\checkmark$), which means gene flow between the two populations does not occur ($\checkmark$). Random mutations then build up ($\checkmark$) between the two populations leading to the production of new alleles ($\checkmark$) and phenotypes ($\checkmark$). Selection pressures may differ ($\checkmark$) between the two populations as well, which means different phenotypes would be selected for in the two different environments. Eventually, the two different populations may become reproductively isolated ($\checkmark$). For example, they may no longer recognise each other as potential mates. - Any seven of the following: Asexual reproduction: $\ce{ -> }$ chromosome number of daughter species is an odd number [1] Sexual reproduction: $\ce{ -> }$ the hybridisation of closely related species [1] $\ce{ -> }$ new hybrid species has one set of chromosomes from each parent species [1] $\ce{ -> }$ self-fertilisation OR autogamy occurs, and chromosome number is doubled OR halved [1] $\ce{ -> }$ fusion of two diploid gametes OR another valid example of fertilisation leading to a change in chromosome copy number [1] Both asexual and sexual reproduction: $\ce{ -> }$ reproductive isolation OR new species are sometimes brought about by differences in chromosome copy number [1] $\ce{ -> }$ abnormal meiotic division in parent species [1] $\ce{ -> }$ daughter species is reproductively isolated from the parent species [1] $\ce{ -> }$ daughter species reproduces asexually because meiosis is no longer possible [1] [7 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Both sexually and asexually reproducing species can be produced when two closely related species hybridise ($\checkmark$) to produce a daughter species that can carry out mitosis and is reproductively isolated from the parent species ($\checkmark$). Sometimes reproductive isolation in both sexually and asexually reproducing species is brought about by a change in chromosome copy number ($\checkmark$). This is often due to abnormal meiotic divisions ($\checkmark$). When an odd number of chromosomes is present ($\checkmark$) in the daughter species, for example, 3n, meiosis is impossible ($\checkmark$), and the daughter species can only reproduce asexually through mitosis. If the daughter species reproduces through sexual reproduction, the chromosome copy number must be even ($\checkmark$) so that meiosis is possible ($\checkmark$). Sometimes a single, self-fertilizing species may undergo abnormal meiotic divisions ($\checkmark$), which result in the production of a new species that has half ($\checkmark$) or double ($\checkmark$) the number of chromosomes and thus becomes reproductively isolated. A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information. [1]

title: Question 46
content:
The diagram below shows the feeding areas of four species of warbler (genus Setophaga).  What is the best explanation for how these warblers came to coexist in such close proximity?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/efab0b51-840a-4a0d-ba33-d1c317006c64/images/33161867-8ead-42eb-bf6d-c392376ff2be/BI0869.png)


[©Revision Village 2023.]



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Polyploidy resulted from multiple sympatric speciation events.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Adaptive radiation reduced competition between the species.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ The presence of four species increases biodiversity and ecological stability.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ One species evolved over time to exploit new ecological niches.
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice B is correct because adaptive radiation involves exploiting new ecological niches and speciation, here resulting in 4 new species from the original ancestral species which compete less with one another. Choice A is incorrect, as polyploidy is rare in vertebrates and animals generally. Although greater biodiversity generally increases ecological stability, Choice C does not explain how the warblers came to coexist in such close proximity. Choice D is incorrect because if only one species evolved to exploit new ecological niches, there would be only one warbler species, not four.

title: Question 2
content:
Which is not a cause of the current biodiversity crisis?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Decreased urbanisation
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ The widespread use of vaccines
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Increased air travel
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Increased transmission of diseases
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Urbanisation is not decreasing, it is increasing all over the world, which is contributing to the current biodiversity crisis. Choice A  is correct.
The widespread use of vaccines has led to fewer people dying of diseases before reproductive age, contributing to worldwide population growth, which contributes to the current biodiversity crisis, so Choice B is incorrect. Increased air travel results in more pollution and makes it easier for diseases to spread worldwide which sometimes negatively impacts species, contributing to the biodiversity crisis, so Choices C and D are incorrect.

title: Question 3
content:
Which statement(s) are possible solutions to the biodiversity crisis?


- I.Promoting rewilding projectsII.Recycling and reusing productsIII.Increase meat consumption




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Rewilding projects attempt to restore and rehabilitate ecosystems by reintroducing native species and allowing natural processes to become re-established.  Statement I is therefore correct. Recycling and reusing products means fewer resources will be extracted from the Earth which is a process that can destroy natural habitats and lead to excessive landfill use, so Statement II is correct. Choice C  is therefore correct (Statement I and II).
Increasing meat consumption (Statement III) results in more land being cleared for animals such as cattle to be bred, decreasing biodiversity. Choice D is therefore incorrect as it includes this statement. Choices A and B are missing one of the possible solutions to the crisis and are therefore incorrect.

title: Question 4
content:
Which is not a cause of anthropogenic species extinction?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Overhunting
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Deforestation
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Introduction of new diseases
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Asteroids
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Anthropogenic species extinction is extinction caused by human activities.  Asteroid impacts are natural events and are not caused by human activities. However, they have played a significant role in past mass extinctions, such as the event that led to the extinction of the dinosaurs. Choice D is therefore correct.
When humans overhunt (Choice A) it can lead to a decline in populations and, in some cases, extinction. Deforestation (Choice B) is another human activity. The clearing of forests for purposes such as agriculture, logging or urban development, can destroy habitats and disrupt ecosystems, leading to extinction of species that rely on those habitats. When humans introduce new diseases to ecosystems (Choice C), either accidentally or deliberately, it can have devastating effects on native species and bring about extinction.  Choices A, B  and C  are therefore incorrect.

title: Question 5
content:
The image shows changes in coverage to mixed dipterocarp forests in Southeast Asia over the last 100 years.
Which is not a factor that contributed to these changes?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a1fefead-ab2a-4ce6-991b-34aa2eb33cde/images/ede73a61-24fa-43b8-b1ae-1135b7e67858/BI0904_A4.2.png)


[Source: Adapted from San Jose. (2006, February 8). File: map of east asia.png - wikimedia commons. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved July 10, 2023 from URL https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Map_of_East_Asia.png. Copyright under CC BY 3.0]



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Building of new roads to mining sites
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Poaching of endangered species
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Planting of rubber plantations
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Building of hydroelectric dams
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The image shows the loss of forests in Southeast Asia over 100 years. Poaching of endangered species does not result in deforestation; Choice B  is correct.
Building new roads to mining sites involves clearing land to mine sites, so Choice A  is incorrect. Planting rubber plantations requires clearing forests to plant rubber trees, so Choice C  is incorrect.  Building hydroelectric dams can lead to flooding of forests and irreparable damage to trees, so Choice D is also incorrect.
