Any one of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ Tinamous can fly so can escape predators OR hunters more easily [1] $\ce{ -> }$ Tinamous can build their nests high up in trees so that their young are less vulnerable [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: Tinamous are less likely to go extinct than the Moa, as they can build their nests high up in trees so that their young are less vulnerable ($\checkmark$). - Any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ geographic isolation of the Tinamou OR Moa lineage meant that different populations were subjected to varying environmental conditions [1] $\ce{ -> }$ random mutations lead to genetic variation [1] $\ce{ -> }$ genetic variation may have resulted in various physical and behavioural traits [1] $\ce{ -> }$ certain traits among Tinamous OR Moas would have been more advantageous than others [1] $\ce{ -> }$ for example, camouflage OR flight ability OR specific feeding adaptations OR any other suitable example of advantageous trait [1] $\ce{ -> }$ therefore greater chance of survival OR more organisms with these advantageous traits survived to reproductive age [1] $\ce{ -> }$ reproduced and passed on alleles [1] $\ce{ -> }$ repeated for many generations [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: The geographic isolation of the Tinamou lineage meant that different populations were subjected to different environmental conditions ($\checkmark$). Random mutations in the populations resulted in genetic variation ($\checkmark$), which may have resulted in different physical and behavioural traits ($\checkmark$). Some traits among Tinamous, such as camouflage or flight abilities, would have been more advantageous than others ($\checkmark$), resulting in higher survival rates($\checkmark$). Therefore, these organisms with advantageous traits were able to pass on their alleles to successive generations ($\checkmark$). - Any two of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ breeding programmes OR carefully selecting individuals for breeding, REASON to increase numbers of rhino OR population size OR genetic diversity OR increase chance of survival of offspring OR produce offspring that can later be released into the wild; OR freeze eggs and sperm OR gametes REASON to preserve genetic diversity OR to use IVF and a closely related rhino species to produce more Javan rhinos [1] $\ce{ -> }$ habitat protection OR restoration projects, REASON to provide safe spaces for rhino OR to provide enough resources for rhino in natural area [1] $\ce{ -> }$ place rhinos into zoos OR nature reserves, REASON to protect from poaching, OR hunting, OR habitat loss, OR for research OR for monitoring OR public awareness OR education OR funding OR to have animals that can be released into the wild after catastrophic events, OR severe disease, in natural habitat [1] $\ce{ -> }$ change laws to protect rhinos, REASON to reduce hunting OR poaching OR export of rhino horn OR use of rhino horn [1] $\ce{ -> }$ sequence DNA of as many Javan rhinos as possible REASON to preserve genetic diversity OR different alleles [1] [2 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: Scientists could prevent the extinction of the Javan rhinoceros by introducing breeding programmes to increase the rhino population ($\checkmark$) or start habitat restoration projects to provide enough area with enough resources to support the rhino ($\checkmark$).

title: Question 8
content:
Which definitions are matched to the correct form of diversity?

Ecosystem diversityGenetic diversitySpecies diversityA.$\hspace{1em}$Different habitats, communities and ecological processesThe type of alleles in a populationGenetic variation within a speciesB.$\hspace{1em}$The number of species and their abundance in an areaPhenotypic variation in a communityGenetic variability within a speciesC.$\hspace{1em}$Variety and abundance of different ecosystems in a geographical areaGenetic variability within a species or populationThe number of species and their abundance in an areaD.$\hspace{1em}$Different habitats, communities and ecological processesThe total number and type of epigenetic markers in a populationThe variety of all life on Earth
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Ecosystem diversity is defined as the variety and abundance of different ecosystems present in a geographical area. Genetic diversity is the genetic variability within a species or population. Species diversity is the number and relative abundance of species found in a specific area. Therefore Choice C is correct.
Choice A is incorrect because genetic diversity does not only refer to the type of alleles in a population but the number of different alleles in a population. Choice B  is incorrect because phenotypic variation refers to differences in observable characteristics, not genetic diversity, and the definition of ecosystem diversity shown in row B is actually the definition for species diversity. Choice D  is incorrect as genetic diversity does not relate to the control of the expression of genes (epigenetics) within a population and the variety of all life on Earth is the definition for biodiversity.

title: Question 13
content:
Which approach, carried out by conservationists in zoos and botanical gardens, defines the transition between ex-situ conservation and in-situ conservation?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Building more capacity in zoos and botanical gardens.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Carrying out artificial selection within zoos and botanical gardens.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Building the population of captive-bred species across zoos and botanical gardens in many countries.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Release of captive-bred species from zoos and botanical gardens into nature reserves.
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice D is correct because the transfer of ex-situ to in-situ means the return of species from captivity to areas that could become their natural habitats again. Nature reserves increase the chances of successful re-introduction, although many other measures would have to be taken to ensure success. 
Choice A is incorrect because building more captive breeding areas will not increase the chances of being able to reintroduce species back into the wild. 
Choice B is incorrect because, whilst artificial selection would allow desirable traits to be selected for in captivity, this would not necessarily guarantee that species would thrive or even survive in a wild habitat again. Artificial selection would also take a long time (measured in years and decades for some species in particular), as successive generations are bred. 
Choice C is incorrect because having more animals in captivity and plants in botanical gardens would do little to increase the chances of those species being successfully reintroduced to the wild. A large captive population serves no natural purpose to conservation unless a species is released into the wild at some stage. Keeping species in captive breeding might be called ‘preservation’, but it is not ‘conservation’ in its truest sense.

title: Question 14
content: - Outline why scientists must have several approaches to conserve biodiversity. [3] - There are approximately 80 Javan Rhinoceros (Rhinoceros sondaicus) in the world. Discuss the environmental and economic implications the Indonesian government must consider before volunteering the Javan Rhinoceros to the EDGE programme. [5] - Explain why rapid human population growth is linked to the current biodiversity crisis. [7]
markScheme: - Any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ no single approach is sufficient OR establishing conservation areas is often effective, but without reintroduction of lost species it will have limited success OR other suitable example showing that when one approach is used, another is required for effective conservation [1] $\ce{ -> }$ different species OR ecosystems require different measures [1] $\ce{ -> }$ not all methods are affordable for different countries OR organisations, OR governments [1] $\ce{ -> }$ biodiversity encompasses a vast range of organisms, habitats, and ecosystems with different interdependencies [1] $\ce{ -> }$ socio-economic factors need to be considered to ensure that conservation efforts take into account local communities' needs and interests [1] $\ce{ -> }$ ongoing changes in biodiversity may mean that strategies need to be adapted accordingly [1] $\ce{ -> }$ multiple approaches can create a more resilient and effective conservation strategy [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Scientists must have multiple approaches to conserve biodiversity as no single approach is sufficient ($\checkmark$), different species require different methods ($\checkmark$) and not all methods are affordable for different governments ($\checkmark$). - Any five of the following (implications must be stated): Environmental negative considerations $\ce{ -> }$ disruption of current food chains OR webs [1] Environmental positive considerations $\ce{ -> }$ restoration of food webs OR chains [1] $\ce{ -> }$ habitats OR forests will have to be restored [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the Javan Rhinoceros is a keystone species, so conserving this species would indirectly protect the ecosystem [1] Economic negative considerations $\ce{ -> }$ can be expensive to put rhinos in breeding programmes OR zoos, OR EDGE program would require financial investments in research OR monitoring, OR conservation initiatives [1] $\ce{ -> }$ land that has been used for urbanisation OR businesses OR agriculture will have to be reforested [1] $\ce{ -> }$ local communities might rely on the same resources as the rhinoceros, OR local communities' livelihoods might be impacted by conservation measures [1] Economic positive considerations $\ce{ -> }$ increase tourism in the area [1] $\ce{ -> }$ may improve international cooperation OR trade agreements, OR foreign investments [1] [5 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Before volunteering the Javan rhinoceros to the EDGE programme, economic considerations must be taken into account. For example, protecting the Javan rhinoceros would likely increase tourism in the area ($\checkmark$) as people will travel to the country to see the rhinos. However, it can be expensive to put rhinos into breeding programmes ($\checkmark$) or reforest land that has been urbanised ($\checkmark$), and this may be unaffordable for the Indonesian government. A positive environmental consideration is that reforestation will increase biodiversity ($\checkmark$) in the area. However, it may also result in disruption of current, stable food chains ($\checkmark$)in the area. - Any seven of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ more hunting OR poaching OR for food OR resources, which endangers animals [1] $\ce{ -> }$ loss of habitats due to urbanisation OR agriculture [1] $\ce{ -> }$ increased agriculture can lead to a monoculture OR a loss in diversity [1] $\ce{ -> }$ deforestation for building infrastructure OR resources such as paper OR agriculture [1] $\ce{ -> }$ increased pollution due to increased vehicles OR global transport OR industry OR factories can cause damage to organisms OR contribute to global warming [1] $\ce{ -> }$ increased use of fertilisers leading to eutrophication [1] $\ce{ -> }$ increased spread of diseases to plants OR animals due to increased global transport [1] $\ce{ -> }$ increased risk of spread of invasive species due to increased global transport [1] $\ce{ -> }$ increased spread of pests due to increased air travel damaging agriculture OR forest ecosystems [1] [7 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Rapid human population growth is linked to the current biodiversity crisis because as the global population grows, there is an increased need for resources which can result in loss of habitat due to increased agriculture ($\checkmark$), an increase in the use of fertilisers which can result in eutrophication ($\checkmark$) and more hunting of animals ($\checkmark$) which lowers animal populations. An increase in agriculture which utilises monocultures lowers species diversity in the area ($\checkmark$). An increase in the human population is also correlated with increased global transport, which can result in increased pollution, which contributes to global warming ($\checkmark$), which can have a detrimental effect on ecosystems and also can result in an increased spread of invasive species ($\checkmark$) and pests ($\checkmark$), which lowers biodiversity within ecosystems. A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information. [1]

content: Mountain gorillas (Gorilla beringei beringei) were reclassified from "Critically Endangered" to "Endangered" by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) in November 2018. This change in status was a significant conservation success story, reflecting the positive impact of concerted efforts by governments, conservation organisations, and local communities to protect and increase the population of this subspecies of the eastern gorilla. Explain how zoos play a critical role in the conservation of endangered species. [2]
markScheme: - The following $\ce{ -> }$ 109.16% OR 109.2% [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: $\dfrac{(1004 - 480)}{480} \times 100\%$ = 109.16% ($\checkmark$) - Any three of the following $\ce{ -> }$ animal husbandry facilities to help prevent death from disease or injury [1] $\ce{ -> }$ maintain detailed records OR pedigrees OR known studbooks to track genetic lineage used to choose breeding pairs to maintain genetic diversity OR minimise inbreeding [1] $\ce{ -> }$ exchange animals between different institutions to introduce new genetic diversity [1] $\ce{ -> }$ captive breeding OR artificial insemination OR in vitro fertilisation increases chance of successful breeding OR means they do not have to find a mate [1] $\ce{ -> }$ reintroduction programs OR release animals into wild [1] $\ce{ -> }$ scientists OR researchers can study the species up close OR in detail for greater understanding of how to protect it in-situ [1] $\ce{ -> }$ educational programs to educate the public about the importance of animal conservation [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Zoos facilitate the exchange of animals between institutions ($\checkmark$) and maintain detailed records to track genetic lineage used to choose breeding pairs to introduce new genetic diversity ($\checkmark$). Artificial insemination also increases the success rate of breeding ($\checkmark$) endangered species. Moreover, zoos are instrumental in reintroducing programs that release animals back into the wild, directly contributing to restoring natural populations ($\checkmark$) and ecosystems. - Any two of the following $\ce{ -> }$ research to make sure control organism specifically targets invasive species OR does not affect native species OR does not damage ecosystem OR habitats OR food chains [1] $\ce{ -> }$ conditions in the target environment should support the survival of the control species [1] $\ce{ -> }$ control species should have a natural control OR predator [1] $\ce{ -> }$ control species should not spread outside the targeted area OR should not become an invasive species themselves [1] $\ce{ -> }$ long-term monitoring plans to observe the effects of the biocontrol species [1] $\ce{ -> }$ possible socio-economic impacts OR consider ethical OR cultural OR social implications of control species should be assessed [1] $\ce{ -> }$ plan should be developed in case species need to be controlled OR eradicated [1] [2 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Before using biological control, it is crucial to conduct thorough research to ensure that the control organism specifically targets the invasive species without impacting native species or the ecosystem ($\checkmark$). Additionally, the conditions in the target environment must support the survival of the control species ($\checkmark$) , ensuring it can effectively reduce the invasive population without becoming invasive itself($\checkmark$).

title: Question 21
content: The graph below shows Biodiversity Intactness, a long-term indicator that measures how much original biodiversity remains within terrestrial communities on the continents, based on levels from around 1500 A.D., when records began. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/af00fec2-0075-40c9-8a41-072c06650376/images/1ad75b4e-1e66-416a-87f8-4d878e1c4179/BI2808%20-%20Bi2813%20A4.2%20PQ%20MCQ%20and%20SAQ%20PhilCh.jpeg.JPEG) [Source: adapted from WWF (2024) Living Planet Report 2024 – A System in Peril. WWF, Gland, Switzerland http://bit.ly/4jzPxrE. Retrieved 30 April 2025, Public Domain] - - Using data from the graph, compare and contrast biodiversity in Asia and Europe. [2] - Suggest reasons for the difference(s) you highlighted in part (a) (i) [3] - Outline two reasons why the graph might give an inexact picture of global biodiversity loss. [2] - Certain Asian species, including the Chinese Crocodile Lizard (Shinisaurus crocodilurus), have been selected for the EDGE of Existence programme in Asia, whereas another endangered species, the Asian elephant (Elephas maximus), is not on the EDGE of Existence list. Suggest why. [3]
markScheme: - - any two of the following (must include one similarity and one difference to gain full marks) Similarity: $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH showed a high level (close to 1.0) in 1800 [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH declined from 1800 to 1950 [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH showed an overall decline 1800 - 2024 OR in the period of study [1] Difference: $\ce{ -> }$ Asia fell steeply from 1950-2000 WHEREAS Europe recovered in that period [1] $\ce{ -> }$ Asia continues to decline (in 2024) WHEREAS Europe is stable OR increasing [1] [2 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: A similarity is that both continents’ biodiversity fell from 1800 to 1950 ($\checkmark$). By contrast, Europe’s biodiversity increased from 1950 onwards, whereas Asia’s continues to decline in the present day ‘any two of the following (must include one similarity and one difference to gain full marks) ($\checkmark$). - any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ better awareness OR education in Europe [1] $\ce{ -> }$ weaker environmental protection law in Asia [1] $\ce{ -> }$ less poverty OR more access to money to fund biodiversity work in Europe [1] $\ce{ -> }$ more reliance on subsistence farming in Asia [1] $\ce{ -> }$ less human population growth in Europe since 1950 OR high population density in Asia [1] $\ce{ -> }$ more deforestation OR urbanisation in Asia since 1950 [1] $\ce{ -> }$ European OR American companies operating in Asia; accept palm oil plantation [1] $\ce{ -> }$ theft OR trafficking OR poaching OR illegal wildlife trading OR of Asian native species [1] $\ce{ -> }$ conflict OR political instability in some Asian regions limits long-term biodiversity policy implementation [1] $\ce{ -> }$ higher rate of industrialisation OR infrastructure development in Asia since 1950 [1] accept converse arguments [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Asia’s rapid economic growth and population growth have put pressure on natural resources ($\checkmark$). An example could be the draining of wetlands and deforestation to create city space for housing ($\checkmark$). Weaker laws and law enforcement in Asia ($\checkmark$) have led to a rise in poaching and trafficking of endangered species, and this can lead to eventual extinction. Non-Asian companies have made large agricultural investments in Asia such as large-scale palm oil plantations, which damage the ecosystem in native tropical forest areas ($\checkmark$). - any two of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ only terrestrial ecosystems OR land are covered in the data OR there is no information on aquatic OR seas OR ocean ecosystems [1] $\ce{ -> }$ there is no distinction between subcontinents such as North and South America [1] $\ce{ -> }$ there is no distinction between kingdoms OR between plants and animals OR microorganisms [1] $\ce{ -> }$ data collection in 1800 will have been less sophisticated OR accurate than 2024 [1] $\ce{ -> }$ biodiversity in 1500 OR baseline data was already influenced by human activity [1] $\ce{ -> }$ indicator may rely on modelled OR estimated data rather than direct field measurements [1] [2 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The data only covers terrestrial ecosystems, so takes no account of aquatic organisms ($\checkmark$). Also, methods of measuring biodiversity in 2024 will be a lot more accurate than those used in previous centuries ($\checkmark$). - any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ the elephant has close genetic relatives OR more close relatives (than the crocodile) [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the lizard is more evolutionarily unique (than the elephant) [1] $\ce{ -> }$ conservation data on the elephant is insufficient OR not up-to-date (to qualify for EDGE) [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the elephant may not be globally endangered OR it may be endangered in one country only OR have a healthy population in other countries [1] $\ce{ -> }$ there is better ex-situ conservation OR better global zoo OR captive populations of the elephant than the lizard [1] $\ce{ -> }$ lizard may occupy a more restricted OR fragmented habitat, increasing extinction risk [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The Chinese crocodile lizard may be very distinct genetically from its nearest relative, which gives it priority for selection into the EDGE programme, whereas the elephant has more close relatives ($\checkmark$). The elephant is a popular species for zoos and conservation projects, so there will be higher populations in captivity ($\checkmark$), making its extinction risk lower. Also, the elephant may be endangered in one country but may exist in large populations elsewhere, lowering its risk of global extinction danger ($\checkmark$).

title: Question 24
content: The Eurasian beaver (Castor fiber) has been described as a species that promotes biodiversity. Beavers are herbivores that feed on freshwater plants and tree bark. They use their sharp front teeth to fell trees and use the logs and branches to build dams that create pools in which they can build their lodge. A beaver lodge is a construction in which they nest and raise their young, providing protection from predators. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/137391ca-319d-43a2-9119-cf4e9aa52801/images/0716c3a5-4515-4c2c-9098-2dc170bfb110/BI1684%20fig1.png) [Source: Jerzy Strzelecki, retrieved July 2024 from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Castor_fiber_07(js),_Narew_River, _Poland.jpg, copyright under CC BY-SA 3.0] - Suggest ways in which the reintroduction of beavers can increase biodiversity. [4] The effect of introducing beavers on the species diversity of birds and bats was studied in four areas: on river banks, one without any beaver activity and one where beavers are present, and then ponds, again, one without beaver activity and one where beavers were present. The graph below shows the calculated Simpson’s reciprocal index of Diversity for each area. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/137391ca-319d-43a2-9119-cf4e9aa52801/images/536e088c-9e87-4ae5-902d-c81de6be0cb0/BI1684%20fig2.png) [©Revision Village 2024] - State two necessary measurements to calculate Simpson’s reciprocal index of diversity. [1] - Calculate the percentage increase in the species diversity of bats in the pond after the introduction of the beaver. [2] Beavers became extinct in the UK over 400 years ago. Reintroduction programmes are now being carried out in various regions of the UK. - Suggest three anthropogenic activities that could have led to the extinction of the beavers in the UK. [3]
markScheme: - any four of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ many different habitats OR niches are created by beaver activity [1] $\ce{ -> }$ dams create pools that slow the run-off of rivers, benefiting plant rooting [1] $\ce{ -> }$ dams generate wetlands that harbour insect OR invertebrate species [1] $\ce{ -> }$ this promotes a food chain with consumers such as birds [1] $\ce{ -> }$ pools are habitats for aquatic plants OR fish [1] $\ce{ -> }$ felling trees allows sunlight onto the forest floor, benefiting ground-level plants and shrubs [1] $\ce{ -> }$ fallen trees are a source of food for microorganisms OR detritivores [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The activity of beavers creates many habitats for other organisms ($\checkmark$), with an overall increase in biodiversity. For example, the felling of trees opens up patches of ground to sunlight, promoting ground-level vegetation ($\checkmark$). The pools created by beaver dams attract insects ($\checkmark$) and the consumers (such as birds) that feed on those insects ($\checkmark$). Dams slow the run-off of rainwater which has a beneficial effect on plant roots which are not washed away by fast-flowing water ($\checkmark$). The pools also attract fish species and aquatic plants that can oxygenate the pond water ($\checkmark$); beavers do not eat fish, so there is no harm to the fish from them. - the following: $\ce{ -> }$ total number of different species in the area OR species richness AND total number of organisms of each species OR species evenness [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Two measurements needed to calculate Simpson’s Diversity Index are the total number of species in the area and the total number of organisms of each species($\checkmark$). - the following: $\ce{ -> }$ percentage increase = {(final volume - initial volume)/initial volume} $\times$ 100% [1] OR {(0.81-0.51) / 0.51} $\times$ 100% $\ce{ -> }$ 58.8% (allow numbers between 52 and 64%) [1] [2 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Percentage increase = {(p.81$-$0.51) / 0.51} x 100% ($\checkmark$) = $-$58.8% ($\checkmark$) - any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ hunting for fur OR castoreum [1] $\ce{ -> }$ habitat destruction OR the draining of wetlands OR other hydrological changes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ deforestation OR logging OR increase in agricultural land [1] $\ce{ -> }$ water pollution [1] $\ce{ -> }$ fragmentation of landscape [1] $\ce{ -> }$ urbanisation OR industrial development OR road construction [1] $\ce{ -> }$ introduction of alien species [1] $\ce{ -> }$ trade OR travel leading to introduction of disease [1] $\ce{ -> }$ use of pesticides OR herbicides OR agricultural chemicals [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The extinction of beavers in the UK may have been caused by overhunting for their valuable fur and castoreum ($\checkmark$), combined with extensive habitat destruction due to the draining of wetlands ($\checkmark$) and deforestation for agricultural expansion ($\checkmark$). Additionally, the introduction of non-native species ($\checkmark$) and diseases, through international travel, ($\checkmark$) further contributed to their decline.

title: Question 25
content:
The graph shows the global human population since 1700 CE, with a projection made to 2086.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fc62bbd6-bbe9-4221-9a0b-b191f799f8dd/images/5e38479b-021b-42bf-9f22-5749b575d27f/QuesEdit2.png)


[© Revision Village 2025]

According to the projection, what will be the percentage population increase between 2000 and 2050 CE?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 27%
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 38%
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 62%
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 88%
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice C is correct because the global human population in 2000 was 6.0 billion, projected to increase to 9.7 billion by 2050. 
The increase is:
9.7 billion − 6.0 billion = 3.7 billion
To calculate the percentage increase:
Percentage increase = ($\dfrac{\ce{increase}}{\ce{population in 2000}}) \times 100$%
= ($\dfrac{\ce{3.7 billion}}{\ce{6.0 billion}}) \times 100$% = 61.67%
All the choices are stated to 2 significant figures, so rounding this answer to two significant figures gives 62%.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fc62bbd6-bbe9-4221-9a0b-b191f799f8dd/images/254de718-6f94-46dc-b122-0decdf87d016/AnsEdit2.png)


Choices A, B and D are incorrect because they all contain calculation errors.
